title: Almost half of bird species at risk of extinction as worrying state of nature in UK revealed
lead: The first State of Nature report in four years has found that nearly one in six UK species is at risk of disappearing due to intensified farming and climate change
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: Britain’s  are not “up to scratch”, environmentalists have said, after a landmark report .
Without action, they warned, the situation would only get worse, with the countryside reduced to monoculture farming and non-native species.

The State of Nature report, compiled by more than 60 environmental NGOs and charities, tracks the abundance and distribution of more than 10,000 species in the UK and the British Overseas Territories with data going back to 1970.

The latest edition, the first  found that nearly one in six species were at risk of being lost from Great Britain. On average, species had declined 19 per cent since monitoring began, with skylarks, for example, dropping 59 per cent in abundance.
The major causes behind the decline were the  from the 1950s onwards and , the report found.

Craig Bennett, chief executive of the , said it was up to politicians to turn the situation around. “This next parliament will be the most important in my lifetime for nature and climate action,” he said, adding, “Nature recovery is fundamental to tackling climate change and improving people’s lives – history will not be kind to politicians who ignore this truth.”
Groups involved in the study said that conservationists already knew what policies worked but that it was not yet being done on a big enough scale.
Beccy Speight, the RSPB’s chief executive, said of the findings: “The UK’s is better studied than in any other country in the world and what the data tell us should make us sit up and listen”.

She added: “We know that conservation works and how to restore ecosystems and save species. We need to move far faster as a society towards nature-friendly land and sea use, otherwise the UK’s nature and wider environment will continue to decline and degrade, with huge implications for our own way of life.”
Richard Gregory, head of monitoring at the RSPB, said that more needed to be done both in supposedly protected areas and on farmland across the country.
“We have huge swathes of land given over to national parks and Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONBs) and so on. And we have all these protected areas, but they’re not being really protected. .”
National Parks England was approached for comment.

Twenty-six per cent of the UK’s land area is covered either by a national park or an AONB, but according to a report by the House of Lords this summer just 6.5 per cent meets the international criteria for being protected for nature.
The UK has pledged to protect 30 per cent of its land for nature by 2030.

Mr Gregory said that the sheer volume of farmland, meanwhile, meant that small tweaks to agriculture could have big impacts. “That would be relatively easy to do with the will because we have the knowledge,” he said.

Across the country, Westminster and the devolved governments have launched various subsidy schemes aimed at making farming more nature friendly. However, the report found that only a fraction of farmland was covered, ranging from 28.5 per cent in Wales, to just 4.8 per cent in Northern Ireland.

Despite the bleak overall picture, the authors of the report were keen to highlight projects that had brought species back from the brink. For example, rock lobster or crawfish was on the brink of extinction in the 70s and 80s but had increased in distribution by 576 per cent.
The report found that , with 43 per cent of species at risk of localised extinction in Britain, while 31 per cent of amphibians and reptiles were also at risk.
For terrestrial mammals, more than a quarter of species were in danger of extinction, including hedgehogs and red squirrels.
The picture was also grim for plantlife, with 54 per cent of species having decreased in distribution.

As well as plants and animals being in decline, the report found that the UK’s landscapes were in a poor condition. Just 7 per cent of broadleaved woodlands and 25 per cent of peatland were classified as in good ecological condition.
, said the Government had put into law the requirement to halt the decline in nature and pointed to the target to protect 30 per cent of land for nature.

“At the start of this year, I published our comprehensive Environmental Improvement Plan, setting out how we will create and restore at least 500,000 hectares of new wildlife habitats, starting with 70 new wildlife projects including 25 new or expanded National Nature Reserves,” she said.
“We also continue to , plant more trees and through our world-leading environmental farming schemes support farmers to produce food sustainably and profitably.”
The report is not without success stories.

Among the creatures to have done well since 1970 was the red kite, which was once extinct in England and Scotland. It now numbers more than 4,400 breeding pairs, a seven fold increase over the last five decades.
Meanwhile, the wood bristle moss has boomed thanks to a decrease in sulphur dioxide emissions, which causes acid rain. The bryophyte has increased its range by 170 square kilometres.

Other species, however, are not doing well at all. Hedgehog numbers appear to have more than halved since 1970s, while red squirrel abundance has dropped 37 per cent. Puffin populations crashed by 30 per cent in the mid-2000s and have not recovered.

title: ‘Truly frightening’ that water companies can’t meet investment targets, say river campaigners
lead: Ofwat found the industry had spent just 73% of the funds available, raising fears that it doesn’t have the capacity the build the much bigger projects needed in future
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: A failure by water companies to hit investment limits is a “truly frightening” sign that they may have lost the capacity to properly invest in infrastructure and reduce pollution, campaigners have warned.

Ofwat, the water regulator, sets a level at which water companies can charge customers so as to fund so-called enhancements, including improving the security of water supply and reducing environmental impacts.

On Tuesday, showing that they spent just 73 per cent of the approximately £7bn in funding allocated for the 2020-23 period. Overall, enhancement spending should account for around one-fifth of company spending.
Across 17 companies that provide water and/or sewage services, 13 failed to spend the full amount. Only United Utilities overspent by any considerable figure.

The largest underspends were by Yorkshire Water, which had permission to invest more than £800m and spent around £300m, and Thames Water, which spent approximately £700m of its nearly £1.2bn allowance.
The industry has blamed a number of factors for the shortfall, including the lingering effects of Covid, rampant inflation and planning delays.
There have  that water companies may be unable to raise the capital needed to fund improvements, but Ofwat’s report suggests that even with money available the industry struggles to get things built.
Nick Measham, chief executive of WildFish, which  and improve drought resilience, told i that it was a worrying sign for the future.
“This is really scary that this industry doesn’t have the capacity to complete capital projects,” he told i, “it’s truly terrifying.”
He said years of underinvestment appeared to have left the industry ill-suited to the changes needed.

Under the Government’s existing infrastructure plan, the industry is expected to spend £60bn over the next 27 years to dramatically reduce storm overflows in which sewage is discharged into rivers and seas.
It also has plans to , with seven regions in England forecast to be water stressed by the end of the decade.
Industry insiders  that would push the sector’s capacity for infrastructure development to its limits.
Mr Neasham and other campaigners have been pushing for the industry and ministers to move even faster.

Ofwat itself said in the report that it was concerned by the shortfall, saying: “Customers have provided water companies with funding to deliver service improvements. We are concerned that there are companies that are underspending their enhancement allowance while not achieving their performance targets”.
The report adds: “Given the step up in investment that is likely to be required for the 2025-30 period we expect companies to improve their delivery capabilities over the next two years”.
Water UK, the industry body, said that it expected companies to catch up in the remaining two years of the current investment cycle.

A spokesperson told i: “Construction projects were severely restricted by Covid lockdowns in 2020. Today’s figures show that the industry has been catching up since then, but there is clearly more to do before the 2025 deadline. Ensuring the security of our water supply in the future while protecting the environment will take significant investment. That’s why water companies in England and Wales are proposing record levels of spend over the rest of this decade, with detailed plans set to be published next week.”

Following the publication of the performance report, which showed 12 companies failing to hit their targets, Ofwat announced that £114m would be returned to customers through lower bills. Five companies have been permitted to charge more as a reward for exceeding targets, with the rest paying penalties.
Ofwat said in its performance assessment that not a single company reached its highest grade of performance, “leading”.
Thames, Anglian, Bristol, South East, Welsh Water, Southern and Yorkshire Water all fell into the lowest category,  “lagging”, while the remaining 10 were rated “average”.

Environment Secretary Thérèse Coffey said: “While I acknowledge there is good work ongoing in some companies – cleaning up waterways and investing in vital infrastructure – there is simply not enough of it. The fact that not a single water company is classified as ‘leading’ is unacceptable. Our water and sewerage systems are highly complex and under increasing pressure – but that is no excuse”.
Ofwat was approached for comment.

title: Temperatures of 75°C will one day wipe out humanity – but not for another 250 million years
lead: The problems we are already facing as a result of climate change show just how monumental they will be millions of years from now at much higher levels of warming, researchers argue
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Scientists are predicting a bout of  so great it will wipe out the human race even if greenhouse gas emissions were cut to zero tomorrow.
But this won’t happen for another 250 million years.
Researchers have forecast the first mass extinction since the dinosaurs died out 66 million years ago – with temperatures set to reach as high as 75°C and humidity becoming so great it will be
The hottest day ever recorded was 56.7°C in California’s Death Valley in July 1913, according to the World Meteorological Organization, the body recognised as keeper of world records.

Based on the first-ever supercomputer climate models of the distant future, scientists say their research demonstrates how climate extremes will dramatically intensify as the world’s continents very slowly merge to form one hot, dry and largely uninhabitable supercontinent.
When this happens, the study predicts temperatures that are routinely hitting 40°C to 50°C, quite often climbing up to around 65°C and even 75°C – combined with extreme humidity.
Alexander Farnsworth, one of the researchers at Bristol University, told i: “In some places we have some daily weather extremes that can reach upwards of 65°C to 75°C in our simulations.

“The hotter it gets the more humid it can also get. And humidity really matters. It can mean the difference between being able to sweat to cool down in hot temperatures and not being able to – leading to death.
“This would ultimately seal our fate. Humans – along with many other species – would expire.”
The temperature rise will result from three factors, the scientists claim, two of which relate to the formation of the supercontinent known as Pangea Ultima.

First, the Tectonic processes in the Earth’s crust that are slowly bringing the continents together to create a single supercontinent will lead to more frequent volcanic eruptions, which release huge amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, warming the planet.

Second, much of the cooling effect of the sea of the sea will be lost. The oceans absorb far more heat than the land, curbing temperature rises in hotter weather in coastal areas and inland.  As most of the Earth’s surface moves much further from the ocean in the supercontinent that cooling benefit will be reduced  – in a process known as the “continental effect”.

Finally, the sun will become about 2.5 per cent brighter in the next 250 million years, adding more energy to the Earth and further warming the world. This is part of a trend, common among all stars, in which hydrogen is converted into helium at an ever-faster rate, in a process called fusion.
These resulting temperature rises also increase humidity because as atmosphere warms, it can hold more moisture.

“The newly emerged supercontinent would effectively create a triple whammy, comprising the continentality effect, hotter sun and more CO2 in the atmosphere, of increasing heat for much of the planet,” Dr Farnsworth said.

Although human-induced climate change and global warming is likely to be a growing cause of heat stress and mortality in some regions, research suggests the planet should largely remain habitable until this seismic landmass change in the deep future.
But when the supercontinent forms, findings indicate only somewhere between 8 per cent and 16 per cent of land would be habitable for mammals, scientists have said.

“If we look at humans’ natural ability to survive extreme heat then there are several heat-stress thresholds that can’t be crossed in general. Firstly, exposure to Wet Bulb temperatures, which consider heat and moisture, above 35°C for over six hours would be fatal. This even considers total inactivity, full shade, absence of clothing and unlimited drinking water.
“Likewise, Dry Bulb temperatures (what you measure on a thermometer) above 40°C and low humidity for a sustained period of time is also lethal,” Dr Farnsworth said.
Many other species are unlikely to fare much better than humans and other mammals.

“We only looked at mammals, but it would certainly not be a fun place for other species. The fact that much of the continents become aridified – removing a lot of the vegetation on which mammals and other species survive would make life difficult for most species.

“And plants, in general, do not like temperatures above 40°C. Plants underpin the food pyramid, so if you start to remove them over vast areas you stress the rest of the species, such as insects, which rely on them and subsequently the higher ‘trophic level’ species that in turn rely on them as a food source.”
He argued that there may be a way round total human extinction with the right technology but says that would be a mammoth and highly complex task with no guarantee of success.
In the most shorter term, Eunice Lo, also of Bristol University, said “it is vitally important not to lose sight of our current climate crisis”.

“While we are predicting an uninhabitable planet in 250 million years, today we are already experiencing extreme heat that is detrimental to human health. This is why it is crucial to reach net-zero emissions as soon as possible,” she said.
found that more than 4,500 deaths were linked to extreme temperatures on the hottest days of 2022’s record-breaking heatwave.
It found there were an estimated 4,507 heat-related deaths over the hottest days in England, the most deaths in a 35-year period between 1988 and 2022.
In the warming study, the scientists applied climate models, simulating temperature, wind, rain and humidity trends for the next supercontinent expected to form in the next 250 million years.
To estimate the future level of CO2 the team used models of tectonic plate movement, ocean chemistry and biology to map out inputs and outputs of CO2.

The future CO2 calculations were led by Professor Benjamin Mills, at the University of Leeds, who said: “We think CO2 could rise from around 400 parts per million (ppm) today to more than 600 ppm many millions of years in the future. Of course, this assumes that humans will stop burning fossil fuels, otherwise we will see those numbers much, much sooner.”
The study is published in the journal Nature.

title: Jobs and investment at risk over year of uncertainty following Net Zero U-turn, business leaders warn
lead: Labour has already pledged to restore the 2030 petrol and diesel car ban and energy efficiency requirements on landlords, leaving firms guessing on the UK’s climate policy until the next election.
author: Arj Singh

body.text: A year of pre-election uncertainty has been sparked by   which will cost the UK jobs and damage the economy, business leaders and climate experts have warned.
The Prime Minister controversially U-turned on a string of climate pledges on Wednesday, including delaying the 2030 ban on new petrol and diesel cars to 2035.
Labour has said will reverse the decision if it wins power, while also rejecting Mr Sunak’s scrapping of requirements on landlords to meet new energy efficiency regulations.

A Shadow Cabinet Minister told i that Labour has heard from car manufacturers that they will carry on” work towards the 2030 date, but said it was “outrageous” that manufacturers who have spent “hundreds of millions on production lines because they were told to by the Government” were now “at a competitive disadvantage”.

The “ambiguity” triggered by the announcement has undone “years of work” in “depoliticising the debate and building investor confidence”, the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) director-general Shevaun Haviland said in an article for i.
“A year out from the likely date of the next General Election, all parties should be engaging in a long-term, stable approach to Net Zero.”
She warned that companies were likely to make investments in competitors like the United States, the EU and China which are “surging ahead” in the race for clean power and technology.

“Conflicting messaging mystifies net zero and diverts much-needed investment to more stable policy environments elsewhere, with the UK losing out on high quality jobs for the future which damages our economic prospects,” she said.
The concern was echoed by green policy experts.

Peter Chalkey, director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU): “The chaos of the past two days leaves investor confidence shaken, particularly as it comes off the back of the Government’s recent failure to secure new offshore wind farms in its own auction, an error that’s cost bill payers a billion pounds.
“Investors will be asking themselves could a possible Labour government after the next election restore that confidence with a more stable policy environment.

“In the meantime though, with the US incentivising and attracting huge sums of net zero investments, the PM’s U-turns will likely put off or delay projects that would have created jobs. The PM has prioritised politics over the economy.
“The UK’s net zero economy is worth £70bn but can’t be taken for granted.”
Ed Matthews, head of campaigns at E3G climate think tank: “Absolutely unquestionably, we’re going to be in a period of investor instability over the next year.

“Because [companies] will now have less confidence in the Government’s plan to deliver on the net zero target, but they will also know that if Labour win the next election, they will be far more ambitious.
“I think for the car industry, they know that it’s highly likely that this target could be reinstated in a year’s time.
“So on one hand they’ll be planning on that basis, but the bigger problem, is about the economic opportunity for the UK as a whole.
“These companies have a choice about where to invest, and we’re locked in a race to Zero with the US, China and Europe.
“And they are steaming ahead in that race at the moment, while we’re already behind.
“So the decision to delay the 2030 ban will just undermine the confidence of investors further that the UK is a serious place to invest in green technology.
“It will be damaging to investment in green industry and green technology.”

:  “We’ve been through all the numbers, we’ve looked at the range of policies that we’ve got in place… we have consistently over-delivered in all our previous carbon budgets, we’ve consistently over-delivered despite everyone saying we were behind,” he said.

Mr Sunak continued: “We are absolutely not slowing down efforts to combat climate change. I am very proud of our country’s leadership. We have decarbonised faster than any other major economy in the G7, not a fact you hear reported that often.”
Delaying the ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars to 2035: Labour would reverse this decision and bring the ban back to 2030

Scrapping measures to force landlords or homeowners to upgrade homes to an energy performance certificate (EPC) of grade C or higher by 2035: Shadow Net Zero Secretary Ed Miliband said Labour does not support watering down obligations on landlords to improve the energy efficiency of rental homes, in a signal it would reverse this

Scrapping the 2035 ban on gas boilers: Labour has not yet outlined a policy response this decision from Mr Sunak, although Mr Miliband insisted the party would “set out a plan in government with a date”

Meat tax, frequent flyer tax, “compulsory car sharing” and seven recycling bins: Mr Sunak has been accused of announcing that he was scrapping a series of non-existent policies. Mr Miliband said “we’re not in favor of seven bins” and “I’m certainly not in favour of a meat tax, it’s ridiculous”.

title: King Charles warns of ‘existential threat’ of climate change, one day after Sunak’s green policy U-turn
lead: He urged both nations to ‘strive together to protect the world from our most existential challenge of all – that of global warming’
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: used a speech to the French senate to warn of the “existential threat” of as he urged the UK and France to work together on the issue.
His comments came a day after Rishi Sunak announced that  including pushing the ban on petrol and diesel car sales to 2035.
Opening his speech in English before , the King, who has often , called for a “partnership for sustainability” between Britain and France.

“Just as we stand together against military aggression, so must we strive together to protect the world from our most existential challenge of all – that of , climate change and the catastrophic destruction of nature,” he said.

He went on the warn that the “challenge facing our planet is both great and grave”, but that it had been “been increasingly heartening to see the action that is being taken by our governments, our people and, more and more, by the private sector”.

“I have long felt that our businesses can play a most vital role, working in partnership and harmony with our governments and our people, to channel trillions of dollars to the solutions that will enable a successful transition to a sustainable world,” King Charles continued.

He added that he would be meeting with business leaders from France and Britain later in the day, who had been crucial in “preserving our precious biodiversity and offering essential global leadership”.

King Charles proposed that France and Britain should team up to jointly tackle the climate and biodiversity emergencies with a new version of the 1904 Entente Cordiale pact that sealed the friendship between Paris and London.
“I would like to propose it also becomes an ‘Entente pour la Durabilité’ [Partnership for Sustainability] in order to tackle the global climate and biodiversity emergency more effectively,” he said.
His speech was the first time a member of the Royal Family has address the French upper house since his late mother  did so in 2004.
He went on to thank France for the “great kindness” it had shown the Royal Family and the UK following her death in September 2022.
King Charles began his state visit with a lavish banquet at the Palace of Versailles on Wednesday night hosted by  alongside 200 guests, including celebrities such as Mick Jagger and Hugh Grant.
Following his speech to the senate, the King will visit the  suburb of Saint-Denis, which is home to the French national stadium used for the Rugby World Cup, and the Olympics next year.
He will later tour a flower market and see the ongoing renovations at the Notre Dame Cathedral, which was partially destroyed by a fire in 2019.
The visit is being seen as a chance for the UK to reset its relationship with France after the damaging years following the Brexit referendum.
The EU’s former Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier,] wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, that “this visit is the symbol of a new chapter in the special relationship between our two nations”.

between the two countries, with French Info correspondent Richard Place saying: “Charles III’s visit may seem insignificant. However, it has a political significance. The arrival of the British royal couple sends an important message.”
French daily Le Monde described the visit as “three days to showcase Franco-British friendship”, while Le Figaro focused on Charles’s transformation since he became King last year.
The publication said: “Charles III largely succeeded in his first steps. The day after his mother’s death, he was up to the task. Finding the right tone, the right place.”

title: What will replace gas boilers in 2035? When the UK ban will be, alternatives explained and how heat pumps work
lead: The cut-off for the sale of new gas boilers remains at 2035, with exemptions for struggling households
author: Sally Guyoncourt

body.text: Rishi Sunak has announced  delaying the ban on new petrol and diesel cars and new fossil fuel heating for off-gas-grid homes, but the sale of new gas boilers will still be outlawed from 2035.
In a , the block on the sale of petrol and diesel cars moves from 2030 to 2035.
The ban on installing oil, LPG boilers and new coal heating for off-gas-grid homes is delayed until 2035, instead of phasing them out from 2026.
However, the cut-off for the sale of new gas boilers remains at 2035, with exemptions for households who will struggle financially to make the switch.
The Government is also raising the Boiler Upgrade Grant by 50 per cent to £7,500, to help households who want to replace their gas boilers with a low-carbon alternative such as a heat pump.
The Prime Minister said this was a .
We take a look what the options are to heat homes if gas boilers are no longer the answer.
The legislation does not mean homeowners must scrap existing gas boilers.
But it will affect the installation of any new boilers in a home from 2035, and what property developers can use in new build homes from the same date.
are likely to become one of the most common ways to heat homes as fossil-fuel boilers are phased out.
The Government had been investigating the possibility of  over the coming years to help reach net-zero carbon emissions.

But in July, Grant Shapps, the former energy security secretary, said it was now “unlikely” hydrogen would be used to replace gas-powered boilers because of the need to replace pipework in a switchover.

He told an event at Westminster that he was “a big believer in hydrogen as part of our energy mix in the future” but added: “Hydrogen molecules are very small, you have to replace potentially quite a lot of piping, and of course you’ve got to produce the ‘green’ hydrogen to make the whole thing stack up, the kind of volumes which mean that the transition would be pretty slow.
“So I’m not sure that home heating will be all through hydrogen, it will have a role to play.”
uses technology similar to that found in a refrigerator or an air conditioner.

It extracts heat from a source, such as the surrounding air or geothermal energy stored in the ground, increases it to a higher temperature using electricity, and then transfers the heat to where it is needed around a home.
Air-source heat pumps use the heat energy from the air and ground-source heat pumps use geothermal energy from the ground.

Heat batteries are an emerging technology that uses dense natural materials to store heat at high temperatures that can be released slowly over a 24-hour period. They are designed to charge up during off-peak times when electricity tariffs are lower.
The heat battery concept can be used for a heat battery boiler, which would be a direct replacement for a gas boiler.

Electric boilers are also available, but they can cost up to four times more per year to run if using peak-rate electricity and are unable to meet high demands for heating and hot water, so are best suited to smaller homes and flats.
Biomass boilers operate in the same way as conventional boilers but burn biomass (biological material from plant-based organisms such as wood logs, chips or pellets) rather than fossil fuels.
Solar thermal panels absorb heat from the sun during daylight hours and use that energy to heat a water-based central heating system.
Within the panels are tubes of fluid that take in heat from the sun. This energy is then transferred through a heat exchanger before warming the central heating system or water in a cylinder.

title: Cost of living sees homeowners rethink green upgrades despite widespread support for net zero
lead: Homeowners were slightly less inclined to install all kinds of net zero-related measure in their homes, from heat pumps to energy efficient lightbulbs, a new study has found
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: The has led some homeowners to reconsider making green upgrades such as heat pumps and solar panels to their homes despite widespread support for , a survey has found.

The second Net Zero Homes Index survey, which tracks the willingness of UK families to make home and lifestyle changes to tackle climate change, found households appetite for green measures has declined in the past year – although many still plan to carry out upgrades.

Over the next two years, 28 per cent of homeowners said they were willing to install a heat pump, down from 31 per cent a year ago, according to the nationally-representative survey of 4,007 carried out for British Gas by the Public First consultancy.
Over the same period, their willingness to install better insulation fell from 47 to 46 per cent and to add solar panels, from 42 to 41 per cent.
Plans to install electric vehicle “fast charging points” took the biggest hit, with just 28 per cent saying they were will to install them in the next two years, compared to 34 per cent a year ago.
Energy-efficient lightbulbs and electrical appliances, as well as triple glazing, also saw slight decreases over the period.

The slight decline in enthusiasm for net zero measures is mirrored by a dip in confidence about whether the UK can meet its target to become carbon neutral by 2050 – with the confidence index dropping from 57.5 to 56.5 in the past year.

“In a year that has been particularly difficult for households with the rising cost of living and inflation at a high, we’ve seen these issues reflected in our second Net Zero Homes Index,” said Gail Parker, director of low-carbon homes at British Gas Zero.

“But we are also seeing that people want to make changes to de-carbonise their homes and its key that we work with Government and the rest of the industry to ensure households can make these changes easily and affordably,” she said.
