The research also found that respondents were overwhelmingly receptive to the development with 79 per cent supporting building more on-shore wind, compared to just 7 per cent saying they were opposed.
Meanwhile, nearly nine in 10 respondents supported building more solar power, 83 per cent supported more off-shore wind.
New nuclear remained the most controversial low-carbon energy option, with only 48 per cent supporting it.

The report comes as Rishi Sunak prepares to water down several policies to help the UK reach net zero, such as pushing back bans on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars and the installation of new gas boilers.

Philip Evans, climate campaigner for Greenpeace UK, said: “Much has been said about Rishi Sunak breaking the cross-party consensus on the urgent need to cut carbon emissions, but it’s important to remember this consensus extends far beyond Westminster.

“These survey results show Britain still overwhelmingly wants cheap solar and wind power, clean technologies and energy efficient homes to cut our heating bills. This is what is needed to bring down the cost of living, and is exactly where economic growth is going to happen.”

Imogen Dow, warm homes campaigner at Friends of the Earth, said: “On a day where the Prime Minister has all but steamrolled over the UK’s climate commitments, it’s heartening to see that public appetite for meaningful climate action is completely at odds with the government’s ill-conceived agenda. “Not only are people incredibly supportive of our climate goals, they overwhelmingly want more cheap, green energy, and many have said they’d be willing to make climate-friendly changes to their homes, such as installing home insulation. “This goes against divisive narratives being pushed by those who wish to make climate action a wedge issue – that people are unwilling to accept the scale of change required. It goes without saying that those who’ve done least to cause climate breakdown, including those on low incomes, should not carry the cost burden of going green, but it’s up to government to design policies so that they are fair and equitable. If this was a real priority, the government would be rolling out a street-by-street insulation programme for those who need it most, helping to slash both energy bills and emissions.”
Kathryn Brown, Director of Climate Change and Evidence at The Wildlife Trusts, says:

“In a world reeling from the costs of inaction over net zero, taking control of our carbon emissions is both empowering and essential. The battle against climate change isn’t about a single choice, but a conscious collective shift.

“British Gas’ new report shows that people are passionate about nature and climate issues, and determined to do what they can to help. It’s about accountability, resilience, and embracing a three-step approach: calculation of carbon footprint, reduction of emissions, and investment in nature recovery. We each have a unique path to net zero, but together, we forge the road to a sustainability.”

title: Why scrapping net zero low-traffic neighbourhoods and school streets could win Sunak votes and save Tory MPs
lead: The PM’s net zero rethink began in July, as he ordered a review of low-traffic neighbourhoods. Last night Tower Hamlets mayor Lutfur Rahman got there first and scrapped most of his. Pollsters tell i how they think it will play electorally.
author: Hannah Fearn

body.text: In Levenshulme, south Manchester, residents are at war. Half of the neighbours in this once-poor but now steadily gentrifying suburb want controversial traffic-calming measures.

They are keen on the closures of “school streets” and the creation of – areas into which only the residents and staff of local businesses can drive. The other half are infuriated by them, worried about rising council tax and angry about incursions on their liberty.

“Two of my neighbours had an argument on the street about it,” one resident, too anxious to be named, says. “It’s a subject I wouldn’t go near, having to live here. I see all sides of the issue: it’s benefiting some streets, but it’s definitely displacing traffic to boundary roads – because sometimes I am that traffic.”

Angry rows like this are taking place in towns and cities across the country. And the conflict is leading some in national politics to sense an opportunity. In the aftermath of the Conservatives’ unexpected victory in the credited to motorists’ opposition to the expansion of the London wide  – Rishi Sunak is seeking to expand his party’s appeal to fed-up drivers.

In a precursor to this week’s , July saw the Prime Minister announce a . And it could go beyond the proliferation of LTNs set up during lockdown. Whitehall insiders have not ruled out the possibility of a review taking in school streets – the partial closures of roads outside schools that keep them free of cars while children are dropped off and collected.

These traffic calming measures have been sold as  by “helping to drive down congestion” – the .But the politics of low-traffic neighbourhoods and school streets are more complicated than simply relieving voters of a looming financial burden in the way that a . While many fiercely oppose the inconvenience that closing off streets to traffic brings,  the safe, quieter and less polluted roads, particularly where school children are concerned.
So would scrapping these really be canny politics that will bring electoral rewards. Or could it backfire for Mr Sunak?

Lutfur Rahman, the controversial directly-elected mayor of Tower Hamlets, has provided something of a test case. Last night he announced , despite the council’s consultation showing that 57.3 per cent of residents wanted to keep them.  Mr Rahman said there had been attempts to skew the consultation. But his decision to scrap the LTNs, or “Liveable Streets” as they are branded in the borough, was only backed by 41.7 per cent of consultees and has been met with angry protests.

So is this just bad politics from the mayor and the Aspire political party that he founded in Tower Hamlets?  The election last year, in which Mr Rahman won the mayoralty, suggests not.  The former local Labour leader had made opposition to LTNs a central issue in his campaign.

At the top of the list of pledges in Mr Rahman’s manifesto was a promise to: “Reopen our roads and abolish the failed Liveable Streets scheme, which has seen emergency services and vulnerable residents’ access blocked.” He said he would “only introduce traffic reduction measures through consultation with, and by the consent of the people of this borough”.

Mr Rahman went on to not only win the mayoralty but his party, Aspire, gained enough councillors to take control of the council. Within months, Tower Hamlets had removed school streets schemes from outside schools in Bow, to a mixed reaction from parents. And this week he has gone much further by scrapping nearly all LTNs.

As ever with elections, the cause and effect of individual policies is hard to definitively untangle. The politics of Tower Hamlets are particularly complex and, on the other side of the debate, the Green Party, which campaigned in favour of LTNs, won its first seat on the council. But it was Aspire that was propelled into power, having campaigned hard on scrapping them and Mr Rahman has said his victory was a “resounding democratic mandate” for the removal of the road closures.

In Levenshulme, where the debate still rages, it is hard to discern which way the issue is playing from election results. Labour, which has run Manchester Council for years, and is responsible for introducing LTNs and school streets – has held onto to all three council seats in the suburb in recent elections. And this year the Green Party, which has been campaigning strongly in favour of street closures, boosted its position in a Levenshulme seat to second place behind the Labour candidate for the first time and took 31 per cent of the vote.
But independent candidate Jeremy Hoad, who has criticised the council’s LTNs policy, has also seen a rise in his popularity in both the 2022 and 2023 council elections.

A study published by the University of Westminster this year that investigated the relationship between political messages on social media regarding LTNs and councillors’ share of the vote might give Mr Sunak some pause for thought.

Professor Rachel Aldred told i her research found that Labour councillors were more likely to receive a slight uplift in their vote share after posting positive messages about LTNs. But for Conservative candidates, there was no immediate impact in taking a negative stance.

However, national pollsters have much more positive news for the PM, with evidence suggesting that he could benefit electorally from scrapping low-traffic neighbourhoods and school streets. Ipsos Mori carried out countrywide research in 2022 to look at the level of support for creating LTNs.

“Last year we found that half of people support creating low-traffic neighbourhoods in principle, but this has a small fall to 45 per cent if you point out that it would mean you personally could not drive in certain areas unless you lived or worked there, and a bigger fall to 22 per cent if it means a financial trade-off in terms of higher levels of council tax,” Gideon Skinner, Ipsos Mori head of political research, told i.

In 2021, a similar Ipsos study found that the most successful arguments in favour were not linked to but to local benefits such as making areas safer and reducing street accidents. Voters found the most convincing arguments against were the inconvenience of making longer journeys and the disadvantages for those with mobility issues.

According to Mr Skinner, the data gathered by Ipsos suggests that Mr Sunak’s gamble might be worthwhile. “Clearly it can have an impact in a local setting if you can turn it into an issue, as we saw in Uxbridge, and it is an issue that may have some potential to help shore up the Conservatives’ political base – especially if it’s framed more about impact on drivers and perceptions of unfairness rather than climate change or health benefits, or if there is big media campaign about it,” he says.
“It’s not unusual in human nature to see people pay more attention to the negative impacts and those who lose out from any policy than those who benefit.”

And election analyst Sir John Curtice, professor of politics at the University of Strathclyde, says that given it is now a national conversation, a backlash against LTNs may be felt by Tory candidates in Conservative areas that had trialled them buoyed by Boris Johnson’s early championing of the scheme.

However, data gathered by Ipsos Mori also suggests that in the wider political context – with the pressure of rising cost of living and concern about the health of the NHS – the issue isn’t an election-winning one. All these issues, and broader existential matters such as the sense that it’s “time for a change”, poll more highly on voters’ lists of concerns.

Ipsos Mori Global chief executive Ben Page told i that, in his estimation, the campaign on scrapping LTNs could secure “the core vote in a few places, but is not something that is going to reverse a 20-point Labour lead”.

title: Rishi Sunak condemning public to cold homes and polluted air, says heat pump industry
lead: Sources at major installers and manufacturers told i that the 2035 ban on gas boilers, which has now been scrapped, was not actually a major issue for the industry but that removing it sent completely the wrong message
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: British heat pump companies have reacted with dismay to , even as he announced more generous grants for installing the technology.
Industry insiders also , saying that obvious ways to boost the industry and reduce costs for consumers remained stalled.

Chris Norbury, chief executive of E.on UK, accused Mr Sunak of “condemning people to  that are expensive to heat, in cities clogged with dirty air from fossil fuels, missing out on the economic regeneration this ambition brings.”

Sources at major installers and manufacturers told i that the 2035 ban on gas boilers, which has now been scrapped, was not actually a major issue for the industry but that removing it sent completely the wrong message.

One senior industry figure told i that while it would not change the economics of getting a , it could undermine people’s confidence. The public still grumbles about the last Labour government promoting diesel cars, only for them to turn out to be more polluting, the source said.
“This won’t affect people’s spreadsheet calculations, but it might make them worry that the Government will backtrack on support,” they said.

As well as putting off consumers, the industry insiders said the uncertainty created by the Prime Minister’s rhetoric was likely to drive investors elsewhere, leaving the UK importing green technology rather than creating skilled, well-paid jobs.
Heat pump and  prices are falling rapidly, but the UK is competing with the United States, the EU and China for manufacturers and expertise.

“The UK risks minimising the creation of the jobs and the economic upside that would come from the green transition, and it would just become a problem for our balance of payments,” James Murray, cofounder of the Net Zero Festival and editor of BusinessGreen, told i.
One industry source said Mr Sunak’s rhetoric would “turn investors cold” and called trying to compete with heavily subsidised EU and US companies while the UK Government equivocates “quite scary”.

Mr Norbury said of the policy shift: “This is a mis-step on many levels. From a business perspective, companies wanting to invest in the UK need long term certainty to create the jobs and economic prosperity the country needs.”
While Mr Sunak scrapped the 2035 ban, he did announce a 50 per cent increase in the amount of money available under the Boiler Upgrade Scheme for households wishing to buy a heat pump.

The grant will now be worth £7,500, meaning the cost of installing a heat pump could be as little as £500. Octopus Energy announced last week that its latest generation of heat pumps could be installed in a three-bed semi-detached home for £8,000.

However, industry insiders said that the original grant was already generous and other policy changes would have been more effective. For example, green levies fall exclusively on electricity, a legacy from Britain’s era of coal-dominated generation.

The Government previously promised to switch them to gas, but subsequently put the decision out to consultation. Enacting the policy would make heat pumps substantially cheaper to run than a gas boiler in most circumstances.

title: From electric cars to gas boilers – the four green policies Rishi Sunak is considering weakening
lead: In a speech this week the Prime Minister is set to outline a major rowback on several green policies
author: Alannah Francis

body.text: Rishi Sunak is  to ensure they are “proportionate”, in a move that has drawn sharp criticism from across the political spectrum and campaigners.
On Wednesday morning, Home Secretary Suella Braverman denied the Government was .
But in a speech this week  is set to outline a major rowing back on several green policies.

Ms Braverman told Sky News that ministers remain “absolutely committed” to delivering on . She added: “Fundamentally, we’re not going to save the planet by bankrupting the British people.”Here are seven green policies the Government is considering watering down.
A delay on the  is expected to be announced.
It is currently set to be implemented by 2030, in line with what has been Government policy since 2020. However new plans would push this back to 2035.
Ian Plummer, commercial director at online vehicle marketplace Auto Trader, described such a delay as “hugely retrograde”.
He said: “Pushing back the 2030 ban on new petrol and diesel sales by five years is a hugely retrograde step which puts politics ahead of net-zero goals.

“This U-turn will cause a huge headache for manufacturers, who are crying out for clarity and consistency, and it is hardly going to encourage the vast majority of drivers who are yet to buy an electric car to make the switch.”

Mike Hawes, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), said a delay in the ban on the sale of new conventionally fuelled cars could cause drivers to delay switching to electric vehicles.

He told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme: “We’re trying to understand what is going to happen next between this sort of statement [on the 2030 ban] and that policy, and the message it sends consumers which must be incredibly confusing.”
Another key green policy that the Prime Minister is considering weakening, according to documents seen by , is the plan to phase out the installation of gas boilers.
Under existing plans, gas boiler installations are due to be wound down by 2035, but it is expected the Government will now only want 80 per cent to be phased out by that year.
David Cowdrey, director of external affairs at the MCS Foundation, which calls for the widespread adoption of renewable energy, said a relaxation of current plans would send the wrong message.

Mr Cowdrey said: “The potential move to relax the ban on gas boilers by 2035 could severely undermine the confidence of heat pump manufacturers, heating engineers, and homeowners, as well as the Government’s own target on heat pumps.

“A failure to follow through on the promise to phase out gas heating by 2035 could mean higher bills for consumers, continued dependence on polluting fossil fuels, and sends the wrong message to the economy.”

Homeowners and landlords are set to be told there will now not be any new energy efficiency regulations for homes. The Government had been considering issuing fines to landlords who fail to upgrade their properties to a particular standard of energy efficiency.

The Government had targeted off-grid boilers which use fuel such as oil, petroleum or solid fuels – as these produce high greenhouse gas emissions. However there has been criticism that such a fast ban could make fuel poverty worse, especially in rural areas, where such system are more likely to be used and would have to be replaced.The ban is now set to be delayed until 2035, with a target of only 80 per cent of off-grid boilers to be phased out by this time.
Meanwhile, Britons are reportedly set to be told there will be no new taxes to discourage flying and no government policies to alter people’s diets.

The Government had also reportedly been looking at a household recycling scheme that would have featured seven bins – six for recycling and one for general waste – but Mr Sunak is likely to rule out what he considers burdensome recycling policies, the BBC reported.
Shadow climate and net zero secretary Ed Miliband, said: “This is a complete farce from a Tory Government that literally does not know what they are doing day to day.
“Thirteen years of failed energy policy has led to an energy bills crisis, weakened our energy security, lost jobs, and failed on the climate crisis.”

Green Party MP Caroline Lucas, said: “This is pure political game-playing from Sunak, but all of us will pay the price. Delaying energy efficiency measures will mean higher bills and more emissions. Delaying green investment will mean fewer jobs and less prosperity. Delaying petrol ban will mean dirtier air. What a farce.”

Liberal Democrat climate and energy spokesperson Wera Hobhouse said: “What Rishi Sunak should see in front of him is the opportunity to embrace the industries of the future and protect the coming generations from the catastrophic impacts of climate change.
“Instead, he has cowered to the delayers and deniers like the disgraced Liz Truss and adopted wholesale their policies.”

Conservative MP Chris Skidmore, the former chairman of the UK government’s net-zero review, said: “Rishi Sunak still has time to think again and not make the greatest mistake of his premiership, condemning the UK to missing out on what can be the opportunity of the decade to deliver growth, jobs and future prosperity.”
There has been some support for Mr Sunak’s reported plans to dilute his net zero commitments. Tory MP for Lincoln Karl McCartney welcomed the expected policy changes.

“For a long time I have been calling on the Government to take the common sense decision to delay its planned 2030 ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars. Just as countries like France and Germany have done. I am pleased the Government has seen the light,” he said in a statement.

title: VAT loophole means Labour’s school-fees plan could see some parents avoid tax for five years
lead: Legal experts told i that ‘many schools are talking about’ using the loophole, with some even scrambling to set up fees in advance schemes ahead of a potential Labour government
author: Poppy Wood

body.text: Private schools are urging parents to use a pre-payment loophole to avoid paying .
i revealed earlier this week that , rather than “phasing” it in across several academic years as was previously assumed.
It means as soon as the first academic year after the general election if Labour enters No 10.
But headteachers told i they would consider using existing “fees in advance” schemes to avoid forcing parents to pay the “unfair” tax.

Legal experts warned that “many schools are talking about” using the loophole, with some even scrambling to set up pre-payment schemes ahead of a potential Labour government, with a general election expected in autumn 2024.
Most private schools offer pre-payment schemes to parents, which allow them to pay fees in advance and at a discount, and schools invest the money on their behalf.
Half of schools have charitable status, which allows them to earn interest tax-free that they then pass back to parents through higher returns.

Parents are able to pay up to five years of school fees in advance through the schemes, meaning families with multiple children at the most expensive private schools could save hundreds of thousands of pounds if the 20 per cent VAT charge came into force.
i can reveal that some schools have already encouraged parents to make use of the schemes to shield their finances from upcoming “political changes”.
Merchant Taylors’ School, a top private boys’ school near Watford, which charges £25,000 a year, sent out a newsletter to parents in June urging them to use the pre-payment scheme.

It said: “Efforts will continue so that the school is prepared for the political and economic changes that are now emerging, whilst maintaining the high standard of education and facilities that you expect from Merchant Taylors’.
“Our fees in advance scheme may provide parents with a degree of long term assurance in the current climate.”
Merchant Taylors’ was approached for comment.

Top private schools including Eton College and Rishi Sunak’s £49,000-a-year alma mater Winchester College also offer parents fees in advance schemes, although there is no suggestion that they have encouraged their use to avoid VAT under a potential Labour government.

Nick Pietrek, the headteacher at the independent Stafford Grammar School, told i: “I know that there are a number of schools looking at fees in advance schemes as a means around it for the first few years.

“The assumption is that any fees paid in advance would actually be tax exempt. If there are families that are able to, they’re obviously going to try and make use of it. We have now got a policy in place – lots of parents I assume will do that if this VAT charge hits next year.”
Mr Pietrek said private schools, especially the smaller ones, are now being forced to draw up cost-cutting plans to avoid passing on the .
“It’s just not fair. We are a smaller school and we do not have much wiggle room. We effectively have a break even position,” he told i. “The VAT will be a hammer blow.”
Tom Richmond, the director of nonpartisan education think tank EDSK, told i that “parents and independent schools will understandably be keen to minimise the potential impact of VAT on fees”.

Mr Richmond, a former Tory adviser, said it would spark ”considerable interest in paying additional school fees ahead of the next general election”, though it remains unclear the extent to which they would be shielded from extra taxes.

He also warned that fees in advance schemes may only prove beneficial to the “wealthiest families” able to pay huge lump sums up front, “as parents on lower incomes or those who rely on bursaries will struggle to find additional funds in the next few months”.

It is unclear whether use of the tax loophole would dent Labour’s estimates for the money that the VAT charge will raise. The party hopes the , with Sir Keir promising to spend it on efforts to raise education standards across the state school sector.
A report by the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) published in July found that , though it warned that there was the “the potential for tax avoidance behaviour on the behalf of parents or schools”.

Luke Sibieta, a research fellow at the IFS and author of the report, told i that it was “impossible to say” how much the use of fees in advance schemes would affect Labour’s calculations and was “an important source of uncertainty”.
“My assumption is that there might be some distortions in the first year or two, which always happens when you change tax reliefs. But after that, the effects are probably quite marginal,” he said.
Mr Sibieta added that the impact would likely be limited by the fact that “there are few families that can afford to pay fees for multiple years up front”.
It comes as i has found a number of law firms offering legal advice to parents and schools about how to use the loophole .

Crowe, a leading tax and advisory firm, said in a blog post on the subject there was an “opportunity for schools to protect their exempt status on educational services by receiving the school fees in advance”.

It said Labour would likely announce “anti-forestalling legislation” alongside any VAT charge for private schools if it wins the election, meaning “only pre-payments received by the school before the announcement would be treated as VAT exempt”.
Crowe was approached for comment.
Paul Ridout, legal director at law firm Moore Barlow, said there was already widespread discussion among the private school sector about how to use the loophole.

“Schools are certainly talking about it. And I think questions are coming both from schools that have existing schemes, and some schools that are asking ‘well should we be setting this scheme up’,” he told i.

Mr Ridout said it was “probably a fairly small number of schools that are thinking about setting up from scratch – partly because of the the risk of looking to HMRC like tax avoidance, and secondly, [to avoid] looking to the outside world as though you’re fiddling the system slightly”.

However, he added that “schools that have existing fees in advanced schemes can quite sensibly talk to parents and say, ‘look, you will have seen the Labour party’s proposals for removing the VAT exemption. You may also have seen that if you were to to pay for school fees now while they’re still exempt, that saves you from paying VAT on them further down the line'”.

A spokesperson for the Independent Schools Council told i: “Fees in advance schemes are perfectly legitimate and have been used for a number of reasons through the years – for example, when a family has been left a legacy.
“It’s right that parents know all their options for paying fees and these sorts of advance payments are very explicitly not being marketed as a tax loophole.

“In any case, the number of parents who can afford to use fees in advance schemes is very limited; most of our parent base are dual-income households who pay each year from taxed income and it is those families who should be focused on: these are the people Labour’s tax on children’s education would hit hardest.”
HMRC and Labour were both approached for comment.

title: Rishi Sunak risks losing ‘Red Wall’ Tory votes over HS2 and levelling up, poll suggests
lead: Polling shows Prime Minister’s decision to row back on HS2 could cost him at the ballot box
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: risks losing Tory voters in  seats after new polling revealed more than half of those who voted Conservative in 2019 believe the party has “done nothing” to level up the .
The survey also shows that any decision to row back on  could cost the Prime Minister at .

But in a damning verdict of the Tories’ flagship policy, 61 per cent of the electorate in constituencies held by the party believe it has made no inroads in boosting opportunities across the North, including 56 per cent of 2019 Tory voters.
The figures, compiled by Opinium for business lobbying group the Northern Powerhouse Partnership and shared exclusively with i, also reveal deep distrust towards Mr Sunak’s commitment to .
According to the survey, 53 per cent believe the Prime Minister is “not at all” committed to levelling up, including 42 per cent of 2019 Tory voters.
Mr Sunak also has a worse net approval rating than his rival , the poll shows, with the Prime Minister on -24 and the Labour leader on -14.
The research was carried out in Conservative-held seats in the North West – excluding Cumbria – and Yorkshire and the Humber – excluding South Humberside.
Potential plans to cut beyond Birmingham were also criticised, with just 18 per cent of voters supporting any decision to cut the high speed rail line short, while 51 per cent are opposed.
Perhaps even more worryingly for the party, 43 per cent of those who voted Conservative in 2019 said they would be less favourable to the party if they cut HS2.
Similarly, nearly two thirds – 62 per cent – said they do “not trust” the Government’s pledges to improve TransPennine rail services, including 57 per cent of 2019 of Tory voters.
Henri Murison, chief executive of the Northern Powerhouse Partnership, said the results of the poll should be “ringing alarm bells for the Prime Minister”.
“Businesses oppose any decision to cut back HS2 and Northern Powerhouse Rail, as do the mayors of both parties, alongside Tory voters in Conservative-held northern constituencies.”

He added: “No one wants to be remembered as the prime minister who pulled the plug on over a decade of cross-party consensus, not to mention huge amounts of private investment from the UK and overseas.”
Adam Hawksbee, deputy director at Onward, warned that there is “clearly serious political risk in scrapping HS2”.

“The warnings from mayors and businesses in the last few days add to the sense that stepping away from the scheme could undermine the levelling up agenda. Put simply: there’s no way to rebalance our economy without improved connectivity in the Midlands and the North,” he added.

title: Rishi Sunak defends multiculturalism after Suella Braverman said it had ‘failed’
lead: The Prime Minister praised the UK’s “fantastic multicultural democracy” in an apparent contradiction of the Home Secretary’s claim the idea had “failed”.
author: Arj Singh

body.text: has defended multiculturalism in Britain in an apparent rebuke of his Home Secretary, Suella Braverman, who claimed this week that it had “failed”.
The Prime Minister instead praised the UK’s “fantastic multicultural democracy” on Thursday, saying the nation has done an “incredible job of integrating people”.
It came after Ms Braverman on Wednesday warned of what she sees as an “existential threat” of uncontrolled migration as she called for reform of international refugee rules.
She argued the “misguided dogma of multiculturalism” had “failed because it allowed people to come to our society and live parallel lives in it”.
Ms Braverman suggested it has allowed them to “pursue lives aimed at undermining the stability and threatening the security of our society”.
But Mr Sunak, the first British PM of Indian heritage, repeatedly declined to back her comments during a round of regional broadcast interviews ahead of the Tory conference.
Asked by BBC East Midlands if he agreed with Ms Braverman, Mr Sunak said: “I think that this is something that is incredible about this country, is that it is a fantastic multicultural democracy.

“We have done an incredible job of integrating people into society and one of the lovely things about getting the job I have, as the first person from my background to hold this job, that’s a wonderful thing, but it’s also not a big deal in our country.
“I think that speaks to the progress we’ve made over the years and how far we’ve come and something we should all be collectively incredibly proud of.”

Asked if the Home Secretary was wrong, Mr Sunak said it is “important that everyone subscribes to British values” but that he believes “our country has done an incredibly good job of integrating people from lots of different backgrounds”.
meanwhile gave his strongest hint to date that the Government’s rail improvements could be refocused on boosting links across the North rather than .
In a round of often tense interviews with regional radio stations, the Prime Minister repeatedly refused to commit to delivering the future phases of the high-speed rail link beyond .

When pressed on the future of the trainline, he chose to raise the importance of improving speeds and capacity on train journeys from Liverpool to Hull, under the proposed , which he claimed would “drive growth most”.

“East-west, west-east connectivity across northern towns and cities is important,” he said. “I’ve said it for years. Now I’m over on the east side of the North. I know that that connectivity across the Pennines is not good enough. And it’s not just Liverpool to Manchester, it’s all the way across the North.”

“And that is probably the thing that will drive the most growth, create the most jobs if we can get that right. And that’s why we are investing in doing that. But we obviously need to do more, go further, but having greater frequency, greater capacity and shorter journey times all the way from Liverpool, all the way over to the east coast is actually I think the thing that will make the biggest difference to unlocking the massive potential across the North.”
Mr Sunak repeatedly refused to commit to delivering the future phases of HS2 beyond Birmingham and cast doubts on whether it will .
A decision on the rail link was expected this week, but the backlash to suggestions portions of it could be scrapped has meant an announcement is now more likely in November.

While Mr Sunak did not deny that the later phases of the new rail link were under review, he declined on several occasions to say they would go ahead, opting instead to talk of the need to connect all northern towns and cities, fix potholes and improve roads.
When asked about the future of HS2, he has said the Government is always making sure “we get value for money”.
Speaking to BBC Radio Manchester, the Prime Minister said: “I’m not speculating on future things. We’ve got spades in the ground right now, we’re getting on…”

“I think what people also should know because I know there’s a lot of focus on this one thing but actually, one of the journeys that people use most in Greater Manchester or across the North, it’s in their cars right now…”
Asked by BBC Three Counties Radio what the point was of a HS2 service stopping at Old Oak Common railway station, which is “closer to Brentford than Trafalgar Square”.
The Prime Minister said: “Old Oak Common is on the new Elizabeth line and actually the connections to most London destinations are very strong.
“Obviously it’s a new station that people will not be familiar with but its connectivity to all those areas is very strong.”

title: Labour U-turns on plans to end private schools’ charitable status but will still impose 20% VAT charge
lead: U-turn comes after i revealed earlier this week that Labour will roll out VAT on private schools immediately and in full if it wins the general election
author: Poppy Wood

body.text: has U-turned on its pledge, but said it will still apply 20 per cent to school fees if the party wins , i can reveal.
Ending the tax breaks enjoyed by private schools is one of Labour’s flagship policies, and the party has stated for several years that it would do so partly by ripping up their charitable status.

The move was put forward by  in a House of Commons debate as recently as January this year. She said that Labour MPs “agree” that “charitable status for most private schools is something that should come to an end”.
However, senior party sources told i that Labour has now scrapped the policy and that the party will only look to apply VAT to private schools if it enters No 10.

On Wednesday, Labour formally confirmed the U-turn after questioning from i. In a statement, a spokesperson for the party said: “Our policy remains. We will remove the unfair tax breaks that private schools benefit from, to fund desperately needed teachers and mental health counselling in every secondary school.

“This doesn’t require removing charitable status, however, driving high and rising standards for every child against the backdrop of a broken economy requires political choices. Labour isn’t afraid to make them.”
The U-turn comes after i revealed earlier this week that Labour will  if it wins the general election, rather than “phasing it in” over several years.

Under current law, independent schools can be recognised as charities if they demonstrate that they make provision for those of “modest means” to attend – usually through scholarships and bursaries. Charitable status means private schools do not have to pay tax on their annual profits, and grants them other tax breaks including business rates relief on buildings.

New legislation would have to be passed for independent schools to lose their charitable status. Doing so would require a statutory change to the legal definition of “charity”, which would possibly pose wider implications for the charity sector.

However, the party could still impose VAT on private schools without stripping them of their charitable status, and this could be achieved much more quickly. The House of Commons enjoys “financial privilege” which allows MPs to decide public taxes and public spending.

i understands that Labour will make further changes to ensure private schools are forced to pay business rates on buildings even if they keep their charitable status if the party enters No 10. It is unclear whether they would still benefit other tax breaks such as Gift Aid and income tax relief.

Liz Brownsell, the head of charities at law firm Birketts, told i private schools would likely still benefit from “relief from corporation tax [and] capital gains tax”, but that the “impact of a change in VAT status would vary enormously depending on the specific circumstances of each school”.
“It’s difficult to assess the potential impact for independent schools if they were to retain their charitable status but become required to charge VAT on school fees,” she said.

“It’s also quite possible that a Labour government might seek to strip independent schools of other tax reliefs that are generally available to charities, even if they do not seek to remove charitable status itself.”

In July last year, Baroness Chapman of Darlington, Labour’s then-shadow education spokesperson, said “charitable status gives private schools around 80 per cent relief on their business rates and saves a school like Eton more than £500,000 a year”.
Sources within the sector told i there were questions over the legality of stripping schools of their charitable status that may have led Labour into changing its plans.
“One could take months, the other could take years,” one source said, adding that ending the charitable status of private schools could also be subject to legal challenge.
The Independent Schools Council also told i that it would “set a worrying precedent that any charity seen as not reflecting the political ideology of the day could be subject to additional taxes”.
Labour MPs have repeatedly said the party would axe the charitable status enjoyed by around half of all private schools, which would require a law change.

In an Opposition Day Debate on the fair taxation of schools earlier this year, Alex Cunningham, the Labour MP for Stockton North, said: “The Tories crashed the economy, so I support those on my front bench in their commitment to create funds by removing charitable status from private schools and from other pots where they can find that money.”
has also stated on several occasions that the party would strip private schools of their charitable status if he becomes prime minister.

In a speech setting out Labour’s vision for government in Gateshead last summer, he said: “When I say we are going to pay for kids to catch up at school, I also say it’ll be funded by removing private schools’ charitable status.”

And in an interview with the Sunday Mirror in 2021, he said: “Labour wants every parent to be able to send their child to a great state school. But improving them to benefit everyone costs money. That’s why we can’t justify continued charitable status for private schools.”
Private schools have argued  which help widen access.

One leading private school headteacher, speaking to i anonymously, said Labour’s plans to end tax breaks for independent schools would force them to make cost cuts elsewhere to avoid passing on higher fees to parents.

Julie Robinson, the chief executive of the Independent Schools Council, told i: “If Labour takes away the tax relief associated with charitable status for independent schools, the policy would create a two-tier system within the charity sector, setting a worrying precedent that any charity seen as not reflecting the political ideology of the day could be subject to additional taxes.
“We would love to work with Labour to build more effective ways to achieve our shared goal of improving education for all young people.”

title: Liberal Democrats oppose Labour’s VAT plan for private schools in fresh dividing line between parties
lead: The third party said it would not support the policy of imposing VAT on school fees which has been promised by Labour
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: The Liberal Democrats have opened a fresh dividing line with Labour by speaking out against the party’s policy of .
Sir Keir Starmer has suggested that the  will be one of his top priorities if he wins the next general election.
As i revealed this week, Labour intends to  – raising the prospect that it would take effect as soon as next academic year.
But the Lib Dems said they opposed the policy, although they would support a review of charitable status among schools due to fears that some do little to help their local area.

A spokesman said: “The Liberal Democrats do not support ending the VAT exemption. We do think some private schools benefit from lower taxes due to charitable status even though they perform almost no charitable act on behalf of the community – so charitable status does need to be reviewed so that it only rewards schools that do real community work.”
The intervention opens a rare division between the two main Opposition parties ahead of next year’s general election.

In the event of a hung Parliament, Sir Keir is likely to seek support from the Lib Dems to operate a minority government. The third party has not yet said which policy concessions it would demand in return.

Neither party has openly said that they would seek to do a deal as part of a so-called “progressive alliance”. But both have ruled out entering any sort of agreement with the Conservatives or the Scottish National Party, suggesting that there would be no other option to form a stable government if Labour falls short of a majority.
Lib Dem demands would almost certainly include some sort of electoral reform, and more funding for health which has been at the centre of the party’s recent campaigning.

It is not yet clear whether it would request a veto over certain Labour policies – or whether Sir Keir would consider dropping the private schools VAT plan given how much he has talked about it since becoming leader.
In an interview with i on Friday pointedly did not rule out a post-election pact with Labour.
The Liberal Democrats are currently seeking to win voters from the Conservatives in wealthy, liberal parts of the country such as suburban areas of South-East England.
Under the Coalition Government between 2010 and 2015, the party was a fervent supporter of educational reforms but did not push for a crackdown on the privileges available to private schools.

Labour’s reforms to the tax treatments of private schools are intended to fund a number of improvements to state education, including the recruitment of extra teachers and more mental health support for pupils.
They are one of the few tax increases that Sir Keir and Rachel Reeves, the shadow Chancellor, have approved as they push to appeal to middle-class voters.

title: Labour tax plan for VAT on private schools is popular but not a voter priority, polls say
lead: According to recent polling data, 49% of adults agreed private schools should lose tax exemptions, compared with 11% who disagree
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: ’s plan to  is popular across the political spectrum, but unlikely to sway voters, pollsters have said.
party intends to remove the 20 per cent tax exemption for private schools within the first year of being elected into government.
According to recent polling data from YouGov, 49 per cent of adults agreed private schools should lose tax exemptions, compared with 11 per cent who disagree.
This figure – published on 4 September – was higher among voters in the North of England, rising to 52 per cent.
Polling by Redfield & Wilton last year revealed 62 per cent of all voters support Labour’s plan – including 51 per cent of those who voted Conservative in 2019.
Research director at Redfield & Wilton, Philip van Scheltinga, said the policy has been popular since it was announced.
But he warned that this support would not be enough to win over voters in Labour target seats in so-called areas, where the priorities are “cost of living and the economy, followed by the NHS”.
The policy would not necessarily bring voters to Labour – or turn them away – he said, but instead could indicate more broadly that Labour is prepared to raise certain taxes.

“When Labour first announced the plans last November, Redfield & Wilton Strategies polling showed the policy was considerably popular. Even 51 per cent of 2019 Conservative voters supported the policy,” he told i.
“In a country in which the vast majority send their children to state schools, it is not hard to see why this policy has been well received.
“Ordinary families that Labour are trying to reach struggle to understand why private schools should have charitable status during a cost of living crisis.”
Polling expert and political professor Dr Will Jennings agreed the issue would not necessarily sway undecided voters.
But he said it could indicate how “bold” Labour is prepared to be if elected.
“I don’t think it’s likely to be a big issue for Labour. The number of voters affected is small and most are unlikely to be swing Labour voters,” he said.
“As ever the potential for it to matter is more to do with the wider message it sends about how radical Labour might be in power, and whether it conflicts with aspiration.
“But given the current economic context I am not sure that there is a lot of potential for it to resonate.”
Former Labour leader and prime minister Gordon Brown said he backed the plan to add VAT to private schools and said he had considered doing the same as PM.

Speaking on Times Radio, he said: “You’ve got to have a very good argument about why private schools should be exempt from the VAT. We don’t exempt most other things from value added tax, and it’s what we might have done when we were in government and certainly looked at it at the time.
“I think probably this is the right time to do this. It raises some money which allows us to invest in education for the rest of the community.
“And of course, it is regularising a situation where you’ve got a particular item of expenditure that is exempt from VAT without any proper justification for that happening.”

title: The middle class can’t afford a hike in private school taxes – state schools already risk being overrun
lead: There’s a good chance state schools up and down the country need to prepare for an influx – but not necessarily because of Labour’s policy
author: Ed Dorrell

body.text: Critics will tell you that if , thousands upon thousands of students will be forced out of independent schools and into the state sector. They say that, as a result, the £1.6bn that Keir Starmer’s people think such a policy will raise in tax receipts simply won’t happen.
Private schools themselves insist that their mums and dads  (promised almost overnight if Labour win) and that many will immediately pull the emergency cord and hoick their offspring off to.

There is a lot of debate about this, with projections varying wildly – and in truth we really don’t know what would happen. There are too many variables. They include how much of the 20 per cent the independent schools would actually pass onto parents and the willingness and ability of parents to pay it. We simply don’t have the foggiest.
Even if we did, though, I strongly suspect we’re actually looking in the wrong place.

I do think there’s a very significant chance that primaries and secondaries up and down the country need to prepare for an influx from the independent sector but it’s not for the reasons we might imagine. It is actually, as with much in our public life today, about the cost of living.

For many of those that pay for education, school fees come out of the same place as mortgage repayments: their post-tax income. And, in case you’ve been living in the moon, mortgage repayments for , in some cases doubling or more.

There will surely be private-school parents in their tens of thousands staring down the barrel of a remortgage in the next few months and thinking that they simply won’t be able afford the school fees anymore. Why pay when there’s a free one around the corner?

I run a lot of focus groups on all manner of subjects across lots and lots of social grades, and recently those that feature middle-class participants have got bleaker and bleaker. The middle classes in this country – including both those who send their kids to private schools, and those who aspire to – are feeling very nervous about their financial circumstances.

The threat of interest rates rising is making them worried about their futures. First the weekly shop moves from , then the two weeks in the south of France are binned. Next up? My bet is that independent schools will become the latest victim of Britain’s middle class austerity epidemic.

The independent sector is fond of pointing out their schools and their parents are much more normal than the stereotypes suggest – and who make sacrifices to pay the school bill. These are the very people for whom an interest-rate increase will leave floundering.

And it’s also worth noting that state schools are, on average, better than they’ve ever been. Both Ofsted data and exam results show – concrete roofs and funding cuts notwithstanding – a system that is competing with most “normal” independents. For many, the marginal benefits of private schooling has been shrinking for some time, a fact that will come into sharp focus as disposable income goes up in smoke.

Of course, if VAT is slapped on school fees by an incoming Starmer administation, there is a significant risk that some private school parents will make the decision to switch sectors, but my bet is that even before a Labour election victory makes that possibility a reality, the threat of repossession will have forced may fee-paying homeowners to squeeze their educational belts already.
In middle-class England the financial pips are squeaking, even before Labour’s tax man comes calling.
Ed Dorrell is a director at Public First and a former deputy editor of the Times Educational Supplement

title: Private schools have abandoned Britain’s aspirational middle class – a VAT hike makes perfect sense
lead: The private sector has broken its side of the social contract with wider society
author: Luke Tryl

body.text: A commitment  is the right one.

It’s a strong electoral strategy. Polling by More in Common in the last few weeks found that the voters who have swung from the Tories to Labour since 2019 are twice as likely than average to say that ending tax breaks for private schools will make them more likely to vote for the Labour Party.

Keir Starmer needs to keep these voters if he has any chance of a solid Labour majority and this policy is one way of ensuring he does so. The sensible thing for the Tories to do if they want these voters back might well be to mimic Labour’s pledge.

The public are not anti-aspiration. Very few of the people that we speak to would ever want to see private schools shut down all together. But there is a sense that during a time when money for public services is being squeezed, schools, hospitals and court rooms are in a , and the cost of living crisis has reduced many families to “working to live, and living to work”, that tax breaks for the top 10 per cent who are wealthy enough to send their children to private school should be at.

And the truth is relentless fee hikes have themselves killed the  – for many families gone are the days when sending your children to these schools was something you could scrimp, sacrifice and save to do.

Instead, with private school fees rising by over 60 per cent since 2000, and now as much as £50,000 per child per year, we’re moving from a Britain where the Prime Minister’s parents could afford to send him to private school on a GP and pharmacist’s salary, to a Britain where only the ultra-wealthy will now be able to afford to do the same.

In hiking fees and filling their classrooms and corridors with ever more international students with boundless willingness to pay, the private sector has broken its side of the social contract with wider society.

Scattering a few bursaries around so that the grand total of  isn’t enough to repair that contract. And while the work of schools like Eton in establishing new sixth forms to support social mobility and the levelling-up agenda, these examples of truly charitable endeavour are too few and far between.
At the end of the day, politics, particularly in a tight fiscal environment, is about priorities.

There is no doubt that education is one of the success stories of this Government. The work of reforming ministers like Nick Gibb have transformed England from a laggard in the international league tables to a reading powerhouse.

New free schools such as  are achieving GCSE results that would have been unimaginable at the turn of the century in an inner London state school, while a relentless focus on standards and behaviour means that around nine in 10 schools are now rated good or outstanding.
But all that said, real problems are emerging, problems that can only be solved by more money.

The first is the parlous state of the school estate – the RAAC school closures  – but in truth it is only part of the problem. Having seen the list of schools in need of repair during my time as a Department for Education special adviser, it is clear we need much more investment in school rebuilding and capital.

Second, we are simply not recruiting enough teachers. Money isn’t everything when it comes to teacher recruitment but it is a part of the picture – particularly in the real shortage areas such as maths and physics where without higher salaries, teaching will simply not be able to compete with other graduate opportunities.

Third, if we are serious about tackling the inequity between private and state schools, we need to support state schools to invest in extracurricular activities that set children up to succeed in later life. But that needs funding too.

There are of course many more areas and the money from removing private school tax breaks alone won’t even address the three I’ve listed, but it is a start and each of them seem to me a far better way of spending money than subsidising the preferences, however legitimate, of the very wealthy.

Simply put then – removing private school tax breaks is one of those rare proposals that is the right policy, the right politics and the right priority and the next Government should do it from day one. Luke Tryl is the UK director of

title: Rishi Sunak teasing an inheritance tax cut reveals a desperate government in its final days
lead: Instead of subsidising childcare, say, or free school lunches, the Tories indulge the greediest and wealthiest
author: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown

body.text: Rishi Sunak may be poised to pull another dead rabbit out of his tatty hat. Last week, he appeared at a Downing Street podium, full of vim. It was an illusion. A man of small vision was trying to appear awesome as he announced the  and promised a bonfire of non-existent green policies. There was no planned tax on meat or flying, no diktat to separate garbage into seven bins. Fakery was – knowingly – given a ring of truth to get Britons in a lather and hand their trust to the Tories.

After using  to win the by-election in Uxbridge by a small margin, Sunak and his gang misguidedly think tactical, emotional stimulation will enable them to retain power. The anti-Green ploy backfired. Al Gore, the ex US Vice President, now an environmentalist, told Sky News: “I think the people of the United Kingdom largely agree that it is the wrong decision.” Yes, Sir, they do. Sunak’s popularity has now  to its lowest point.

So what does he do next? Political experts expect him to get rid of . He knows that people harbour irrational fears about their houses and savings being grabbed by the state when they die. Vera, my late mother-in-law, lived in terror of that. Nothing we said would shift this panic.

Inheritance tax affects barely 4 per cent of the population. Yet right-wing organisations, individuals and commentators have droned on and on about it for years. by More in Common confirms that people think inheritance tax is the second most unreasonably high tax after council tax. So maybe this will boost Sunak’s chances.

On , Jane Dodge speculated that “such a move would only benefit the children of couples who are able to pass on more than a million pounds. But it is being seen as a sweetener aimed at wealthier voters in Tory-held seats who may be thinking of switching to the Lib Dems.” Such arrogance.

In today’s calamitously unequal Britain, Sunak’s bunny will, many believe, only send odours of revulsion. This amounts to a tax cut of around £7bn, according to Labour analysis. It proves the allegiance of the British PM to those in the very top sliver of the wealth and assets pyramid. If the tax was revoked, his daughters could save millions of pounds, based on figures of the family’s estimated wealth. Meanwhile, tax burden on most Britons is higher than it has ever been.
The richest among us do not pay the taxes they should. King Charles  after the Queen died; Hugh Grosvener, the young Duke of Westminster, is believed to have  because his estate is held in a trust.

Expect soon, Labour campaigns slating Sunak for not caring about the people. They could point to the evidence all around us. Official figures . A record number of our citizens are dependent on food banks. Teachers are feeding and clothing kids in their schools.

It should be obvious to any sentient Briton that inheritance tax abolition would confirm beyond doubt that these Tories really don’t give a damn about the neediest, or, indeed the middle classes, now also struggling. Instead of subsidising childcare, say, or free school lunches, they indulge the greediest and wealthiest. OK, these are, you might think, the biased views of an ardent social democrat. So why I don’t I consider the counter-arguments?

In 2020, Paul Johnson, the rightly respected director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, : “Sweden and Norway, often considered beacons of social democracy and equality, have abolished their inheritance taxes entirely… Looked at from the perspective of the recipient generation, inheritances appear random, unjust, an obvious basis for taxation. Looked at from the perspective of the bequeathing generation, though, bequests appear simply as an exercise in property rights. I have earned, and paid my taxes, and saved; it is my right to dispose of my assets as I see fit, and in particular to support my children. Few human emotions run deeper.” He advocates a graduated (lower) tax on gifts worth between £30,000 and £2m.

Economist Catherine McBride, member of the Tax Reform Council’s Advisory Board, that getting rid of inheritance tax “would even make the UK a more attractive place for the world’s wealthy to base themselves, bringing custom to UK businesses, shops and services. Sweden abolished [such taxes] in 2004 and many wealthy Swedish families who had moved out of Sweden due to its high taxes have now returned.” They come, spend and live the high life. How does that help make this country fair again? And also, citizens of Sweden uncomplainingly pay income taxes of up to 52 per cent. Would you be prepared to pay that here? I’m not convinced by either of them.

Labour peer Joan Bakewell’s tweet makes far more sense: “Inheritance tax is good for society: it reduces inequality and promotes the idea that money goes to those who have earned it.” Resist Sunak’s cynical moves. Tax the successors of the very rich.

title: Attacks on Labour’s private school plans show how little the Tories care for state schools
lead: It’s crucial if we’re to spread opportunity across our country
author: Bridget Phillipson

body.text: Politics is about choices, often tough ones. It’s something the Prime Minister continues to tell us on a weekly basis. The choices we make define us as politicians, and define governments.

Rishi Sunak knows this only too well: his decision to  across the country being taught in portacabins, or under steel girders to stop the roof falling on their heads. It will be felt for years to come.
It’s not just the  that show schools are in a sorry state. Teachers  in droves and too few are being recruited to replace them.

More and more pupils are now persistently absent from school, stuck on mental health waiting lists and missing crucial learning. Attainment gaps are growing among the youngest children, gaps that only grow as they progress through school. The bond of trust between schools and families has broken down.
The reason these problems go unaddressed is simple: education is simply not a priority for Inaction Man Rishi Sunak and the Conservatives.

It’s not their children being taught under steel props, not their children in draughty portacabins, not their children who are struggling under the weight of a  or having their life chances curtailed because there aren’t enough teachers in their classrooms.

Labour would make different choices. We have a plan to drive up standards in all our state schools for all our children, with 6,500 new teachers, access to mental health professionals in every school, dedicated careers advice and early speech and language interventions.
And we will pay for that by ending .

I won’t have any truck with Conservative claims that to do so . To say is that is an insult to the aspirations of millions of families up and down this country whose children go to state schools. Do the Tories think they do not also dream of better for their children?

I am impatient to get on with our mission of breaking down barriers to opportunity for young people. That’s why we don’t need to get bogged down in the complexities of changing : we just need to end the nonsense that sees private schools exempted from tax that other businesses pay.

Our plans have been shown time and again to be popular and have the backing of families up and down the country who want to see their children receive a brilliant state education. It’s crucial if we’re to spread opportunity across our country and make sure that background is no barrier to getting on.
Be in no doubt: Labour will deliver our plans by ending these tax breaks, but so could the Conservatives, at a stroke.

That’s why I’ve written to the Education Secretary setting out our plans and challenged her to back them. If they do, they will have Labour’s full support. It’s time to show that the Conservatives care about other people’s children, not just their own.
Bridget Phillipson is the shadow Secretary of State for Education

title: VAT rise for private school fees ‘is not an attack’ and does not have to hit parents, says Starmer
lead: The Labour leader insisted that schools do not ‘have to pass’ the new higher costs on via pupil fees
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer has insisted that plans to add 20 per cent VAT to private school fees is “not an attack” and suggested parents will not necessarily see increased costs.
The party estimates that  to spend on lifting educational standards across the state sector.
Speaking on the BBC’s Political Thinking podcast, Sir Keir told Nick Robinson that the country had to “do something about the appalling state of our schools”.
He added: “It is not an attack on private schools. It’s just saying an exemption you have had is going to go.
“The school doesn’t have to pass this on to the parents in fees. And each of the schools is going to have to ask themselves whether that’s what they want to do.

“I’m very comfortable with private schools but I want our state schools to be just as good, so it doesn’t matter whether you send your child to private school or to state school because you’ll get equal chances in life.”
A Labour spokesperson said the party would use the money raised from the changes “to fund desperately needed teachers and mental-health counselling in every secondary school”.
i revealed earlier this week that Labour will  if it wins the general election, rather than “phasing it in” over several years. The party estimates the policy could raise £1.7bn a year.
The party had previously indicated it would scrap the charitable status of private schools, but .
Ending the tax breaks enjoyed by private schools is one of Labour’s flagship policies, and the party has stated for several years that it would do so partly by ripping up their charitable status.
However, senior party sources told i that Labour has now scrapped this policy and that the party will only look to apply VAT to private schools if it enters No 10.

In a statement, a spokesperson for the party said: “Our policy remains. We will remove the unfair tax breaks that private schools benefit from, to fund desperately needed teachers and mental-health counselling in every secondary school.

“This doesn’t require removing charitable status. However, driving high and rising standards for every child against the backdrop of a broken economy requires political choices. Labour isn’t afraid to make them.”

The move has proved popular among voters, and according to recent polling data from YouGov, 49 per cent of adults agreed private schools should lose tax exemptions, compared with 11 per cent who disagree.
This figure – published on 4 September – was higher among voters in the North of England, rising to 52 per cent.
Polling by Redfield & Wilton last year found 62 per cent of all voters supported Labour’s plan – including 51 per cent of those who voted Conservative in 2019.
However, Julie Robinson, chief executive of the Independent Schools Council, remained critical of the policy.

She said: “If Labour takes away the tax relief associated with charitable status for independent schools, the policy would create a two-tier system within the charity sector, setting a worrying precedent that any charity seen as not reflecting the political ideology of the day could be subject to additional taxes.
“We would love to work with Labour to build more effective ways to achieve our shared goal of improving education for all young people.”

title: Labour are underestimating the Lib Dems at their peril – they could have 50 seats after the next election
lead: The starting gun on the election race is fired now
author: Mark Wallace

body.text: are an aspect of politics that are particularly hard to explain to political non-combatants. As a battle-scarred (and only slightly traumatised) veteran of almost 30 such events, I find these early Autumn bun-fights endlessly fascinating.

Not everyone doe – even some professional Westminster-watchers. If you must go to all of them (plus the TUC’s conference, then maybe a UKIP during the years of Peak Farage), it can make September and October a gruelling season, characterised variously by drab hotel rooms and a never-ending parade of different colds and sniffles threatening to overcome an immune system eroded by warm wine and a lack of sleep.

But for me they’re a guilty pleasure – whether they’re going well or badly, whether they’re being run by a party I like or not, the combination of high drama, mild absurdity, sleep deprivation and the discussion of political ideas is somehow irresistible.

Let’s be honest, it would be an overstatement to say that all human life is here. Indeed, one might debate the humanity of some life here. But all political life is here, from activists to ministers, has-beens, wannabes and never-wills, crammed into three and a bit days of a gossipy, tribal whirligig. It’s addictive and amusing in equal measure.
For all their chaos and intermittent absurdity, the  still have plenty to tell us about their hosts and the state of political play. This year’s season is no different.

The  are gathered in Bournemouth, where their leader Sir Ed Davey was gamely and inexplicably tipped out of a kayak and into the sea for the benefit of the cameras and the (possibly perplexed) voting public.

The party is understandably excited: following some very strong by-election results, they have good reason to hope for an enjoyable General Election night. Interestingly, while Davey’s party has historically suffered from a national vote share spread too evenly, costing them seats, they believe that their Blue Wall strategy of focusing on disillusioned, older, pro-EU former Tories in specific constituencies will pay dividends.

It’s far from impossible that the Lib Dems will thereby end up with 50 or more seats at the next election, if they play their cards right and their campaign lands as they hope. That would restore them to a position of serious clout – either in the case of a large Labour majority, as the polls currently imply, in which case they could play havoc by nipping at Sir Keir Starmer from all sorts of directions, or in the less likely circumstance of a hung parliament.

Their conference, however, suggests that this prospect is still underappreciated. Considering the possibility that there could be scores of Lib Dem MPs in a year’s time, or sooner, there was surprisingly limited media attention or corporate engagement with the event – a missed opportunity for both the press, the electorate and indeed any lobbyists looking to get to know the future occupants of the green benches, in my view.

The Conservatives, by contrast, have a somewhat different outlook, albeit due to the very same polls. Goodness knows what row will blow up in Manchester next week, although the febrile atmosphere suggests at least one will indeed arise.

For the Government, the run-up to their conference provides advance warning of a different sort of political battle. For the second year running, rail unions have organised strikes aimed at disrupting the conference and its attendees.

That’s an extraordinary thing in itself: trade unions who are so keen on battering a government that they dislike, and undermining its electoral prospects, that they will shut down a national service, disrupting the whole country, in order to do political damage to their opponents.

It may also be a foretaste of further such explicitly political strikes. Which other public services will be withdrawn for political ends? I wouldn’t hold out much hope, for example, of patients being spared further doctors’ strikes if the BMA follows the rail unions’ thinking that getting the Tories out of power is worth inconveniencing the public.

Labour’s conference has already produced one of the most interesting developments for us long-suffering veterans. After many years of resentment that the Conservatives get to go last, and thereby get the final word on the whole conference season, the Opposition have torn up the traditional calendar and have leap-frogged the Government, stepping out of sequence to gather in Liverpool in mid-October.

Officially, it was forced on them by venues’ logistical demands, but this looks to me to be a very clever move indeed. If it is chance, then it’s an extremely happy accident for Sir Keir Starmer, who – like a gymnast at the Olympics, or a singer on a talent show – will reap the benefit of being fresh in voters’ minds as the conferences come to a close.
Any debater will tell you that speaking last has an additional reward – you can essentially say whatever you like about the other side, and they have very little opportunity to answer back.

Starmer’s Party Conference schedule gives him the opportunity to set the tone for the last few weeks of the year, shortly before the likely election. That’s a canny choice, and suggests that Labour are already operating in campaign mode – the starting gun on the election race is fired now.

title: Forget HS2, our local bus services are now so appalling people walk for hours just to work
lead: The old and the young alike are left stranded, robbed of their freedom to shop, work and socialise
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: During an Urgent Question in the House of Commons on the , buses minister Richard Holden had to stand in for rail minister Huw Merriman, who was away in the Czech Republic.

Becoming the human equivalent of a rail replacement bus service, Holden did his best to bat away a barrage of questions about speculation that the Government was planning to axe the  – and save £34bn in the process.
Yet whatever your , there’s no question that Holden’s day job – in charge of our nation’s buses – gets much less attention, and cash, than the more high-profile topic of rail travel.

Even though the bus is Britain’s most used form of public transport, it has suffered years of cuts in funding and routes. Forget high speed rail, it’s the no-speed bus that worries both the young and the old in areas outside London.

The sense of a quiet crisis is borne out by the statistics. Official data from the  shows the number of bus routes has been halved since the Tories took power, falling from 17,394 in 2010 to 8,781 in 2022/3. Some 2,160 .

The West Midlands has been the hardest hit region, with the number of registered routes falling by more than two thirds. But the North West has seen a 52 per cent drop, 50 per cent in the North East, 45 per cent in the East, 43 per cent in the West and 29 per cent in the South East. Only London has survived the cull.

Of course, Covid triggered a big hit to  and even in the capital passenger numbers are still only at 85 per cent of their pre-pandemic passenger level, with some workers permanently changing their habits by working at home.

But the rot goes back much further. More than five years ago, when Jeremy Corbyn used Prime Minister’s Questions to highlight the dire state of Britain’s bus services since Margaret Thatcher’s time, he was mocked and jeered by Tory MPs, several of whom yelled: “Taxi!”

That particular heckle may stick in the craw of the many pensioners and others who now have to rely on expensive taxis when yet another bus fails to turn up on time. Our elderly rely hugely on their local bus, but their “freedom pass” has been replaced by a freedom penalty caused .
For many in Labour and even a growing number of Conservatives, it was Thatcher’s 1986 privatisation and deregulation of bus services that really sparked the demise.

At the time, Thatcher is reputed to have declared: “A man who, beyond the age of 25, finds himself on a bus can count himself a failure.” Yet instead of proving the benefits of competition, her own policy proved a failure, with fragmentation, fewer routes and higher fares.

In Greater Manchester this weekend, that legacy finally comes to an end when Metro Mayor Andy Burnham starts to take back full local control of buses. The  will see simplified, integrated fares with bus routes, frequencies and prices set locally for the first time in almost 40 years.

When the Tory party descends on Manchester next month, it will see for itself Burnham’s new bright-yellow, electric-powered bus fleet (there will be a bit of nostalgia for me too, remembering the pre-Thatcher era of publicly-owned GM Buses’ orange livery when I was a kid).
The franchising model is not without risks as any losses will fall not on private firms but the local authorities, although , creating a virtuous circle of more fare income and better services.

Other areas like Liverpool City region, West Yorkshire and South Yorkshire are all hoping to follow suit, but other areas without metro mayors are legally forbidden from doing so. A  by the Local Government Association and Urban Transport Group says that giving similar bus franchise powers to all areas would end the “spiral of decline” of services across England.

Boris Johnson, who was the first Tory PM since Thatcher to really enthuse about buses, realised that voters in the “Red Wall” of the North and midlands – as well as many in rural areas – really did want better services.
In his “” plan, he promised billions of new money, rightly declaring that buses “liberate the old, the young, the disabled…the double-decker bus is a symbol of Britain”.

Unfortunately, Johnson’s promised £3bn turned out to be £1bn and many areas lost out in a bidding process for a central pot of cash. While Labour plans to give all areas London-style franchising powers, its own strictures on spending mean extra funding is not at all guaranteed.
A big problem is also staff shortages, often the reason cited whenever buses don’t turn up and leave people stranded. No matter who owns or runs the service, that’s a problem.

Higher wages cost money, better apprenticeships need time and importing foreign drivers (the Confederation of Passenger Transport  for bus and coach drivers to be added to the Shortage Occupation List) requires political nerve, but all are among the solutions.
It’s a sign of how many Tory MPs get this agenda now that the Government injected £500m to  and then at £2.50 until 30 November 2024.

But it remains the loss of bus routes that causes most hardship. In Stoke-on-Trent, the city’s bus service has been cut in half, , students late for studies and pre-dawn starts for those on low wages who need more than one bus. It may not be a coincidence that the Tories lost control of the council this May.
Still, it’s also worth saying that while electric buses can help us reach net zero and cut pollution, Labour would be taking a risk if it ignored the sheer number of people who prefer to use a car.

Business Secretary Kemi Badenoch this week  who said “the poorest in society don’t drive in this country”. Badenoch retorted: “If you step outside London, you will find the poorest in society drive because they live in a rural area”.
