And she’s right, and not just in rural areas. Although the poorest are less likely than the richest to own a car, around two thirds of those on low incomes are motorists. It’s the sheer cost of buying and running a car that is likely to be the deterrent, not any lack of desire.

For many working people cars mean personal freedom (and for women in particular, security). Some young people opt out on environmental grounds or because it’s cheaper to use their parents’ car, but predictions that Millennials or Gen Z youngsters will reject motoring .

The key ought to be giving people a choice. In many rural and urban areas alike, the absence of reliable, affordable bus services means there really is no choice at all. When the debate over HS2’s billions reignites in coming weeks, that’s worth remembering.

title: Rishi Sunak’s ‘we’ve had enough of experts’ stance on net zero feels like Brexit all over again
lead: The PM tried to pin the blame on the Climate Change Committee – it doesn’t bode well for the environment or for British jobs
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: During Rishi Sunak’s combative interview with Nick Robinson on Radio 4’s Today programme, perhaps the most uncomfortable moment came on the issue of “”.

In his big “reset” speech on Wednesday, Sunak declared he had “scrapped” such a tax. When Robinson pointed out no such levy existed and the (CCC) denied his claims it had ever proposed one, the PM ended up skewered like a shish kebab.

But what was striking was just how hard Sunak tried to pin the blame on the committee, a group of environmental experts with a statutory duty to set five-yearly carbon budgets and make recommendations to ministers.

Sunak claimed, rightly, that they had talked about “an accelerated shift away from dairy and meat”. He added: “It also says we have to implement measures to bring that about.” I looked upand in fact it recommended Government should implement “low cost, low regret actions” to incentivise less meat eating. That’s far from a tax.

The PM was similarly economical with the actualité when he tried to spin a line that he had “scrapped” plans for “compulsory” car-sharing. He said the CCC’s call for “demand-side measures” was a euphemism for compulsion or taxes. But, again, the actual report says no such thing.

Sunak was on stronger ground when he said that there should be much more scrutiny of what the CCC proposes as the best routes to get to net zero by 2050. From cutting meat eating (a 20 per cent drop by 2030) to how we drive and heat our homes, the public may be surprised by .

He’s also right to prioritise making the transition to a greener economy more affordable for all, and, like many Tory voters, to start a debate about whether bans, taxes, incentives or regulation are the best way to change behaviour. The CCC would welcome more debate too.

Yet the whole point of the committee is to give expert advice on how to cut emissions and set out the possible policy options. As with Covid, ultimately it’s up to ministers to decide, marrying the policy (what’s possible) with the politics (what’s fairest, for example).

The danger is that the PM ends up sounding like someone who simply doesn’t like the independent criticism of his Government’s progress. Among the most wounding remarks has been CCC chairman Chris Stark warning that ministers are already off track on net zero and the latest announcement was “magical thinking” about how to make legal requirements a reality.

Given his insistence on detailed figures, it was notable that Sunak had no answer to the question of what other emissions cuts he would make to replace those lost from . Instead, he said he had “confidence and belief” that Climate Secretary  would get there.

Sunak’s irritation with the CCC feels very much like Liz Truss’s irritation with the Office for Budget Responsibility, another statutory watchdog whose job is to advise, when it warned last year her unfunded tax cuts could cost billions.

And there’s another parallel that sits ominously in the background too: Brexit. The PM’s attacks on and misrepresentations of the Climate Change Committee have real echoes of the “” rhetoric of the 2016 EU referendum campaign.

Sunak appears to be gunning for the committee. He knows he can’t say meat taxes or compulsory car-sharing are Labour policy, but he’s happy to (falsely) suggest they’re the brainchild of out-of-touch elitists – and weaponise the whole thing in

Those who know the PM well say this week is about underlining his main belief that politics should be about balancing and publicising the “trade-offs” of big policy issues. On lockdown, for example, he constantly argued as chancellor that the economic impacts were underplayed.
He also previewed his big speech by saying “for too many years politicians in governments of all stripes have not been honest about costs and trade offs” of getting to net zero by 2050.
Yet on Brexit itself, Sunak (like Boris Johnson and many others) has failed to show a similar honesty and transparency about both the downsides and upsides of quitting the EU.

For someone who was a Brexiteer before Johnson, it’s remarkable how little Sunak has talked about Brexit. He mentioned it  just once in his 2022 Budget speech, with a small VAT cut on solar panels. In his Budget and Spending Review in October 2021, the B-word wasn’t uttered at all.

In his March 2021 Budget, he did at least have something, as he unveiled eight new freeports. Unfortunately, the OBR was pretty withering on their impact: “We have assumed that the main effect of the freeports will be to alter the location rather than the volume of economic activity.”
This year, when asked to list the benefits of Brexit, the best he could think of was cutting VAT on sanitary products and tweaks to alcohol duty.
What Sunak never highlights is that the OBR has consistently projected that Brexit is causing a four per cent hit to UK growth, double that of the Covid pandemic.

When pressed by MPs last year on the OBR finding that leaving the European Union had caused UK trade to plunge by 15 per cent since 2019, much lower than other economies, he came close to candour. He said different EU relations “will obviously have an impact and that I’m sure is a big part of the reason why this is happening”.

Yet the PM sidestepped the question when asked if he had expected such a big drop in trade when he voted for Brexit in 2016. It is claimed that he has privately told some colleagues he backed Brexit because “I looked at the numbers” – but no one knows what those numbers those are.

Of course, there’s a perfectly respectable case for saying that getting out of the EU was more a matter of sovereignty than prosperity. Sunak has also been pragmatic about fixing the  and stopping Jacob Rees-Mogg’s .

But for a man who prides himself on trade-offs and figures, he has failed to admit the extra red tape and costs for business, let alone detail how to counter them. “Spreadsheet Sunak” has remarkably empty spreadsheets for metrics of Brexit success.
If Brexit is the biggest political change to Britain of our generation, climate change is the even bigger policy challenge.

Expert warnings about the economics of leaving the EU have turned from Project Fear to Project Fact. In his attacks on the net-zero “establishment”, Sunak may be repeating that mistake, but with even higher stakes for British jobs, influence and our environment.
In the 70s, TV impressionist used to end his shows with the line “and now, this is me”, before crooning a final song in his own voice and character. Many viewers found the finale a turn-off.

Now Sunak has declared who he really is – a small-state, low regulation Brexiteer – it will be interesting to see whether the voters have a similar reaction. For all his talk of tough trade-offs, the toughest test will be a .

title: After U-turning on petrol and diesel car ban, Rishi Sunak is trying to clean up a mess of his own making
lead: There’s the strong whiff of desperation amid his dire personal polling
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: The last time a Prime Minister held an emergency Downing Street press conference,  was drowning in a market meltdown after sacking her Chancellor. Her robotic performance turned out to be a mere prelude to her inevitable resignation.
And there was a strong lame-duck vibe as Rishi Sunak staged a hastily-arranged media briefing. Far from being in assured control of events, here was yet another PM .

As Sunak confirmed the worst-kept secret in Whitehall – the delaying of the once “immovable” 2030 deadline for banning the sale of new petrol and diesel cars, and the 2035 phase-out for gas boilers – there was also an echo of the days of the Covid press conferences.

Yet this turned out to be the PM announcing he had given in to the virus of net zero scepticism that infects his Tory backbenches. As he gripped a podium sporting a slogan “Long Term Decisions For A Brighter Future”, pro-green MPs would have read it instead as “Short Term Decisions For A Blighted Future”.

There is an argument that the free market is the best mechanism to lead the switch to cheaper energy. Sunak made plain that consumers are voting with their feet, with many buying electric cars and vans already. Unfortunately, he didn’t admit that it is Government regulation that has driven that switch – with the car industry and charging industry expecting a 2030 target.
There is a legitimate concern that net zero policies can only win public support if they make going green affordable for all.

But one problem for Sunak’s central claim – that he still wants to deliver on the– is that it now feels very much like the environmental version of St Augustine’s prayer: Lord, let me be chaste, but not yet.
And ditching the targets causes three separate but related difficulties for post-Brexit Britain: higher costs, a damaged reputation and losing the first-mover advantage in a free market.

First, putting deadlines back actually increases costs for ordinary consumers. The second-hand market for electric cars depends on rapid rollout of their production, and similarly boiler replacements get cheaper when demand is focused on a date. Delaying home insulation keeps bills high too.
There’s also the cost to the taxpayer of shelling out up to £700m on subsidies to Tata’s battery factory and BMW’s Mini factory, both of which are predicated on targets previously announced.

Second, it will reverse the global leadership that the UK has shown to date (the first country to make the 2050 target a legal requirement). Tony Blair’s unusually daft argument that the UK “only” contributes one per cent of emissions ignores that one per cent is a large number, and that we are in the top 17 emitters in the world and the eighth-largest historic emitter.

And all those one per cents add up too, particularly in trying to get global agreement. As Alok Sharma, the former COP26 president and Tory MP, pointed out today: “If we have countries around the world resiling from their commitments, the Earth is going to be on life support.”

Third, there’s the sheer stupidity of giving up a market-beating advantage. Yes other countries are doing 2035 rather than 2030, but a confident Government used to see that as a reason to steal a march on our rivals in the EU. Instead, we now have a “little Englander” approach that suggests the UK is a small player on the global stage in every sense.

The strangest thing about this whole affair is the way it undermines Sunak’s own unique selling point as a future-facing Mr Stability, the man who steadied the ship after Liz Truss, who offers business the calm certainty it needs.
U-turns also undermine the  as a flip-flopping, untrustworthy politician. No 10’s own reputation for fair dealing is on the line after several assurances that the 2030 target remains.
Worst of all for the Prime Minister is the perception of an inexperienced, weak politician who dithers, delays and doesn’t follow his gut instinct.

He’s undeniably been sceptical about Johnson’s net-zero agenda, yet has spent years echoing it – and the whole of this year pondering what to do. Indeed, one of the most curious aspects of Sunak’s address was that he was critiquing his own year in office. Why did it take him this long to wake up that his own Government was not being “proportionate”?

The irony is that all this certainly feels like ‘the real Rishi’ – a right-wing Brexiteer with reactionary reflexes, not the moderate many assume him to be. Yet he didn’t say a peep about his net zero scepticism in the Tory leadership race last year, or as Chancellor. He preferred instead to pay lip service to Boris Johnson’s agenda and targets.

By contrast, at least Kemi Badenoch, Suella Braverman and Liz Truss have been clear on their sceptical agenda. The risk is that Sunak now looks like he’s dancing to their tune, rather than being his own man.

There’s the strong whiff of desperation about this too. After the Ulez by-election in Uxbridge and South Ruislip, the PM looks like a man clinging onto a net-zero-sceptic life raft that itself is leaking air. That’s why this ‘reset’ sounds like panic, not pragmatism.

The risk to the Blue Wall is very live too. One former minister with a seat in the South told me recently: “Every time Lee Anderson says he would ‘send them back’, every time Suella opens her mouth, every time Truss pops up on TV, my voters recoil in horror. They’re liberal conservatives who don’t like what our party has become.”

That’s the obvious political risk in all this. Voters in the Red Wall may already be lost thanks to the here-and-now cost of living crisis caused by mortgage misery and rent rises, while those in affluent areas are repelled by the image of a PM pandering to the reactionary forces in his party.

When the Netflix film Don’t Look Up was aired, many felt it was too heavy-handed a satire about how cynical, science-free politicians and media would ignore the impending doom staring them in the face. As the planet burns, it’s now looking like an instruction manual for No 10.

What should worry Sunak is that far from looking like strength, this net-zero scepticism looks like weakness, as future leadership contenders like Braverman and Badenoch try to outflank him. Truss offering her support after the press conference felt like the kiss of political death.

Braverman today said net-zero goals are “just that, goals not straitjackets”. But as his party again appears to have one eye on life after his premiership in Opposition, the real straitjacket is the political one he’s allowed his net-zero sceptics to impose on him. Looking like a prisoner of his party, not its leader, may tempt the voters to throw away the key at the next election.

title: Brexit Britain has a new European future and Keir Starmer knows it
lead: A radical vision of Europe is being developed and there is a place for UK within it – if someone grasps the opportunity
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: If you squint, and turn your head just right, you can see the future of Europe.
It’s a Europe that is more powerful by virtue of offering nation states greater options in their relationship with it. And it’s one in which Britain could have a place.

The outline for this idea emerged in a joint German-French paper this week, but in truth it’s been around for a long time. It is the idea of a multi-speed Europe – one in which a hard core of countries press ahead with ever closer union while others are able to hang back, enjoying the economic benefits without the political requirements.

It makes sense. Indeed, it already exists, albeit in a haphazard unplanned way. Norway, Switzerland, Iceland and Liechtenstein are either in or docked with the single market despite not being EU members. The creation of the Eurozone created a new de-facto two-tier status between those countries sharing a currency and those which would not. And Britain has left altogether, but last year it joined the European political community – a forum to discuss political and strategic matters.

For decades, Europeans have dreamed of formalising these types of distinctions into a multi-speed Europe, or a Europe of concentric circles. Countries could pick the level of engagement they wanted, from being at the heart of things to maintaining a more distant economic relationship.

now plans to see that through. He’s worried that recalcitrant members like Hungary will interfere with plans for deeper integration and streamlined decision-making, particularly on defence and foreign policy. That’s especially important now that Ukraine readies itself for membership.

This week’s joint paper proposed that core countries form an  if another country tries to block treaty change. There would then be a second tier composed of the remaining existing EU who would get an opt out from the new treaty, but not from the previous ones.

After that there would be an “associate outer tier” of non-EU single market countries like Norway, who want frictionless trade but not future integration. And finally there would be the existing European political community.

It’s a good system. To be really radical it would offer limited voting rights to associate countries, as Commission president Jacques Delors proposed in 1989, but that’s an argument for another day. The fundamentals are these: it is time for Europe to step up and take up the role of a world political power, not just an economic one. This kind of framework is the only way that becomes feasible.

Britain is currently in the European political community, but the joint paper clearly envisages that it might like to take a step inside and take up associate outer tier status. Indeed, it has been written with that idea very clearly in the authors’ minds.

The paper emerged yesterday at the worst possible moment for Keir Starmer, who’d been in France chatting with Macron. And of course the Labour team instantly shot it down. The idea was a “non-starter”, a senior Labour source .
They have to do that. There is no way on God’s earth that Labour are going to allow a conversation which involves the words “EU” and “membership”, even if it’s technically in a new framework.
But we are not talking about the Europe of today. We’re talking about the Europe of tomorrow.

Starmer unveiled some of his plans for European policy this week: alignment of agricultural products to reduce friction at the border and probably some kind of reciprocal youth visa scheme which would basically amount to free movement for the young. It’s quite a good package – basically the closest you’re likely to get to Europe without joining the single market.

But he is not going to propose joining the EU, the single market or the customs union. And there is a good reason for that. . It could help stitch back together the winning Tory electoral alliance of 2019. It returns us to the identity-war conversation of the post-2016 era, which Labour cannot win, rather than the cost-of-living and competent government conversation of the post 2021 era, which Labour can.

Starmer was duly attacked for this sensible proposal from all sides. Brexit supporters like the Daily Mail said it was “proof you can’t trust Starmer on Brexit”. Remain supporters got cross that he wasn’t offering something more radical. And analysts pointed out that this kind of tinkering with the existing EU deal would achieve little economic difference and would anyway struggle to engage the Europeans. This latter point – that Europe is done with Brexit and doesn’t want to bring Britain any closer in – is picking up a lot of traction.

And yet that is not the picture we get from the French-German paper. It is of a Europe which is thinking hard about how to incorporate a more friendly UK into its structures. It is looking forward to a day when we can work co-operatively rather than as resentful opponents.

Those of us who consider ourselves European always knew we were in a long-term project of at least a decade to fix the situation after the thumping we got in 2019. It was a three-stage process: Change the government. Repair the relationship. Then fight to rejoin the EU or the single market. The first is on the verge of being achieved. The second comes after the election. The third constitutes a demand on Starmer for a second Labour term, around 2030.

Much could go wrong before then. Starmer might not win this election, let alone the next one. Europe could itself face difficulties – financial or political – which makes it less attractive to British voters. But we have a Labour leader who is cautiously and pragmatically moving closer to Europe. And we have European leaders who are cautiously and pragmatically offering options which might prove politically possible in a few years time.
In the right light, and with a bit of luck, the future of Europe can be seen over the horizon. There is a place for Britain within it.

title: We know Keir Starmer’s asylum policy will work because the Tories are apoplectic about it
lead: The Conservative Party’s hysterics – inventing numbers out of thin air – show Labour is doing something right
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: Keir Starmer has unveiled . You can tell, because all the people who failed in this area of policy are intent on attacking it.
They came thick and fast – wave after wave of mewling know-nothing political idiocy plastered over the press and dutifully reported verbatim by the broadcasters.

Tory vice-chair Lee Anderson – who can make a viable claim, even in this crowded market, to be the stupidest person in British public life –  that Labour’s plan was to “legalise illegal migration”. The Daily Mail hyperventilated itself into total mental collapse with a headline : “Labour ready to open door to EU asylum seekers.”
So what’s actually going on?
The Starmer plan has one key element. It is to process the claims.

It’s dressed up in all sorts of tough-sounding security language of course, because that’s how he needs to sell it. His intervention yesterday was framed through an  and a. There was obviously a lot of infantile GI Joe hardman nonsense in these pieces. “Those who make British lives a misery will face British force – and British justice,” he said, in a spine-shatteringly cringy aside.

But politics involves compromises, on policy and language, and Starmer’s approach is a sensible way to sell the policy. Some on the left would prefer him to talk about compassion, as undoubtedly Jeremy Corbyn would have done. That will placate those who already agree without convincing those who do not.

Strip away the rhetoric, and there is a practical, pragmatic policy in there. Processing the claims sounds obvious. It’s like saying that your health policy is to heal the sick. But that is the stage of organisational decrepitude we have reached. These blindingly obvious points must be made because they run entirely counter to Government policy.

The  basically closed the UK asylum system to those arriving on these shores. Instead, it refused to process claims and then tried to send the asylum seekers somewhere else – to Rwanda, or back to Europe, or home. But the Government couldn’t do the first because it is illegal, can’t do the second because it has no returns agreement, and is barred from doing the third because the Refugee Convention outlaws it.
Starmer has proposed the obvious solution. . Scrap the Illegal Migration Act. Process the claims. Set up a returns agreement with Europe. In other words: establish a functioning asylum system.

This would involve a concerted effort to clear the backlog: recruiting 1,000 more Home Office caseworkers, fast-tracking certain decisions, creating temporary “Nightingale courts” for legal challenges, and establishing a removals unit.

It won’t be easy. Claims processing is not just a question of staff – it’s about equipment, training, specialist skills, pay and morale. But it is a step in the right direction. With fewer people in the backlog, the costs of the system – and in particular the use of hotel accommodation – will fall.

But it’s the second part of the plan that has triggered the Conservative : the returns deal with Europe. And there are indeed reasons to be sceptical about this. The chief one is that Europe is in an absolute state over asylum.

The EU’s system of asylum quotas and returns has . Germany has suspended its quota from Italy because they’re not holding up their end of the bargain. Authoritarian populists in Hungary and Poland are refusing to take part at all. France’s Emmanuel Macron is under severe pressure over the issue.

So it won’t be easy to get a deal. But then, what other option is there? To just give up? To insist that no deal is possible, that no solutions to the problem can ever be found? This is essentially Downing Street’s position. It insists it wants a deal – even last month it  it “remained open” to one. But that deal is evidently one in which Britain gets whatever it wants and offers nothing in return. That’s not a deal. That’s a child rubbing its face with chocolate cake and insisting the world is so unfair.

The Conservative response to Starmer’s plan is to start inventing numbers out of thin air. “Britain will be forced to take more than 100,000 illegal migrants from the safety of Europe each year,” Immigration Minister Robert Jenrick said. This is ostensibly a prediction based on existing European formulas grounded in relative population and GDP levels. But Britain is not in the EU. It would not have to agree to those terms and indeed is vanishingly unlikely to, given the number far exceeds the 45,000 who arrived last year.

From there, the number swung into the wildest realms of the human imagination. In a particularly pitiful editorial,  said that 180,000 would be “the logical outcome of Labour’s new strategy”. Home Secretary Suella Braverman then ramped it up to predictably deranged levels by insisting Britain would become “the dumping ground for many of the millions of illegal migrants that Europe doesn’t want”.

And then, in the usual tiresome merry-go-round of British twaddle, the broadcasters ran with it. The BBC repeated the 100,000 number in many of its bulletins. It mentioned that it was from the Conservatives but it did not mention that it was a completely made-up piece of fantasy-land claptrap. It was allowed to take root in viewers’ minds without the national broadcaster doing the bare journalistic minimum of pointing out that it is nonsense.

We’ve been walking down this road for a long time now. Tory administration after Tory administration has followed the same pattern: refusing meaningful international co-operation, replacing rational debate with post-truth hysterics, and refusing to do the hard organisational work required of a functioning state. And where has it got us? Nowhere. A failing asylum system in a failing country.

Starmer’s plan is pragmatic, practical, realistic and clear-sighted. The best indication of its viability is that it has incensed the people who persistently failed us over the last decade. And no wonder. When you spend your life in an imaginary world, the sight of the real one shocks the system.

title: Theresa May is telling a fairytale about her Brexit deal. This is the truth
lead: May encouraged Brexiter fever dreams and then fell victim to that which she had nurtured
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: Ever since  left office, she has been telling a story about a prime minister who never existed.
She was a great prime minister. She fought down extremist ideologues on both sides. She fought valiantly for a pragmatic middle-way on Brexit. She kept her head while others lost theirs.

This version of the prime minister was born on the morning she resigned from Downing Street, when she stood outside the door of No 10 and  of “compromise”. Today, with a new book out, she’s telling the BBC’s Political Thinking  that she “wanted to deliver a Brexit that recognised the concerns of the 48 per cent”.
If this version of Prime Minister Theresa May had ever existed, we would be in a better place than we are now. But she didn’t, so we’re not.

May never represented some moderate wing of the Conservative Party. She was on its hard-right fringe. As home secretary, she introduced the  policy, which eventually led to the . She refused any mercy to asylum seekers on . She sent out vans with the words “Go Home” emblazoned on them into immigrant areas.

In 2015, with the Brexit referendum fast approaching, she gave us a glimpse of the future, in a keynote speech at the Conservative Party conference. Immigration, she , had “close to zero” net economic and fiscal benefits. There was “no case, in the national interest, for immigration of the scale we have experienced”. EU immigration was “unbalanced” and “unsustainable”.
It was all there at the time: the fierce opposition to immigration. The rejection of economic reality. The constant attempt to placate the right of the party.
And then she became prime minister.

At this point, there was a genuine Brexit compromise position available to her. Indeed, political probity demanded it. The vote had been close. Remain had won in two of the UK’s constituent nations. This needed to be handled delicately and honestly.

The outline of that compromise was perfectly clear, because other countries, like Norway, already used it. It was to and the customs union. This would have preserved the UK’s economy and removed the need for customs and regulatory checks.
In the years to come, this came to be seen as politically impossible, because it would have retained free movement. In reality, it was nothing of the sort.

conducted during and after the referendum found between 20 to 40 per cent of Leave voters were either relaxed about immigration or did not prioritise it above the economy. Indeed, in the days after the vote, it was the outcome Boris Johnson himself seemed to support, when he  Telegraph readers: “British people will still be able to go and work in the EU; to live; to travel; to study; to buy homes and to settle down.”

May could have been straight with Leavers and Remainers, both within and outside of her party. She could have spoken the language of trade-offs and compromise.  She could have genuinely pursued the middle ground.

Instead, she told delegates at the 2016 Tory conference: “I know some people ask about the ‘trade-off’ between controlling immigration and trading with Europe. But that is the wrong way of looking at things… We will decide for ourselves how we control immigration.” Then she made clear that this went to the heart of national identity. “If you believe you’re a citizen of the world,” she , “you’re a citizen of nowhere.”
And that was it. That was the moment in which everything changed. May had taken Ukip’s nativist worldview and absorbed it into what had, until then, been a centre-right Conservative Party.

It meant that Britain would pursue a in which reducing immigration would trump the maintenance of trade with Europe. It meant that customs and regulatory borders would go up. Once that was decided, the whole contorted horror story of the next few years became inevitable. Immediately it was clear that many British workers – from agricultural exporters to  – were in serious trouble. Immediately it was clear that a border would need to be placed either on the island of Ireland or in the Irish Sea.

May engaged in this fairy story for as long as she could, but eventually something had to be written down. That was when the reality of trade-offs became clear, in the form of her so-called “” guarantee of no hard border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. It was a compromise, of sorts. But it was a compromise which was only necessary because of the hard lines she had herself created. It led to her fall from power.
Johnson later surmounted this problem in his characteristic way, simply by lying about it. He drew a trade border within the UK in the Irish Sea and then  it did not exist.

But reality always reasserts itself eventually and by God, it is reasserting itself now. The state of Britain after Brexit is a complete vindication of the warnings critics made during and after the referendum period. We are poorer than we would otherwise be. We are weaker than we would otherwise be. Our economic, diplomatic, trading and political power status is diminished. We are increasingly a shadow of our former self.
, the US and EU announced an ambitious plan to build an economic corridor linking Europe with the Middle East and India. Britain was nowhere to be seen. What was once unthinkable is now commonplace.

It did not need to be this way. May could have pursued a genuine compromise position. She could have faced down the hard Brexiters in her party with at least half the relish with which she lambasted the Remainers. Instead, she encouraged their fever dreams and then fell victim to that which she had nurtured.

That’s the story of the real Prime Minister Theresa May. The imaginary one which she is now describing would have been far superior. It’s a shame she couldn’t have invented her while she was still in power.

title: No matter our achievements, men like Laurence Fox will always judge us on how ‘shaggable’ we are
lead: It’s not just ‘locker-room boy talk’, it’s out and proud and on national television
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: There was a piercing clarity as Laurence Fox and Dan Wootton sniggered, smirked and giggled about not wanting to shag journalist Ava Evans which laid out so many things. One, that  really is the blocked toilet of British broadcasting, platforming some of the nastiest voices on the right. There are big, meaty, ideological discussions from right wing thinkers challenging the personal, political and indeed the philosophical which do deserve a hearing. “Maaate… I wouldn’t even wanna shag ‘er” is not one of them.

But that moment also reminded women that no matter how old or young you are, whatever your background, your professional accomplishments or your lived experiences or stories – it will always boil down to whether some bloke wants to have sex with you. That is your sole worth.

Let me explain. Not being shaggable is your first sin. But it can get worse. If they deem you to be shaggable but you don’t want to shag them back – ooof, well, you’re in some trouble now. At this stage, they’ll either U-turn faster than Rishi Sunak round a heat pump and suddenly reclassify you as an old boiler (combi presumably) who they wouldn’t touch with a barge pole, or if you believe those pesky “feminist” statistics, they could attack and kill you. No cute punchline line there. It often goes back to the maxim – men are scared that women are going to laugh at them, women are scared they’ll get killed.

Women being reduced to what some man would like to do to them is not just about sex or violence. It’s also about male power structures. If your boss or the men in charge think you’re hot, you’re more likely to get the job, promotion, gig, role, or show. That’s why so many women panic about growing older and hitting 40 because that’s when they commit the cardinal sin of being “unf***able” in the eyes of the architects of society who are still mainly men (apart from some very brutal female-hating women’s magazine editors).

And there’s no escape. Even if you’re a serious older woman in, let’s say the world of politics, who has never sought to use her looks or sexuality to make a point, you’re still fair game. My former boss Harriet Harman was and is a fierce feminist politician who has campaigned for a range of issues to help women from childcare provision to tougher sentences for domestic violence and rape. Here’s what Rod Liddle  in The Spectator in 2009 “Harriet Harman then. Would you? I mean after a few beers obviously, not while you were sober.”

I was recently at a briefing about American politics where someone quipped: “Hilary reminded men of their first wife, and why they left her for a much younger, hotter one.” Cue much mirth from the mainly male audience. And who could forget the blistering speech which former Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard made in 2012, triggered by the misogyny she had experienced, much of it centred on her body including a menu which offered “Julia Gillard Kentucky Fried Quail – small breasts, huge thighs and a big red box.”

Some of you may be thinking this is all about looks and attractiveness, and if only that were true. The most mind-blowing case of “I wouldn’t shag her” was deployed earlier this year on social media (so hard to believe I know) against… wait for it… Margot Robbie. Yes. You read that correctly. Margot Robbie is a woman so blessed with the highest level of Hollywood (Caucasian) beauty that she was allowed to play friggin Barbie. And yet, she was told by some dude on the internet in his mum’s basement that she was a “mid” and that there were “hotter” babes about than her and that they “could do better.” If Barbie is now “unshaggable” what hope do the rest of us have with these most kind noblemen?

So maybe we ladies/rabid feminazis should grudgingly thank the sewer that was the  for something. It’s now clear for all to see in glorious technicolour – everyday sexism is alive and well. We aren’t imagining it. It’s not in our pretty, stupid heads. We’re not even being gaslit anymore. It’s no longer “locker-room boy talk”, it’s out and proud and on national television. Although is it any surprise really? Look who they put in the Whitehouse a few years ago and may soon make his comeback.

title: Keir Starmer’s immigration plans are not about undoing Brexit. What a shame
lead: The Labour leader has been clear there will be no ‘going back in’ to the EU, no matter what the Tories’ attack line is. Meanwhile, Britain’s migration policy is a mess
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: Immigration has haunted Labour for many years. The party is either accused by the right vof being bleeding-heart liberals who advocate open borders, or accused by the left of being vicious, heartless racist thugs. It’s a lose-lose. Which is why the party’s default position for a long time has been to say very little.

But that isn’t an option right now because the entire system is out of control, and this time, it isn’t the fault of the Labour Party. The numbers – both legal and illegal – have shot up under the twitching eye of one of the most right-wing Tory governments in recent history, one which has consistently made bringing numbers down its absolute priority (and which has failed spectacularly).

The chumps who brought us Brexit promised the people control of the borders. Instead, chaos reigns supreme. More and more people crossing the Channel. Hotels and B&Bs, often in deprived areas, stuffed full of. Soaring accommodation bills. Local tensions. And no end of Wacky Races-type madcap ideas that manage to blend extreme cruelty with dark comedy thanks to the incompetence and idiocy involved.

The Rwanda scheme is costing vast sums of money, yet no planes can take off. A woeful immigration minister talks tough, but the only people he can really take it out on are the. Take that, Mickey Mouse. A  was even floated as a solution to the small boats crisis at one point. The idea that this Government could have the competence to harness tidal power and command the sea to stop those pesky boats is hilarious.

All they have is rhetoric. And the harder and more insane it gets, the higher the numbers go. I genuinely believe that their constant cycle of going big on immigration, then failing to curb Channel crossings, has only telegraphed to the traffickers how broken the system is, and probably encouraged them.

And yet the Tories’ biggest attack line on Labour (apart from economic mismanagement) is still immigration. Despite their appalling record, they are going to come for Keir Starmer on this, so it makes sense for Labour to not only be ready for it, but to try and get on the front foot and shape the debate, which is what we are seeing this week.

Starmer and shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper have been waiting for the right moment to set out their stall. Cooper has been covering this brief for a long time – as shadow Home Secretary back in 2015 when the migrant crisis and the camps in France were hitting the headlines, and then as chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee. She knows the policy details and the difficult politics of immigration almost better than anyone.

Cooper is cautious of going out too far on a limb, and she and Starmer have been planning an intervention that is as credible, robust and safe as possible. They want to get out on this, but they don’t want to scare the horses. Whether they succeed remains to be seen.

The overall plan looks pretty common-sense, although is not actually that new. It brings together ideas which have been floated before, like the pledge to scrap the Rwanda scheme, plans to expedite the backlog of cases, better intelligence sharing with crime agencies, more co-operation, and an EU-wide returns agreement for asylum seekers.

On better co-operation, no one can really criticise that, as it’s something the Government themselves have been working on. Indeed, better relations with Albania shows that co-operation can work. It also shows why a returns agreement is so important, something which we don’t have now post leaving the EU and the Dublin Agreement.
But this is what the Tories and the right-wing press will zone in on. We have already seen Tory MPs claim that a returns agreement would mean the UK taking an extra 100,000 asylum seekers.

There are also accusations that any deal would somehow be a precursor to Britain rejoining the EU. If only, sighs this Remainer and many others. Starmer was clear in his media rounds that there would be no return to freedom of movement, the single market or the customs union, and no “going back in”.

Remember, he has been pretty tough with businesses by saying that they have to wean themselves off “cheap EU imported” labour, to much annoyance. I personally think this stance will make life harder for him on the growth front but it’s clear he is signalling very aggressively that he wants to bring overall immigration down, despite our skills shortages.

The reality is that if we want an effective returns policy, which is crucial, that will involve taking a fair share of people. Why would other EU countries bend over to help us when they are having their own set of issues on this front along with other shared woes like inflation and housing? We must realise that a deal means compromise (I know, I know).

The level of naivety around what other countries owe us from some right-wing figures is astonishing. Many countries already think we have an unfair advantage from migration because of our geography as an island, and they are right. At some point, people were going to try and use the Channel to get here. Necessity is the mother of invention and a great deal of tragedy.

Labour’s plans are a good start. They are serious, sensible, and rooted in reality, as opposed to cruel, ideological fantasy. They also demonstrate a political confidence – no no-go areas. But the truth is that stopping small boats (or the next form of travel to get here) is still going to be incredibly difficult even with a better, less calamitous government.
Mass migration will only increase due to poverty, conflict, the climate crisis, extreme weather, and natural disaster –  – and the desire to seek safety and a better life.

Men and women have always moved across the globe. We were the masters of it back in the day, ruling the waves and all that. You can set up agreements, treaties and have a stronger criminal justice response and that is all very important, but it is very hard to stop innate human nature. Especially when people are desperate and have nothing to lose.

title: The big by-election winner was… Boris Johnson
lead: Uxbridge and South Ruislip delivered the former PM’s dream result – but that doesn’t change the fact that it looks like the Tory Government is in its end days
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: Yesterday’s trio of by-elections were like a progressive sports day: . How’s that for classic British fair play?

While by-elections are not the be all and end all,  these are fascinating events – they test the newspaper polls with actual human beings at the ballot box. And give people like me something to get excited about.

So what did we learn? Never bet against. They continue their remarkable run of success with a big win in Somerton and Frome, taking another seat off the Conservatives. They are going to need a considerably bigger . Their results also show that people have developed a taste for tactical voting and rather like it. Whether that carries on in a general election remains to be seen but it will definitely play a role.

The fact that the Lib Dems did so badly in and that Labour lost their deposit in Somerton and Frome hints at a low-key, informal alliance, certainly when it comes to allocating resources and how hard a party chooses to fight a seat when they know a rival could knock out the sitting Tory MP. Is Sir Ed proving to be Sir Keir Starmer’s Paddy Ashdown, who was so significant to Labour’s 1997 success?
When it comes to the Tories, it was a surprise to all (most of all, to them) that they held Uxbridge and South Ruislip by just 495 votes. But a win’s a win and it gave . It was now not a 3-0 defeat.

But it doesn’t change political gravity and it still looks very much like the Tories are in their end days of office. Conservative voices are valiantly spinning that the Ulez referendum, which is what Uxbridge effectively became, is the key to winning the next election. This is for the birds, however. Where they do have a point is that it will be a clear dividing line at the next London mayoral election.

Sadly, the big beneficiaries of Uxbridge are the right-wing climate sceptics within the Tory party who can use this victory to hammer their message that green issues turn off the public. That is a great shame for all of us who care about  but there is no doubt this gives the “green crap” culture warriors a shot in the arm (don’t tell the anti-vaxxers).

Perhaps the biggest winner, however, is Boris Johnson. This was his dream result. A win for the Tories, but by a whisker – he will now no doubt claim bragging rights in a column on Ulez, even though he introduced the.

There was good and bad news for Labour. Last night’s stunning victory in Selby and Ainsty gives Starmer permission to assert there is very likely to be a Labour government with a majority after the next election. That felt a stretch to many after the local elections in May, but he has won that right. He should be given credit for passing every electoral test he is set by commentators. Selby was declared the one to really prove that he’s on track for a Labour majority and he won big, with a 24 per cent swing in a Tory heartland.

Remember how bruising the reaction was to Labour losing the Hartlepool by-election in 2021? Many saw that as the beginning of the end for Starmer and a sign of Johnson’s unstoppable march forward. Well, life comes at you fast. Especially in British politics. And especially for the Labour leader, who has taken the party, in Tony Blair’s own words, “from the brink of extinction to the brink of government” – a feat not to be dismissed.

But there’s a long way to go until a general election – which could be in November next year according to reports – and a lot can go wrong for Labour in that time. Which is what Uxbridge and South Ruislip showed. The Tories successfully .

There was a clear disconnect between London Mayor Sadiq Khan and local Labour MPs in those outer London seats (as well as Starmer’s office). Local MPs like Clive Efford (Eltham) have long argued that the principle is right but that it makes sense to delay implementation while there is a cost of living and fuel crisis and the cost of replacement-compliant cars is also rising. The fact that Uxbridge Labour candidate Danny Beales changed his position so late in the campaign speaks to an internal tension that should have been resolved earlier.

There are two issues here. One is how to navigate the politics around well-intentioned environmental proposals during an economic crisis. Luke Akehurst, a prominent Starmer supporter and member of the party’s NEC, has warned about the impact of robust anti-car policies, saying “they are understandably popular in inner urban areas but alienate working-class voters in outer areas of towns and cities. We need to listen as this could be the new Brexit culture wedge.” The politics of the motorist is back – certainly for the next mayoral election in London.

The divide between Khan, Labour MPs and the party centre on this issue and throw up a second interesting point: Starmer versus the mayors (those within the Labour movement who currently do actually hold power). Many elected Labour leaders in the nations and regions have strong, proud views on issues including green policies, giving away tax-raising powers, free school lunches and the two-child cap on benefits, which inevitably will cause tensions within the party – especially as the National Policy Forum gathers in Nottingham this weekend.
Labour is very keen to give away power to local leaders – but how much is too much when it comes down to the nuts and bolts of actually winning a general election?

However, although Uxbridge is an interesting blip for Labour and throws up some bigger questions, it shouldn’t dominate the overall narrative, as Ulez is not going to be a national issue. The key takeaway from the local elections, and now Thursday’s by-elections, is that this country is crying out for change and that voters are smart enough to work out who to support in which part of the country to make that happen. No Tory should feel safe.

title: Brace yourselves Birmingham, living under a bankrupt council means paying more for less
lead: Here’s what we’ve faced in Croydon since a Section 114 was issued
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: Birmingham City Council, the largest local authority in Europe, issued a Section 114 notice earlier this month – effectively .
It is expected to be announced later on Tuesday  the day-to-day running of the council. Rumours abound that the Library of Birmingham and Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery will be sold off.

Birmingham is not unique. In the past five years Northampton, Northumberland, Nottingham, Slough, Thurrock, Woking and my very own London borough of Croydon . Between them they have been both Conservative and Labour-run authorities, but all have in recent years declared that they can no longer balance their books.
My advice to the one million-plus people served by Birmingham Council is brace yourselves. You are going to pay more to get less. Here’s what we’ve faced in Croydon since a Section 114 was issued.

Last year council tax went up by 15 per cent – in the middle of a cost of living crisis the average household paid an extra £235 a year, taking bills to over £2,000. Council tax support, which offers discounts on council tax to low income households .
All funding to the voluntary sector has stopped, cutting vital services, including for homeless people and people with mental health conditions.

A local maintained nursery school around the corner from me, which specialises in provision for children with special educational needs (SEN), is facing closure – . The adult social care budget has been cut, the housing services department is shedding jobs, despite council tenants being hit with a 7 per cent increase .

It’s a similar story in Woking, which issued a Section 114 notice in June. There, local toilets, community centres and a swimming pool are earmarked for closure; there will be budget cuts for parks, the arts, and for community transport for elderly and disabled people.
And this is coming to your town too: Bradford, Devon, Guildford, Hastings, Kent, and Southampton are all said to be on the brink of issuing a Section 114 notice in the coming months.

Throughout the country there have been mass closures of local services. In 2019, : councils in England had closed more than 859 children’s centres, 940 youth centres, 835 public conveniences and 738 libraries, as well as funding for 1,224 bus routes having been withdrawn.
Even councils’ statutory provision, like social care and children’s services, have not been untouched. The cuts to social care mean that .

This is not though a tale of neglect. Government has sat not idle while councils collapsed. It has actively set fire to them with massive spending cuts, and then turned off the alarm by abolishing the Audit Commission, the independent spending watchdog which oversaw local government accounts, in 2015.
, since 2010 councils in England have faced cuts in their resource spending of 21 per cent. In Scotland, that figure is just 7 per cent, in Wales it is eight per cent.

Funding cuts are only one side of the equation. While the supply of funding has dried up, the demand has increased. Thanks to a decade of weak economic growth, failure to build adequate housing and benefit cuts, councils have greater poverty and homelessness to contend with in their communities, and an ageing society.
The Audit Commission was closed in a move that the Secretary of State (now Lord) Eric Pickles said was designed . It certainly reduced inspection and auditing.

In 2014, as councils complained of budget cuts, Pickles told themthey should be “making creative use of reserves to address short-term costs, such as restructuring, or invest to save for the longer term”.

Not all those investments turned out so well, and the body that would have checked them was abolished. Running down reserves meant that, as austerity continued and the economy tanked again, councils started amassing unsustainable debts.
As 2023 rolls into 2024, many  down the financial plughole. This is a crisis coming to a town near you.
Andrew Fisher is the former director of policy for the Labour Party

title: Stop the War has exposed how hollow it now is. It should disband
lead: Stop the War has marginalised itself and alienated the vast majority of the Ukrainian population in the UK
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: In 2001, I was at the founding meeting of the campaign group Stop the War Coalition. I’m immensely proud of marching against war on Afghanistan and Iraq – but the Stop the War Coalition, formed in response to Tony Blair and George W Bush declaring a “war on terror”, should have ended when UK troops withdrew from Afghanistan. At that point, the war on terror, as we knew it, was over.

Stop the War was a coalition of people and organisations that did not believe the right response to the 9/11 attacks was an ill-defined “war on terror”. This gave succour to oppressive dictatorships such as Vladimir Putin’s Russia, then waging war against the Chechen people, who were labelled as “terrorists”.
Two of those who had protested Putin’s aggression against Chechnya in 2000 were Tony Benn and Jeremy Corbyn, who went on to be leading lights in the Stop the War Coalition.

At its peak, the Stop the War Coalition encompassed the majority of British , the leadership of the Liberal Democrats and Greens, and – little did we know it at the time – the future leadership of the Labour Party.

Trade union banners adorned that massive protest (the largest in UK political history) in February 2003 when more than 1.5 million of us marched in London against the Iraq war, with the support of every major trade union in the country.

This week, the Stop the War Coalition showed how hollowed out that coalition has become. As Trades Union Congress (TUC) delegates met in Liverpool, they were castigated by Stop the War for overwhelmingly backing Composite 21, a motion supporting Ukrainian resistance to the Russian invasion. It : “If Congress adopts this motion it will be taking a position supportive of the Tory govt’s war policy in Ukraine.” Portraying TUC delegates as Tory supporters, pro-Nato and apologists for imperialism is laughable.
Composite 21 was passed overwhelmingly at TUC Congress in Liverpool, with only a handful of delegates opposed.

The Socialist Campaign Group of Labour MPs – the bulwark of resistance to New Labour’s military adventures – is, like the TUC, overwhelmingly united in solidarity with the Ukrainian people against the Russian invasion. Former shadow chancellor John McDonnell spoke at a Ukraine Solidarity Campaign meeting alongside trade union leaders on Tuesday night in Liverpool.

Ian Lavery (a former president of the National Union of Mineworkers) and Nadia Whittome, a former trade union rep, both sent  expressing their support for the position adopted by the TUC. According to the warped minds of the withered remnants of the now grandiosely-named Stop the War Coalition they are “backing the Tories”.

Across the political spectrum and public opinion, Stop the War finds itself in a tiny minority position. Bizarrely and ironically, it finds itself replicating many of the arguments used against Stop the War when opposing the war on Iraq.

Then, we were told that, by opposing the bombing of Iraq, we were supporting Saddam Hussein. Now Stop the War says those backing the Ukrainians are pro-Nato. Like Jeremy Corbyn, I believe Nato should have disbanded at the end of the Cold War. Instead, it has been involved in a series of disastrous interventions from Afghanistan to Libya, which I have also opposed. That doesn’t obscure the fact that Nato’s role is a secondary one.

Likewise, sharp criticisms of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s domestic policies – its neoliberal economic policies or anti-union laws – does not obscure the fact that the invasion by Russia is wrong. Backing the Ukrainian people does not mean giving full support to the domestic politics of Zelensky, any more than opposing the Iraq war meant an adoration of Saddam Hussein.

As Dr Yuliya Yurchenko, a senior lecturer in political economy at the University of Greenwich, said: “The international left must put its decolonial hat on in thinking about Ukraine. We are fighting Russia, our historic imperial oppressor. We’ve been politically, economically, culturally and linguistically dominated and colonised for a very long time. I think some people still get their vision clouded by a one-dimensional opposition to US imperialism alone. But the US is not the aggressor in this situation.”
Stop the War made sense when the UK government was starting aggressive wars around the world: Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya. But the UK did not start this war. Russia did.
Under this or future UK governments, new wars may be proposed and waged. We may need to build new coalitions to oppose those wars.

Stop the War could have called for “Russian troops out”, elevated the voices of the oppressed anti-war movement in Russia, while backing the rights of refugees to settle here. Instead, it has marginalised itself, alienated the vast majority of the Ukrainian population in the UK, and probably scuppered any chance of it being a broad-based campaign able to mobilise against any future wars.

Those holding onto the Stop the War banner no longer speak for the many who flocked to it two decades ago. They should show some humility and disband. As we said of the UK government in 2003, “not in my name”.
Andrew Fisher is the former director of policy for the Labour Party

title: The Labour reshuffle leaves Starmer surrounded by yes-men
lead: Even the mildest of dissent is not tolerated, let alone embraced. Labour needs radicalism
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: Listening to Education Secretary Gillian Keegan this morning fumbling to explain why hundreds of schools are not fully open due to crumbling concrete, I suspect  is regretting opting against a wider reshuffle in his top team. Her floundering excuses were followed by her post-interview, , frustration that her predecessors had “sat on their arses and done nothing”.

I had been briefed on Friday by several sources that the much-rumoured would take place on Monday. I was also told it was to be “significant”. In terms of movements in and out of the Shadow Cabinet it was, and yet, has anything really changed?

“Policies not personalities” is a principle that was fondly and repeatedly articulated by Tony Benn, a Cabinet minister in the governments of Harold Wilson and Jim Callaghan. It was the first bullet point on my notes for my BBC Politics Live appearance today. I wanted to make the point that ultimately what matters is not who is in the Shadow Cabinet, but what is being done (or not). Peering over my shoulder, before we went into the studio, my fellow panellist Liz Kendall said “well, I agree with your first point”.

Kendall had just moments before been appointed , replacing her neighbouring Leicester MP Jon Ashworth who, back in June, had  on benefits as “heinous”, saying that it was “keeping children in poverty”, and signalling it would be repealed under a Labour government. A few weeks later Labour leader Keir Starmer announced that Labour . Shadow cabinet sources tell me Ashworth had not been briefed in advance of Starmer’s intervention.
On Politics Live, the new shadow secretary of state confirmed that her appointment meant no change on the two-child limit, or indeed probably any social security policy.
That is not to say that personalities don’t matter. But the problem is we don’t have Cabinet government or even Shadow Cabinet opposition any more.

Read Tony Benn’s diaries or those of Barbara Castle and you get a flavour of detailed debates that went on in government – ministers having wide-ranging debates about the best policies for the country. The Cabinets in which Benn served were in the broad church tradition that included figures on the left like Benn, soft left MPs like Castle, liberal centrists like Roy Jenkins and those on the right of the Labour Party such as Denis Healey and Tony Crosland.

Today, policy is constrained by the self-imposed straitjacket of arbitrary fiscal rules, political caution and an emphasis on unity and discipline that means any independent thought or even the mildest of dissent cannot be tolerated, let alone embraced.

Strong leaders welcome debate – even challenge – yet Starmer’s Labour is a top-down affair. Shadow Cabinet meets only briefly, sources tell me, with Starmer discouraging discussion. Every Labour minister is constrained and on-message, or they’re out.

That was the fate that befell Rosena Allin-Khan who until Monday had been Labour’s shadow minister for mental health, attending Shadow Cabinet. An NHS doctor  was barred by Starmer’s office for doing any interviews after travelling to Ukraine to work as a humanitarian doctor. Allin-Khan – who has previously volunteered in Palestine and Myanmar – was scolded on her return.

NHS doctor Rosena was also said to be have been less than impressed by shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting’s embrace of outsourcing to the private sector. Allin-Khan is by no means on the party’s left. Like the Greater Manchester Mayor and London Mayor , she sits somewhere between the party’s right and soft left. All three have been the subject of . Independent-mindedness is not welcome.

Another scalp for Team Starmer was , who once toyed with the idea of rent controls (a big no, no) and building council housing. Shadow Chancellor Rachel , but reform to planning would be the solution to increase home ownership. “Reform will do the heavy lifting” is the endorsed refrain parroted enthusiastically by Starmer, Reeves and Streeting.

The hospital pass that is shadow levelling up – encompassing local government, housing and planning – now falls to , who  can be solved without spending more money. Alchemists set themselves an easier challenge.

Rayner though has dug her heels in and kept the shadow future of work brief. Labour’s commitment to strengthening employment and trade union rights remains one of the few policy commitments yet to be reneged upon, although a recent briefing to the Financial Times – apparently without the knowledge of Rayner – suggests that it is not safe yet.

The other significant non-move is that Lou Haigh, the shadow Transport Secretary, who keeps control of two areas that have endeared her to the party’s left: public ownership of rail and the re-regulation of bus services. Her retention signals those policies are at least safe for now.
So overall nothing much has changed. The new Labour Shadow Cabinet can look at the polls – and the continuing scandals and failures of the Tory Government – and prepare for government.

In today’s most under-discussed and overshadowed appointment, former senior civil servant finally joined as Keir Starmer’s chief of staff. In his memoir, Gordon Brown wrote of Gray that she offered “wise advice when – as all too regularly happened – mini-crises and crises befell”.

With the crises Keir Starmer’s new team will inherit in government, her wise advice should be for the Shadow Cabinet to start making the case for redistributive taxation to solve the multiple crises they will inherit. Without that, she’ll be advising on mini-crises and crises for a long time yet.
Andrew Fisher is the former director of policy for the Labour Party

title: Rishi Sunak is trying to do what Nick Clegg did in 2010 – but he’s forgetting one vital point
lead: It’s a bold move
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Was  onto something really important in his  this week? No, not the changes the Prime Minister announced to measures tackling climate change, but something else he seemed equally agitated about.

He spent a fair bit of his hastily-rearranged address to the nation complaining about the state of politics, about short-termism, and about the way in which measures to tackle climate change had barely been scrutinised by MPs, let alone the public at large. He said: “I know that they dislike Westminster game-playing, the short-termism and the lack of accountability.”

Parts of the speech sounded a bit like  in the 2010 leaders’ TV debates, where he decried the state of two-party politics and charmed voters by  “the more they attack each other, the more they sound exactly the same”.
This was opposition, anti-politics Clegg, rather than responsible in-government Clegg, or indeed the new tech bro Clegg who Sunak would probably quite enjoy hanging out with.
Either way, Sunak is in government, whereas Clegg wasn’t at the time, so it was much easier for a Lib Dem leader few had really heard of to attack the state of politics.

Like Clegg, Sunak wants to posit himself as the change candidate in the looming general election, with Labour representing lazy consensus and a failure to be honest with the electorate, a status quo in the form of disruptive strike action, and so on. It’s a bold move.

Voters do dislike all the things Sunak listed, but so far he has shown no real inclination to make the fundamental changes that would answer that yearning for change. Why is there such a lack of accountability in politics?

Part of the reason is ambitious backbenchers stay loyal to the Government, even when they know there is a problem with a Bill because they understandably want to progress their career and have greater influence by joining the Government.

The conflict of interest in legislators wanting to join the executive they are supposed to be holding to account is something one of his closest aides and my former colleague James Forsyth was very alive to when he was at The Spectator.

He often wrote about the need for a formal separation of powers, or at least for experienced politicians who had been ministers to see the value in staying in the Commons after high office so they could help their successors avoid making mistakes. The chances of his conviction making it into reality are pretty slim, though.

Sunak complained this week that the last carbon budget process was “debated in the House of Commons for just 17 minutes and voted through with barely any consideration given to the hard choices needed to fulfil it”. He said he wanted Parliament to consider the plans to meet the carbon budget at the same time in any future votes.

Fine, but is he really also proposing making more time available for MPs to examine government policies? The current conduct of the Government suggests not. Even though he was rushed into unveiling his net zero changes a day early, he had always been planning to make that announcement when Parliament was in recess, meaning MPs didn’t have the chance to debate it at all. The Speaker of the House of Commons was furious, issuing an unusually forthright statement in which he said that if he had the power, he would recall the House.

The Prime Minister would never offend his colleagues by saying this, but the public are anyway quite aware that the calibre of politicians isn’t what it should be. There are lots of reasons for this, not least that many talented people wouldn’t want the weird, often dysfunctional life of an MP.

But it is also the case that even the talented folk who do make it into the Palace of Westminster are ill used by a culture  performing what should be one of the primary functions of their job: scrutiny.

Keir Starmer likes to complain about “sticking plaster politics” too, which is less of a surprise coming from the Leader of the Opposition than it is from the man in power. But even he only wants to talk about reforming the House of Lords rather than any proposals to make the House of Commons work better.

That’s because suits the people in power, at least in the short term. In the long term, of course, the problems that might have been raised earlier by a stronger legislature end up biting the government that introduced them.

At this autumn’s conference, Sunak wants to tell his party he is the one prepared to speak hard truths. But a hard truth he doesn’t seem to be prepared to confront himself is that all the things he complains about will just keep happening unless he is prepared to make himself less powerful.
Isabel Hardman is assistant editor of The Spectator magazine

title: Abuse of Power by Theresa May review: Ex-PM leaves no stone unturned, except when it comes to her own failings
lead: In this crisply written book, Theresa May accepts her premiership will be remembered for her failure to deliver Brexit. But we are all only self-aware up to a point
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Theresa May’s first speech as Prime Minister promised to tackle the of society, so perhaps it’s no surprise that her book, Abuse of Power, returns to that topic after her premiership was .

Like all ex-prime ministers, she has a few scores to settle, and a few points she wants to make for the record. Unlike her immediate predecessor David Cameron, who actually gave his memoirs the title , she doesn’t seem that interested in recording the day-to-day experience of being in power.

In fairness, not many people would want to recollect in great detail the trauma of that hamstrung parliament, the indicative votes, the weird fairground atmosphere of a Westminster filled with screaming pro- and anti-Brexit protesters. Instead, May has written about the cases of abuse of power she encountered in office. Some are well-understood: , sexual harassment, , Russia’s illegal invasion of Ukraine and so on.

Others are more surprising: as well as arguing that there was an abuse of power from a number of figures, including , while she attempted to lead the country through Brexit, she accuses the US of an abuse of power in its  “by acting in its own interests”.

She finds several themes. One was that people in power rode roughshod over bereaved, injured and traumatised people “because they could”. Many of the chapters finish with that refrain. Another is the desire of public sector institutions to protect their reputations rather than the people they purport to serve.

May tries to be as reflective as possible, accepting that her premiership will largely be remembered for her failure to deliver Brexit, and that the  in which she lost the Conservative majority was her mistake. But of course we are all only self-aware up to a point, and I wonder whether she might also reflect that some might see an attempt at abuse of power in the very act of calling the election.

The Daily Mail wrote this up as “crush the saboteurs”, and those around May boasted at the time of a huge majority that would allow them to do as they pleased. Anyway, the British public clearly thought she didn’t deserve as much power as she already had.

Her travails after losing that majority were also not blameless. The reinstatement of the Conservative whip to two men accused at the time of serious sexual impropriety (since proven in court) – – represented an abuse of power: it was given back to them so they could back her in the vote of no confidence in 2019.

But that’s human nature: even the most self-reflective among us misses things others spot. May’s book is fascinating and crisply written, but it does also suffer from a narrow view of human nature itself: her diagnosis of the problems we have is strong and detailed, her analysis of why they have happened quite good, but her prescription for how to stop abuses of power in the future is weak because it relies too heavily on an assumption that more people could develop the commitment to service she clearly sees as a core part of her identity.

Her concluding chapter is entitled The Answer Is Service, and while it is very good on how too many politicians are careerists and how Parliament doesn’t work to improve the skills or behaviour of its occupants, she is possibly too idealistic about what motivates most people.

Not everyone has the quiet and serious vicarage upbringing May recalls fondly in this book. Indeed, most have a more complex mix of altruism and a desire to be praised and paid well, motivating us to do all kinds of jobs, whether it be MPs, doctors or other public servants.

That May has more seriousness and commitment than the average politician is one of the reasons she hasn’t bustled out of Parliament to earn money elsewhere, like some of her fellow ex-PMs. It also means she has a better chance to fix some of those burning injustices this book shows she is clearly still worried about.

title: In Rishi Sunak’s worst-ever week, he paid the price for David Cameron’s mistakes
lead: Even someone doing a truly effing good job would struggle to fix these problems in time
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Rishi Sunak’s first week back in Westminster turned out to be an elegant summary of the predicament he finds himself in. The Prime Minister is a technocrat who believes more than anything else in getting through the “too difficult” bit of a leader’s in-tray and making things work better. But the in-tray isn’t so much groaning as cracking under the weight of crumbling concrete in schools (), an escaped prisoner from a jail where staffing was so short  – as well as all the other crises we had long known about in the health service, illegal immigration, and so on.

Of course, we in fact did already know about the concrete crisis, and the fact that the justice system is also cracking, for a long time. As Sunak himself reminded at Prime Minister’s Questions this week, problems with reinforced autoclaved aerated concrete had been known since the mid-90s:  buildings containing RAAC this week was that the risk assessment had changed.

A particularly lame attack line from his backbench colleagues was that Labour had known about RAAC for 13 years, but hadn’t done anything about it. It’s the kind of slam dunk you can do on coming into office, not at the end of your own 13 year period of also doing nothing about an issue.

Sunak’s Education Secretary Gillian Keegan  when she complained that no-one was thanking her for doing a ‘f***ing good job’, but both she and the Prime Minister have indeed come late to a problem their predecessors sat on their backsides and ignored. Presumably the calculation of the four Conservative prime ministers and 10 education secretaries who came before them was that by the time these chickens came home to roost, it would be to a coop run by another party.

Well, the chickens have come home to roost, perhaps earlier than the Tories expected, or perhaps the long line of people at the top of the party never really believed they’d be in power for this long. Certainly few of them thought that the past 13 years would involve the party repeatedly squandering the majorities it did manage to win to the extent that it has scarcely had the time to move from the bit of the in-tray marked “urgent and important” to the “important but not urgent” section where public buildings languished.

Our political culture hardly rewards people who work on important but not urgent matters, either. It’s easy to focus here on the electoral cycle, which encourages an attention span of five years. Secretaries of State in big delivery departments have been asking potential recruits to set out how they might deliver something that looks like success within ever-shrinking windows: one whose projects are necessarily very long-term was nonetheless asking interviewees what they thought they could show for their work within a year, because that’s when the next election is due. But no-one (not even an exhausted Touy) really wants an even longer cycle that denies voters the chance to hold their politicians accountable in a reasonably timely fashion. There are other ways in which short-term thinking flourishes in Westminster.

Most of us reach a point around our early twenties when we realise, often with some satisfaction, that the most confident people around us are not necessarily the most able. The fellow student who predicted they’d get a first without any evidence of hard work or aptitude. The tremendously self-impressed person sitting next to you at a job interview who you never saw again. Sadly, this realisation seems to have passed a lot of people in Westminster by: you can spend years proclaiming confidently that you’re doing a great job – and there is enough credulity in the system to allow you to keep bullshitting your way through, to use a Keegan-sequence turn of phrase. By the time it transpires that you haven’t done a good job, you’ll have fled the scene anyway.

David Cameron and George Osborne spent most of their , with their own hard hats and hi-viz jackets, despite failing to reform the planning system so that enough homes were built, bring the school and NHS estates up to scratch, address a creaking justice system or reform social care. There are children who don builders’ costumes who achieve more in a sandpit.

Of course, these two had the excuse of being in coalition with the equally short-termist Liberal Democrats: their leader Nick Clegg famously boasted that there was no point in investing in  because the new plants wouldn’t be in operation until 2022 (which turned out to be the year Britain could really have done with a bit more energy security and a bit less reliance on Russia). Then of course they had a majority for a year before they squandered it on Brexit. Then Theresa May squandered the actual majority by trying to get a bigger one.

Boris Johnson got the parliamentary numbers to get his way, but then blew up his own authority with his behaviour. Liz Truss took a  of Tory MPs backing her. Sunak tends to avoid doing anything to highlight how fragile his command is over the notional Tory majority. But even with that careful management which means dodging the same issues that Cameron ducked a decade ago, Sunak is the one watching the chickens come home to roost. Even someone doing a truly effing good job would struggle to fix these problems in time for voters to thank them.
