The Ryder Cup is divided into the following match play competitions:
In foursomes two players from each team play one ball, taking alternating shots. One point will be allocated to each team for a win, and a tie will result in each team earning a half point.

In fourball two players from each team compete but each has their own ball. The best score for each side is taken as the score for each hole. Like with foursomes, a win is worth a point, and that point is halved in a tie.

All 12 players from both the US and European teams compete head-to-head in singles matches, with a point for a win. The match-ups are somewhat random, with each captain deciding the order the players will be sent out in ahead of time.
This year’s tournament is at Marco Simone Golf and Country Club near Rome in Italy.
It was designed by architect Jim Fazio and recently underwent an €11m (£9.5m) complete restyling in order to host the Ryder Cup.
Some of the highlights of the course are its expansive lakes and the ability to see St Peter’s Dome from many vantage points.
But most impressively, on the grounds of the course is an 11th-century castle. It’s wedged between the sixth and eighth holes and has a large Italian flag waving from its tower.

title: Dylan Hartley: Eddie Jones over the hill? I disagree
lead: Don’t get me wrong, we can be critical of his mistakes at this World Cup – but keep it professional
author: Dylan Hartley

body.text: I have a great respect for “the man in the arena”, as the description goes in the famous passage from American president Theodore Roosevelt.

The individuals who go out on to the turf to compete, physically and emotionally draining themselves, pouring years, months, weeks of preparation into 80 mins. They’re there to fight and win, but at times they will inevitably lose and get it wrong on the big stage (many a time for me!).

They then have to pick up the crap that’s thrown at them from disappointed fans and media while patching themselves up to go again. Another week of prep, more emotional and physical expenditure to fight another day. A little reminder that these players and coaches are human (yes  is human) and we’d do well to remember that.

Don’t get me wrong, we can be critical but keep it professional. Let’s talk Australia’s timing of Eddie’s appointment and Dave Rennie’s exit, as well as his selection and philosophy but that needs to be separated from personal/character assassination of which I’m seeing a lot, none of which is from people who have worked with Eddie and know the coach well enough to give a fair, factual analysis. A lot of opinion-spitters are blurring the lines of fact and fiction.

So let’s examine this issue of the timing of his appointment.  (RA) need to take responsibility for this. The low-impact option would have been for RA to let Rennie play out to the , purely for continuity and a steady ship, which is all important going to a big tournament – but the danger in doing so would be if Australia progressed and put on a good show it would complicate his exit.
Did they romanticise Eddie’s grand return? It also shows the excitement around someone like Eddie Jones on the open market. He is a quality coach, with impressive stats and speaks fluent Australian.

From Eddie’s point of view, imagine being released from your role, you’re unemployed and on the hunt for a new challenge (he’s human, remember) when the opportunity to coach his native Aussies emerges after travelling the world in numerous roles.
It must have been a dream job, of course he’d jump at it, it seemed like.

This whole situation was put into play when  Eddie’s contract which threw  into the role nine months before a World Cup instead of letting Eddie see out his England tenure – and people wondered why England were not scoring 10 tries a game and winning everything immediately.

My point is you’re creating multiple stories, stresses and dynamics. Termination of a head coach (never a nice story), uncertainty with players and staff on their futures and now a young coach under the pump with fans wanting performances and results –  the safe play is to let the contract play out and minimise the headlines and noise.
The time for change is post-World Cup, when you’ve got objective data and results, clear heads and a clear direction for the next four years. Good things take time.

In 2019, South Africa culled their coach and inserted Rassie Erasmus at short notice which resulted in them becoming world champions – many factors contributed to this (notably an established world-class playing group). It does prove this can work, but it takes bold leadership to make these culls and calls and ultimately you live and die by them – this time it hasn’t worked for Rugby Australia and we are yet to see how England progress.

The knee-jerk thing for Australia to do now would be to terminate Eddie, but what’s the point in all this pain if you’re going to start again? New coach, new staff, new/old players, more uncertainty. It’s quite clear EJ put his focus on developing the next wave of Australian talent and overtly talked about long-term planning to “make Australia great again”. All of the current crop will be better for this current experience, so long as they stick together.

I would however question why we didn’t see two old war horses in Michael Hooper and Quade Cooper – both high-performing, world-class athletes, talented rugby players with bags of experience. Australia needed them to guide this young crop.

Eddie hasn’t explained those non-selections – and that is very typical of him which leaves unanswered questions, which drives curiosity, frustration and conspiracy. Ultimately he’s in the big seat of leadership where he makes those calls, where you live and die by your selections, and Eddie has died on this one. That said, Carter Gordon, Australia’s young fly-half, will be better for this experience.

Another way to look at it is what’s happened with Wales. They have unearthed a new captain and world-class bolter in Jac Morgan. Just imagine that Warren Gatland had left Justin Tipuric at home and selected Morgan over him – it would have initially created pandemonium in leaving out a stalwart of Tipuric’s quality but the current performances and justified fanfare around Morgan would dissipate those initial grumbles.

A selection masterclass by Gatland and a reminder that in sport we have short memories – so long as we win at the weekend, “everything is awesome” but also a reminder when our team lose it’s not to panic – a case in point is England’s World Cup prep compared to where they sit now.
Behind the scenes, 99 per cent of players who work with Eddie are very complimentary.

They talk about his philosophy on the game, his unwavering dedication to the role and the way he interacts with players as humans away from the paddock… and that’s not forgetting the unrelenting, intense conversations where he holds you accountable to your every word and forensically analyses your physical performances. He keeps you very honest and is 110 per cent dedicated to his role.

It’s commonly suggested I have a blind loyalty to him just because he made me his captain, which is ridiculous. I am loyal with my personal views based on my experience with the man. I have bags of respect for him for reasons outlined above but I’m not blind, there’s nothing to be gained from lying… my time under him was not pleasant but damn it was rewarding. You don’t have to love his media persona but if you can separate that from the rugby, you’ve got to respect what he’s achieved in the game.

The Australian newspaper breaking the story of his discussions over the Japan job on the eve of their game was filthy. Why would you want to sabotage your own team’s prep? Why couldn’t they wait? If they were true-blue Australians, they’d have let the team play Wales, then run with it at a later date.

It seems personal. With an already turbulent campaign, Australia’s young group of players didn’t need extra fuel on the media fire –  I have no doubt it was disruptive to their preparations and performance. Any player who says it’s not a distraction, don’t believe them. It is.

Again, in sport we live in the here and now and have a short memory. England got knocked out at the pool stage in the 2015 World Cup, and they sacked Stuart Lancaster, Andy Farrell, Mike Catt and Graham Rowntree. Lanny and Faz are now being rated among the best coaches in the world while Catty and Wig are doing great in their respective roles.

I believe they had to go through that to become the men and the coaches they are today. We all need to go through that to learn. That sense of failure, hardship, loss, disappointment, to come out the other side stronger, more experienced, uglier and more resilient for it – it’s the same for players and coaches.

Timing is everything. Post-World Cup, in 2016, it was the right time. England had been knocked out of a home World Cup, we were rock bottom and couldn’t go any further which paved the way for opportunity. Whoever is coaching Australia after this World Cup will have a group with only one way to go and that’s up, I believe in time they will come back to be a very powerful rugby team.
Mentioning Andy Farrell, his team were strong contenders along with France, New Zealand and South Africa at the start of this World Cup – now I make them bang-on favourites.

They remind me of England in 2002 and 2003 – slaying whoever steps up, winning everything, doing everything that’s asked of them and fully justifying their world No 1 ranking. Put simply, they are on it and their belief will only be building with every performance like the one last weekend.

I’m of course supporting the darkest of horses England, you know that, but that game I saw between Ireland and South Africa was played like a final. The intensity was something else. South Africa are now a wounded beast and their race is far from run.
I enjoyed their post-match comments saying the loss is good for them as they now understand where they need to go to work – spoken like champions.

I copped some stick for saying had been lucky against Fiji – I stand by it and will repeat it (I wish the Welsh press actually printed the context to what I say not just a headline!)  – they were lucky.

Semi Radradra, one of the best players in the world, dropping the ball with an open try line in the last play of the game is unbelievably lucky, in my eyes – and that’s not taking anything away from the fantastic defensive effort and intensity that Wales hustled with.

As a player, you’re always chasing the perfect game and  was pretty damn good. It was full of some huge individual efforts which contributed to a team performance that has now raised some eyebrows around the tournament.

Warren Gatland has made reference to an episode he and I shared when I was playing for England against his Wales team in 2011. He publicly questioned my temperament and rugby capability… which I thank him for. It gave me the fuel and awareness to prepare for a game like I had never done so before and I subsequently performed well that weekend with England picking up the all-important win in Cardiff.
You could say it’s a great example of the Eddie Jones syndrome – you live by the sword, you die by the sword.

What people don’t see is when Warren had to regulate, with great sportsmanship, and approach me post-match to shake my hand and congratulate me on the performance. That’s the human stuff we don’t always see.

title: Ryder Cup 2023: Why Jon Rahm’s swagger and electric Viktor Hovland are key in Europe’s quest for victory
lead: The cohesion and unforced bonhomie on display from Europe this week suggests their 30-year unbeaten home streak can continue
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: ROME —  opening ceremonies have become a performative over-estimation of a sport best left to speak for itself. The competition is sufficiently compelling to require no sugary amplification. The golfers are never quite able to rid the stage of their awkwardness, and the production suffers from the disconnection between the stage-managed opera and the thing itself.
At least we were spared the role-out on stage of the players’ wives and partners standing decoratively behind the participants, a welcome junking of an ancient insult to womenkind.

They were present in the audience, of course, and also featured as enhancements alongside the golfers in a photo shoot at the Spanish Steps in the Piazza di Spagna. In one sense the episode was entirely innocent. Less so in another, since it pitched women as the augmentation of a thing not fundamental to it.

Golf likes to project this marvellous contest as one of the world’s marquee sporting events. The big production opening ceremony is thought to be a necessary feature associated with heft and grandeur, which places the Ryder Cup alongside the Olympics and the . In that context it is a geopolitical muscle flex, and perhaps appropriate as a naked soft power lunge to garner positive affirmation. In this reduced setting it misses the target.

Though scaled back from the days Justin Timberlake rambled through poetry sets it still feels too much like a sales pitch to big business and sponsors and has yet to settle on an introduction that adequately fits the bill. The schmaltz factor remains too high and jars with the authenticity of the competition.

The Corinthian claims for golf repeatedly made by the captains touch on the sacred elements and traditions that underpin it, but they do not exclude rampant, partisan eruptions that no characterisation of sportsmanship would allow.
Witness  walking after his putt with fingers on lips in a gesture to silence the crowd or  cupping his ears and bouncing around the green screaming defiance, “I can’t hear you”.

All of this is a vital and necessary part of the show too, but does not meet the elevated moral plane the captains ascribe to golf. The idea of playing for something greater than oneself, if sincere, is best expressed on the field rather than wrapped in ribbons and bows. When poured on too thick this stuff acts as a drag on what is a magnificent pageant.

American captain Zach Johnson soared with a speech that sought desperately to link the historic migrations of millions of Italians to the United States to his mission here. The poor and dispossessed seeking a route out of privation and disadvantage in Italy would have rowed their own boats across the Atlantic had they known how valued and romanticised they would be a century later.

This event is not about the American dream of displaced Italians. To make it so is another example of the unnecessary over-reach to which the presentation is victim. His European counterpart  was less ambitious in his attempts to take ownership of Italy but wooed by opening his address in practiced Italian.

Thankfully . The has taken Rome’s seven hills template and pumped it full of juice. There is hardly a flat spot on an undulating track that rises 150 feet from its lowest point. Such is the distance between some greens and tees the players, caddies and scorers resemble an army on the march, flanked by walls of heaving humanity.

On practice days some stopped to sign autographs and pose for selfies, others engaged in banter with the galleries. One, however, stood out in his zoned-in determination on the final day of preparations.

Big Jon Rahm evoked Hannibal leading the Carthaginian rampage across the plains of Italy two millennia ago. The Iberian warrior was all business, exuding a visceral foot-stomping, arms-pumping energy that brooked no quarter.
Rahm imbues this European team with a feeling of invincibility, instilling all with big dog confidence and belief.
Rookie Nicolai Hojgaard was just one beneficiary, strutting about the Rahm group like he was . Rahm’s swagger is just one of the factors behind the bookie’s late swing towards Europe.

Others include the other worldly calm of , who turned pro only in June yet looks ever more the veteran by the day, the enduring excellence of McIlroy and the electricity generated by Viktor Hovland, a golfer better connected to his ball than any at this sunny career juncture.
Thirty years is a long time unbeaten at home. All streaks come to an end and , not least the world No 1 Scottie Scheffler and six of the world’s top 10.

Yet the cohesion and unforced bonhomie on display this week readily promotes the idea of European ascendency, and when Hovland holed out at the drivable par-4 fifth on Thursday morning, it felt like Jupiter himself was pulling for Europe.

title: Inside Bruno Guimaraes’ new contract: Newcastle’s ‘happy camp’ policy and a £100m release clause
lead: Newcastle’s owners want to marry smart recruitment with savvy retention of key players to help compete on four fronts
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: There was a theory doing the rounds in some corners of  social media on Wednesday night that the  was fixed.
“Anyone else notice [Don] Goodman looking at the numbers before picking the away balls?” one prominent account asked as Sky’s footage of the draw was picked apart with a forensic eye.

A quick review of the evidence against him seemed to focus mostly on his previous as a Sunderland player. Given that the pot he was picking the balls from was covered by a giant green lid, it is safe to say the case can be closed and Goodman’s integrity remains unblemished.

Newcastle fans should relax – Manchester United at Old Trafford might not be the kindest reward for taking out Manchester City but it is not the daunting draw it once was. Playing as they did against , their aspirations to go one better than last season’s Wembley final failure do not feel all that unrealistic.
After an early season wobble, it feels as if the Magpies are flying again and Wednesday’s victory, a first over City since 2019 and Eddie Howe’s first over Guardiola, felt significant.

True, they may have eyes on global domination this season but the League Cup has carried heft for City in recent years. This was their earliest exit from the competition since 2011 and it was not a team of greenhorns that Guardiola picked, despite his pre-match protestations.

Newcastle’s greatest achievement was that their own understudies looked more than comfortable on the main stage.  certainly looked the part, shackling Jack Grealish superbly on his full debut. For Paul Dummett, playing his first football since a solitary 90 minutes at Tranmere 13 months ago, it was an especially memorable night.

The battle for Newcastle was always going to maintaining the unity and fire that carried them into fourth last season and Eddie Howe’s rotation policy should ensure competitive edge remains, even among those used sparingly. Squad members like Dummett and Jamaal Lascelles have been kept on precisely because their training standards remain high even without the guaranteed reward of first team football.
They will hope that dovetails with a “happy camp” policy that will see the club enter contract negotiations with almost all of their most prominent players over the next 12 months.

The first visible signs of progress on that front centre around Bruno Guimaraes, whose new deal is to be announced imminently. He played the first few weeks as if the ongoing negotiations were weighing heavily on his shoulders.

He is a player who needs to feel the love, which is why Newcastle’s decision to acquiesce to his team’s desire for a release clause in excess of £100m and agree a new long-term contract makes sense. The pay bump is reward for a player who has been a game changer at St James’ Park and as his mood has improved so too have his performances.

Against City his half-time introduction was a statement of intent that ended with an exclamation point as Newcastle followed the lead of their midfield talisman and became more aggressive and more assertive.

For all the debate about how long it will be until someone triggers that clause and takes him from Newcastle, it shouldn’t be forgotten that his current club have ambitions to win things. The sneaking suspicion of the hierarchy is that he feels such a connection he will stay as long as those goals remain attainable.

The “happy camp” approach of Newcastle’s owners is to marry smart recruitment with savvy retention of key players. Guimaraes had plenty of time left on his contract before entering contract talks but a pay rise is a reward for his contribution.

Next up for fresh terms is Joelinton, superb against City. Talks are said by insiders to be “progressing well”. And then in the next 12 months Newcastle are likely to start discussing extending Sven Botman’s contract as Paris Saint Germain and other heavyweights lurk.

title: Chelsea should be 4th, not 14th – Mauricio Pochettino just needs more time and more lemons
lead: Chelsea’s ‘expected points’ show things aren’t as bad as they seem, with Pochettino’s unusual methods starting to kick in
author: Sam Cunningham

body.text: No Premier League goals in 285 minutes. Defeat to  signalling their worst start to a league season in 45 years. Nine senior players out injured – currently the most of any side in the league. Two more suspended for the trip to Fulham on Monday.

The unwanted records, statistics, hard truths and problems are piling up on the desk in glass-walled office at  Cobham training ground, right next to thehe believes, if they are just given enough time, will soak up the bad energy and turn around his team’s fortunes.
But is it – just maybe – not as bad as it seems on the surface? Bear with me on this one.
The fundamental principle of co-owner and chairman  billion-pound project is signing the world’s best young players on long contracts so they can compete for trophies now and long into the future.

Boehly’s unprecedented wade into the transfer market has left Chelsea with the youngest squad in the Premier League – the average player age of 23.7 years old almost a year younger than next youngest Arsenal. And so many of their key players are, in footballing terms, practically children.

Their attack hinges on Nicolas Jackson, who only recently turned 22. With Reece James and Ben Chilwell injured, their captain against Aston Villa was Connor Gallagher, who is 23. Even when fit, captain James is also only 23.
, the £106m midfielder tasked with making the team tick, is 22. Back-up right-back Malo Gusto, sent off for a reckless and unnecessary challenge against Villa, is 20.
Levi Colwill is a potential England centre-back but is still only 20. Record £115m signing Moises Caicedo is 21.

It all requires a careful manager who can turn young, inexperienced players into trophy winners and Champions League regulars. That’s the idea, anyway. But if there’s a coach who can make this work, it’s Pochettino.
“It’s a difficult era for managing footballers,” Pochettino wrote in his 2017 book, Brave New World.
“These days you have to spell it all out for them if you want them to be comfortable, as if everything were plotted on a map.

“Managers nowadays are more like architects or highway engineers. You spend the day mapping out and reminding them of the journey because footballers’ concentration spans are shorter and shorter. The electronic gadgets surrounding us are to blame for the players constantly needing new sources of stimulation, so we have to aim for variety and try to keep their minds fresh.”

There’s a subtle but important distinction here between Pochettino’s perception of young players and the notion, believed by many in the older generations of managers, that young players can’t handle criticism and must be wrapped in cotton wool.

In Pochettino’s view, while players need everything carefully planned for them and enough fun and variation to keep them engaged, he will not hold back from being tough on them and has every confidence they can take it.

As one story goes, at  during the 2016 preseason, not long after they had challenged for the Premier League title and qualified for the Champions League, the players were caught out by one such bollocking. Everything had been going fine on a tour of Australia until Kyle Walker turned up late for a team meeting, and Pochettino lost it.

It is thought to have brought back memories of the way the players capitulated when the title was no longer attainable after that ferocious Battle of the Bridge draw with Chelsea. In the remaining two games they lost to Southampton and were thrashed away to Newcastle on the final day.

Pochettino felt Walker’s lapse time-keeping was indicative of a group of players who were letting their standards drop after working so hard. They had recently played a friendly against Atletico Madrid and Pochettino showed them a video clip of Fernando Torres chasing after the ball well into stoppage time.

Torres was a World Cup and Champions League winner in the twilight of his career and had been travelling for around 30 hours before the game but he kept running until the very end, Pochettino pointed out. And his side were winning!

Pochettino told his players they should be ashamed of themselves for the way they finished last season. And if his intention had been to continue driving them onwards, it worked. They finished in the top four for three more seasons, and reached the Champions League final.

Back at Chelsea, after Jackson was suspended for one game for an accumulation of needless yellow cards and Gusto was banned for three for a needless bad tackle, Pochettino told his players they need to grow up and take some responsibility.

Armando Broja is the only striker available to replace Jackson and he has played 14 minutes of football in 10 months, due to injury. Oh, and he’s just turned 22. There’s no obvious cover for Gusto and James.
These are trying times, but Pochettino’s methods have worked before and they will work again.

There are small signs in training. Such as with , who is slowly rebuilding confidence that has taken a battering. Pochettino and the young Ukrainian play games of crossbar challenge – seeing who can hit the crossbar from the edge of the box the most times – offering him some little wins, provided he earns them (Pochettino is quite good at it!).
And then there are the statistics that paint an entirely different picture to the one laid out at the beginning of this column.

This season Chelsea are seriously underperforming in their xG – the goals they should score based on their chances – and when the number gurus at Opta Analyst ran an Expected Points model this week it returned the verdict that Chelsea should be fourth, not 14th.
Maybe those lemons – and Chelsea’s manager – simply need a little bit more time.

title: UK house prices: Properties selling for £12,000 below asking price as market weakens
lead: The highest discounts are found in London and the South East, where the average discount to the asking price is now 4.8 per cent
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: Properties are  for £12,000 below their original asking price as buyers continue to benefit from a slump to  as the market weakens.
The average discount to the asking price is now 4.2 per cent, according to data published by the property website Zoopla. This rises to 4.8 per cent in London and the South East.

As a result of  and starting to fall, enquiries for people to view properties rose by 12 per cent in September compared with the previous month. This led to discounts reaching their highest level since March 2019.

While an increase after August, a time when many are on their summer holidays, is to be expected, agents  report that it remains a buyers’ market and home sellers have finally accepted the need to drop their prices. This has meant more buyers are happy to proceed. There are now 80 per cent more homes  for sale than in September 2021.

However, mortgage rates still remain high compared to two years ago when people could get rates for as low as 1 per cent. The average two-year fix is 6.53 per cent while the rate for a five-year one is 6.03 per cent, according to the analytics firm Moneyfacts.
Some experts believe that average rates will fall below 5 per cent within six to nine months, although some providers including Nationwide, HSBC and Santander,  all have rates below this already.
Zoopla added it expects the number of buyers to increase once mortgage rates get below 4.5 per cent.
Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, told i: “This is still a buyers’ market for the moment. It is no longer an environment where sellers can set a price knowing that  it will likely to be met.”
“The continues to adjust to a higher mortgage rate environment,” added Richard Donnell, executive director at Zoopla.
“Better news on and the end of increases has provided scope for lenders to start reducing mortgage rates which has supported a modest uptick in demand for homes this September.”

Home hunters also remain unwilling to make compromises on the size of home they are looking for, meaning they are waiting for either a fall in house prices or mortgage rates, even if this is not guaranteed to happen quickly.
Overall, the number of homes sold this year is set to be 20 per cent lower than in 2022, with 28 per cent fewer buyers around for those relying on a mortgage, Zoopla said.

Matt Thompson, head of sales at Chestertons, said: “Since the Bank of England’s announcement of interest rates remaining at 5.25 per cent for the time being, we have seen a positive response from buyers in September who felt more secure to make financial decisions and resume their property search.

“Understandably, buyers who are now entering the market are particularly careful about their budget and factor in any future rate hikes as well as the cost of living. As demand for properties in the capital continues to outstrip supply, the market remains competitive.”

title: How to buy a house for the best price: your guide to bagging a bargain in a buyers’ market
lead: There are several ways to get a discount on your property in the current market
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: Home hunters will be closely observing at the moment, as  for an average of £12,000 under asking price, amid a weakening .
The average discount to asking prices is 4.2 per cent, with to be up to 3 per cent lower over 2023, according to Zoopla.
Prices have already fallen by 5.9 per cent compared to the same time last year, according to Nationwide, the sharpest fall since 2009.

This has created a buyers’ market, providing more options to negotiate with sellers and get a hefty discount on the asking price. If you’re thinkingin the near future, read below to see how you can get a good deal.
Experts says that now is a good time to put a “cheeky offer” on a home you want to buy, to see if it is accepted.
“It has swapped to a buyers’ market at the moment,” said Aaron Strutt of Trinity Financial, adding that  are trying to “stimulate the market” by offering cheaper rates to first time buyers.
“Mortgage rates are  with more lenders offering below 5 per cent fixed rates, provided you have a larger deposit.”
Nationwide, HSBC and Santander are all lenders offering deals below 5 per cent.
Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, told  that buyers shouldn’t wait too long if they have found a suitable property.

“My advice to any first time buyer or prospective home owner is, if you see a property that meets your desires and is affordable, don’t try to second guess when the market is going to bottom out or when rates are going to hit rock bottom,” he said.
However, Mr Strutt said many first time buyers are still putting off getting onto the property ladder.

“Many suspect mortgages will be more affordable by then, and property prices may well be more stable. But property is supposed to be a long term investment, and as we have seen, prices will go up and down.”
No seller puts their property on the market expecting to get the asking price at the moment, experts say.
“It’s a way of testing the market, see how many viewings the property gets and test any opening bids,” Mr Mendes said.
The longer the property stays on the market, the higher the chance of negotiating for a price you’re more comfortable with.
If you notice that your dream property is listed with two estate agents, Mr Mendes says to speak to both of them to “gain as much information as possible”.
“This could provide you with the golden nugget to seal the deal.”
Furthermore, showing sellers you really want their property can also win them over, even if you ask for less than the asking price.

“Sellers want to ensure you are committed to the purchase, so being personable and selling an idea of why you will be perfect will go a long way. They could choose your offer over another prospective offer at a higher amount.”
It’s important to remember to see what needs to be done to the property, something not every homeowner does. This doesn’t come cheap so negotiating the price is highly recommended.

Mr Mendes added: “Take stock of all the work that needs to be done and potential costs and use it as part of the negotiation. What’s the worst that can happen? The seller says no to your price, but at least you have something to work from.”
House hunters are encouraged to take things into their own hands and being slightly different, as it may come with rewards.
For example, if there is a property on the street up for sale, don’t be afraid to write a leaflet with why you want to live on that street and post to neighbouring properties.
Mr Mendes said: “Estate agents do it with ‘we need more properties like yours for a prospective buyer’ leaflets.”
“This way, you get in there first and potentially get a better deal buying privately without the competition.”
That being said, while buyers will have room to negotiate in the current market, it’s still important to remember that not all properties will be up for debate.

For instance, it may be easier to bring down the price of a larger home compared to a one bedroom flat. Post pandemic, the “race for space” is on the decline, with estate agents seeing a decline in house hunters looking for larger properties with spacious gardens.
In prime locations, sellers may try to hold out for the best offers they can get, so haggling for lower prices might not work.
It’s important to think about what a property may be worth and if the price you have in mind is realistic.

title: Hidden mortgage fees mean homeowners could be paying more than ever despite rates falling
lead: Some homeowners could find they are paying more on their mortgage now than when rates were at their peak
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Mortgage holders could find themselves paying more now than whenhave been found to be upping their fees by as much as 60 per cent.
Some leading two-year fixed deals in July, proved to be cheaper than those currently on the market despite rates coming down, research by Which?, exclusive to i, reveals.
This is because providers are increasing their arrangement fee – also know as product fee – which most come with. They usually cost between £999 and £1,999 and are charged by lenders.
Now many providers are increasing these fees, offsetting mortgage rates coming down, with some charging nearly £3,000 – money which could
Skipton Building Society is the worst offender, charging £2,995 on its five-year deals for those with 10 per cent, 15 per cent and 25 per cent deposits.

Ele Clark, senior money editor at Which?, said: “While several lenders are reducing products’ headline rates, some have also hiked their arrangement fees, meaning that a number of borrowers could actually have secured a cheaper deal back in July, when mortgage rates were higher.
“The market is complicated for borrowers and choosing a new deal is not as straightforward as picking the cheapest rate – it’s vital to look at the overall cost.”

Which? compared the top 10 leading products available on 25 September with the top 10 deals available two months ago on 24 July across four different deposit brackets including 40, 25, 10 and 5 per cent deposits using Moneyfacts data.
Of the 40 leading products, 15 were fee-free in July. In contrast, on 25 September there were no fee-free products in the top 40.
The average fee for a product with a 40 per cent deposit was £718 in July, but this has now risen to £1,157 – an increase of 61 per cent.
Separate data from Moneyfacts found the average mortgage fee has risen for two consecutive months, increasing to £662 in September. This is the highest on its records since April 2021 (£663).
At the same time, average fixed rates dropped this month. Last month, the average two-year fixed rate was 6.85 per cent the highest since August 2008 when it reached 6.94 per cent.
Now the average five-year deal is under 6 per cent and the average two-year deal is 6.5 per cent.
Rachel Springall, finance expert at Moneyfacts, said: “Low-rate fixed mortgages can carry some of the highest fees, so they may not be the best choice for every borrower.”
So what does this mean for the cost of a mortgage? Which? compared the market-leading deal in September with the best fee-free deal from July, to find out the overall cost.
It crunched the numbers based on how much a homeowner would pay over a two-year fix on a £200,000 mortgage taken out over a 25-year term.

The analysis found that while borrowers who took out the best fee-free deal at a 40 or 25 per cent deposit in July would have been better off with September’s market-leading rates that are lower but come with a fee, the reverse is true for those with smaller deposits. It found that borrowers at 5 or 10 per cent deposit would have paid less in July, even though were higher.
So while interest rates on mortgage deals may have dropped, you need to check how the fee impacts what you pay back.
When searching for a mortgage deal, always look at the extra costs involved, these come under different guises, such as a product, arrangement or completion fee.

Banks commonly set fees between £999 and £1,999, but some use percentages instead – for example 0.5 per cent of the overall loan amount. If you’re borrowing a larger sum, this kind of fee can be significantly more expensive.
If you’re unsure about which type of deal to go for, a mortgage broker will be able to research deals based on their true cost, taking into account rates, fees and incentives such as cashback.

title: Should I fix my energy? How Ofgem’s new price cap change will affect bills as fixed deals return to the market
lead: As the price cap is due to change this week, some will be considering whether to fix their energy deal
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: The new comes into effect this week, dropping to
Millions will be affected by the change on October 1, with the cap falling by £151 from the current level of £2,074.
Under the cap, which limits the unit cost of  for those on variable tariffs, the unit costs will fall to 27p for electricity and 7p for gas.
As more providers start to introduce , many will be wondering if now is the best time to fix their energy bill?
i spoke to experts to find out.
The energy price cap is set by , the body that regulates energy suppliers in Great Britain. It limits the maximum amount energy suppliers can charge you for each unit of energy you use.
It was introduced in 2019 because there was a concern that people were paying too much for their energy. The price cap is currently reviewed every three months.

It was overridden by the Government’s energy price guarantee between 1 October last year until 30 June, 2023. This provided a support rate discount to all households with gas or electricity, bringing it down to around £2,500 per year.
However, since July the price cap is now the scheme limiting bills. It only applies to variable tariffs and not fixed ones.
Fixed deals, where you are tied in to a contract with your provider, used to be the cheapest way to pay for your energy.

Despite the reduction to the price cap being a positive move, are still much higher than they were just a couple of years ago when people could get a fixed deal for an average of £800 a year, if not less.
They are now returning to the market as prices begin to decrease, with some now available below the price cap. Most are fixed for a year or more.
Whether you should fix your energy deal will depend on what sort of deal you can get and whether you are willing to risk energy prices going up or down again.
If you are looking for certainty, a fixed deal could work for you. However, it will probably only make sense if you are guaranteed to pay less than your supplier’s default tariff.
Currently, there are 10 providers offering fixed deals, however, many come with caveats.
For example, several are for existing customers only, such as Octopus Energy’s Loyal Octopus fixed deal.

Others like Utility Warehouse’s Fixed Saver 6 deal requires customers to sign up to two other products with the firm, like broadband. This is also the only one below the new price cap at £1,873 on average.
However, it is probable that more deals will become available after the new cap comes into effect.

Natalie Mathie, energy expert at Uswitch.com, said: “Only those on fixed tariffs have the certainty of knowing what they will pay for the full term of their deal, which is usually a year. During that time, customers on variable tariffs will see their bills change four times.

“A reasonably priced fixed deal could be a good option for households who want certainty over what they will pay. However, as the energy market remains volatile, it can be difficult to predict whether opting for a fixed deal or sticking with a variable will save you money in the long run.”
For those thinking of switching to a fixed deal, experts are warning people to pay attention to any exit fees, which could cost up to £200 per fuel.

Ms Mathie added: “The price you are quoted to pay through direct debit each month is an estimate based on your predicted usage and may not end up being the actual cost over the whole year. Remember, if you use more energy, you’ll pay more.
“Make sure you look at the unit price and standing charge so you can understand how much you will pay for your energy usage and how it differs from what you are currently charged.”

title: How much the children of the UK’s super rich inherit – and how little they pay in inheritance tax
lead: Analysis by the IFS shows that the wealthiest 1 per cent of the population would see almost half of the financial benefit if Inheritance Tax (IHT) was abolished.
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Children of the wealthiest fifth will receive £380,000 next year in inheritance next year – with just 10 per cent of this paid in, according to figures from a leading think-tank.
Figures from the Institute for Fiscal Studies illustrate the differences in the amounts of money passed down through generations, with the least wealthy fifth of  leaving less than £2,000 per child.
Analysis by the IFS shows that the  of the population would see almost half of the financial benefit if Inheritance Tax (IHT) was abolished.

The think-tank said the cost of abolishing the  would be around £7 billion, and 47 per cent of the savings would go to those with £2.1 million or more in assets – representing the top 1 per cent of estates.
The calculations show that the vast  – around 90 per cent – would see no benefit if the tax were to go.
According to reports last weekend,  are currently drawing up plans to cut, and potentially even scrap, Inheritance Tax.
And the IFS’s report, Reforming, says that scrapping the policy would come with cost that “grows over time.”
In a decade’s time, it says getting rid of the tax would cost the Treasury around £15 billion.

The most recent HMRC statistics show less than 4 per cent of estates paid inheritance tax in 2020–21, but the rapid  among older individuals means this number is set to rise to over 7 per cent by 2032–33, according to the IFS.
And the number of people affected by the tax will be still larger, with one in eight people (12 per cent) will have inheritance tax due either on their death or their partner’s death by 2032–33.
The report has argued that if it retained, IHT should be reformed.
It has said reforms that remove poorly justified reliefs could raise up to £4.5 billion.

David Sturrock, a senior research economist at IFS, said: “There are reasonable arguments for and against an inheritance tax. But as inheritances grow in size, it’s increasingly important that we address problems in the current system.

“The government should abolish the special treatment given to business assets, certain types of shares, agricultural assets, pensions and homes passed to direct descendants. These exemptions and reliefs open up channels to avoid inheritance tax,” he added.
“This is costly, unfair and distorts economic decisions. Reforming them could raise as much as £4.5 billion in additional revenue,” he said.
There is a large regional variation in the number of people that pay the tax.
In London, around 23 per cent of people (or their surviving spouse or civil partner) will pay inheritance tax, almost twice the national average and five times higher than in the North East.

title: Number of first-time buyers falls by a fifth as UK mortgage rates remain high
lead: Challenges in the housing market have presented obstacles for many first time buyers in recent months
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: The number of  fell by more than a fifth this year, as the rise in mortgage rates has made getting on the property ladder less affordable.

Although first-time buyers still accounted for more than half of all home loans, this was down by 22 per cent between January and August this year when compared to the same period in 2022, according to Halifax.
Challenges in the , from increases in mortgage rates to periods of lower availability of mortgage deals, have presented obstacles for many first time buyers in recent months.

Nick Mendes of brokers, John Charcol, said: “First time buyers have been affected by affordability constraints. Lenders have had to take into account higher rates and an increase in household expenditure.”

Despite house prices falling in recent times with some experts still predicting drops of as much as 15 per cent from their peak, the average price of the first home is now £288,030, down by just 2 per cent in the past year.
Experts say there hasn’t been a drop in first time buyer activity like this since early 2020, after the pandemic hit.
Mendes said: “The last time we saw first time buyers transactions fall would be around the  period.
“We saw many first time buyers, those early in their careers or those who have recently started a new job, worried about their job security and as a result put on hold plans to take on a mortgage.”
Many are in the same boat now, due to the ongoing cost of living crisis, with inflation a barrier when it comes to  – an already difficult challenge of house ownership. The needed is now £54,116.

“The average age of those buying their first property is now 32, rising by two years over the past decade, most likely reflecting that increasing costs are making the road to home ownership longer,” said Kim Kinnaird, Director at Halifax Mortgages.
“When people are ready to , most are doing so in joint names which helps both in terms of costs and affordability.”
According to Kinnaird, “expected” falls in house prices and “stronger income growth” may offset in the future.
Currently, the house price to income ratio for first time buyers has fallen from 5.8 in June last year, to 5.1 currently.
According to Mendes, the figures reflect the  for the past 12 months, which included “fluctuations in rates and short periods when markets have settled.”
“Property prices have gradually decreased but are still significantly higher from where they were 24 months ago,” he told i.

Regionally, the South East – which has the second most expensive average property prices in the UK – had the biggest decline in the number of people buying a first home between January and August this year, at 25 per cent.
London and East Anglia had the second biggest decline in first-time buyers entering the property market so far this year, down 24 per cent.

title: Interest rates to stay high, but predictably so: welcome to the new normal for our finances
lead: Andrew Bailey votes to pause on rate rises, but leaves wiggle room to increase in the future
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: On Thursday we saw something happen last seen in November 2021: the Bank of England opted not to increase the base rate.

The effect in the press room at the Bank of England, where journalists got early sight of the decision, was immediate. There was a ripple of excitement and intakes of breath. Nothing was happening, but this was the best and most exciting nothing we’ve seen for close to two years.

and his colleagues at the Bank left lots of wiggle room to increase rates in the future if necessary – the Governor of the Bank of England repeatedly stated he was not being “complacent” to reassure the markets.
But he will be aware the message he’s sending: that the fastest period of increases to interest rates in modern times is likely to be coming to an end.
This is good news. It means we are moving from a period of uncertainty and financial shocks to a future where rates are likely to be more stable.
But let’s not get out the bunting just yet: mortgage rates won’t go down dramatically, they will just remain predictably high.

The markets are now predicting the base rate to average just above 5 per cent for the next three years, and the GDP data for the second and third quarter of this years show us uncomfortably close to a technical recession, another reason the Bank may not want to have pushed things too far on Thursday.

It will be some time before we get to the next stage of recovery, when the . Inflation is not expected to return to 2 per cent next year, and rates aren’t likely going to go down significantly before the middle of 2024.

So what are the key messages from today? That people with variable mortgages can breathe a small sight of relief that their repayments won’t go up too much higher in the near future and those on fixed rates can assume a rate of 5 per cent (ish) for the next three years or so.

Savers should fix a good rate now ad feel able to tie up their money for several years, if they haven’t already, knowing that rates won’t get much better. Anyone holding off getting a pension annuity can now commit for the same reasons.

Ultimately, while Thursday’s news isn’t a celebration, many people can take a small degree of comfort from knowing that it’s going to be easier to plan our finances. We’re not living with shifting financial sands any longer.

title: Stamp duty should be scrapped and ‘gums up’ housing market, says senior economics expert at IFS
lead: Economics expert Helen Miller says the tax on house purchases means ‘young families struggle to trade up, and older people hold onto bigger properties than they need’
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: The deputy director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies has called for  to be axed.
, Helen Miller said it “imposes a heavier tax charge on properties that change hands more often” and “there is no good reason to do this”.

Ms Miller, head of tax for the independent and respected economics think tank, added: “It gums up the housing market, meaning people find it harder to move to where the jobs are, young families struggle to trade up, and older people hold onto bigger properties than they need, because it costs so much to move… stamp duty should simply be scrapped.”

Buyers paid £15.4bn in stamp duty over the tax year 2022-2023. Currently, it is paid on increasing portions of the property price when you buy a residential property. In England, the tax only applies to homes over £250,000, above which the buyer pays up to 12 per cent.

In Scotland, there is no Land and Buildings Transaction Tax – the equivalent of stamp duty – on the first £145,000 above which buyers are taxed up to 12 per cent, and in Wales, the Land Transaction Tax is triggered at £225,000 and also goes up to 12 per cent.
Earlier in the summer, another think tank, the Resolution Foundation, called on the Government to reduce stamp duty by 50 per cent to boost the country’s productivity.

The foundation proposed cancelling the 2025 rise in stamp duty, and halving rates for main homes and non-residential properties, at a total cost of £5bn. It said this would make it cheaper for people to move jobs and homes while helping firms grow and move premises.

Ms Miller’s comments came as the IFS called for the tax system to be reformed more broadly. A report by the institute found that tax revenue is now 37 per cent of national income –– and rising, and that taxes will have to go higher in the coming decades to fund health and social care costs for an ageing population, as well as costs associated with climate change.

The report also looked into how the tax system encouraged people into , and how wealth “tends to be undertaxed relative to labour income… and in some cases – including the gains made on main homes – completely untaxed.”
This combined, with high marginal tax rates caused by “humps” in income, reduce the incentive to work, or change how people work, which creates “an unnecessary drag on productivity”.
Ms Miller also wrote that inheritance tax is currently “easily avoided by the healthy, wealthy and well advised”.

title: ‘At 62, I’ve fallen in love with my job again after going part-time, now I’ll work into my 80s’
lead: New figures reveal record numbers of people in their fifties and older are now in part-time work
author: Aasma Day

body.text: A tutor who cut her hours to work part-time says the move has rekindled her passion for work so much she never wants to , as figures reveal record numbers of people aged 50 and older are working part-time in the UK.

New data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) shows that 3.6 million  are working part-time in the UK. This is a record high and a 12 per cent increase since 2021. It also represents a 26 per cent increase in the past decade and a 56 per cent increase in the past two decades.

Sue Dinnage, 62, who lives in Gorseinon, Wales told i that changing to working part-time from full-time has completely changed her outlook on work and it is now such a pleasure rather than a necessity, she “never wants to .”
Ms Dinnage, who is married to Keith and has a son and a step-son, spent 15 years working in the education sector in different roles, most recently as a higher level teaching assistant.
A few years ago, the family relocated back to Wales from South East England with no jobs and Ms Dinnage planned to set up a private online tutoring business.

She says she has now built up a busy practice tutoring English and maths with 20 students and a waiting list and reveals she now earns more money working part-time as a tutor than she ever did in her full-time role in schools.
Ms Dinnage, whose husband is also working part-time in retail, tells i becoming a part-time tutor has totally transformed her perspective on work and .
“I love working in education, but working in a school brings with it all sorts of stresses which are not there when you’re tutoring on a one-to-one basis.

“When me and my husband were both working full-time, we felt we were working flat-out and our weekends were devoted to jobs and all the boring and necessary things and lo and behold, it would be Sunday evening and Monday morning again.
“But now I enjoy my work so much and moving to part-time work has given me so much more time for other things, that I never want to retire and want tutoring to be a part of my life forever.
“Many people can’t wait to retire because they don’t particularly enjoy what they are doing and it is a drudge.
“However, I love what I do so much that I don’t ever want to retire. If the children would be happy to have an 85-year-old tutor teaching them, I would willingly do it until that age and beyond.”
She added: “The word ‘retire’ is like a dirty word in our house as my husband also loves working part-time and the flexible nature of it.”

Ms Dinnage explained that moving to part-time working has allowed her to look after her elderly parents, including visiting her mother who is in a care home. It has also given her more opportunities to socialise with friends and pursue interests such as joining a book club.

She and her husband also have a dog now – something she says they could never have done while they were both working full-time. As well as having time for dog walks, as she and her husband both work part-time hours, they even have time to enjoy the occasional lunch together.

“Life has never been better and I can’t even bring myself to call what I do a job, because it has become such a part of me,” she said. “I never have the Sunday night blues and work feels so much more rewarding and I’m not bogged down with all the form filling and data collection that runs alongside with working in a huge secondary school.
“A job used to be more of a necessity than a pleasure, but now that has completely changed. Working is still a necessity in terms of that we do have to earn that income.
“But if you’re earning it and enjoying it at the same time, then it is the best of all worlds.”
The new data from the ONS about the record number of older people in their fifties and older are in part-time work was analysed by Rest Less, a digital community and advocate for those aged over 50.

It found that 42 per cent of the UK’s part-time workers are aged over 50 and that at least 40 per cent of workers aged 60 to 64 are part-time and 66 per cent of workers aged over 65 are working part-time. The is 66.
Stuart Lewis, chief executive of , told i there are positive and negative reasons behind the shift in work and retirement among the over-50s.
“On the one hand, it is a positive thing as more and more people are reframing their relationship with retirement,” he said.
“There is a growing body of evidence to show that working for four or five decades before suddenly retiring cold turkey is actually bad for people’s health and wellbeing.

“So it is a positive that more people are choosing to glide into retirement with this transition period of working part-time where they might be looking for a bit more flexibility for life around work, rather than ‘nothingness’.
“However, on the more negative side behind this, there are concerns some people may be working part-time when they are older, .”

Mr Lewis explained that the reasons behind this include that many people in their fifties and sixties are the “”, where they have responsibilities caring for their elderly parents in their eighties and nineties, while maybe also having dependents at home with their own children and grandchildren.

He says other reasons include more people working part-time for health reasons and fitting around medical appointments and treatment and people needing to work part-time due to and struggling to rely on the .
“There are also people who cannot find permanent or meaningful work due to age discrimination, which is still very widespread,” he added.
“There is great inequality when it comes to in this country.”

title: ‘I’ve opted out of saving into my pension – even though I will end up regretting it when I hit 60’
lead: Cutting back on your pension contributions can leave you with less money in retirement – though many opt-out to have extra cash up front
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Inflation may be going down – and interest rates paused – but this doesn’t mean people’s financial worries are over.
Among the more dramatic solutions to make ends meet is to pause or stop pension contributions altogether, something on the increase.

Some 51 per cent of employers said employees have requested to cut pension contributions, and 47 per cent have seen them ask to halt contributions altogether, according to LCP’s 2023 Financial Wellbeing study.
Jennifer Page is one such person who has currently opted out of the  that her employer, a teaching supply agency, opts staff into, but knows she will likely end up regretting this in the future.
The 40-year-old primary school teacher, who lives in Birmingham, has  twice in the past three years and says she did so “for purely financial reasons” both times.
In 2020, she retrained to work in schools after a career in sales, but by doing so, her salary halved.
“I pretty much budgeted to the narrowest of narrow margins.  – it was only a small amount but I just couldn’t stretch that far,” she says.
She  of her scheme in the second year after her career switch.

“My salary went up a bit and I could have just about afforded it, but my had been so depleted and I needed money for things like Christmas and buying birthday presents. I needed a year to get that breathing space,” she explains.

She then chose to opt in again but has since pulled out once more after leaving her full-time teaching post – where she was eligible for the generous Teachers Pension Scheme – and becoming a supply worker for an agency.
“I know I may need it and I know when I get into my sixties you’ll possibly regret it, but it’s an awful dilemma to have,” she says.
“I know it’s for and that’s the whole point, but it’s difficult to tie up money knowing you can’t get it for 20 years or so.”
Under UK law, if you’re employed, your employer must automatically enrol you into a pension scheme and make contributions to it if you are over 22 and earn £10,000 or more per year.
They must contribute at least 3 per cent, with the total minimum contribution being 8 per cent – and people who pay income tax also get tax relief on the money.
The tax relief and the money from your employer are clearly a boon – especially as research suggests you need a £23,300 per year income to live a “moderate” lifestyle in retirement.
But in the current financial climate, Jen is not alone.
According to recent research from Hargreaves Lansdown, more than one in five people have stopped or cut back pension contributions as a result of the .
Men were also more likely to have made changes, with 25 per cent reducing or halting contributions, compared to 18 per cent of women.
Chris Brooker, 47, from Bristol is another who is opting to forgo his pension.

The dad-of-three became  in 2016, running a smart technology business as a sole trade. Self-employed people get the same tax advantages that an employed person would, including 20 per cent relief added to the pension pot, and the ability to claim extra tax relief as a higher-rate taxpayer.
But Chris has chosen not to take advantage of this.
“I paid into a pension straight way from the age of 21, as my first job was as a computer programmer for a pensions software company, and paid into various pots after this,” he says.

“I know that currently with the money I have, I actually don’t have quite enough to live off, but with what I do have, hopefully having the mortgage paid off and more, I’d have options. And my money is actually outperforming my wife’s, even though she’s been paying in to a pot for years,” he adds.
Chris says at the moment, he would not pay into a pension until he was making enough to be a high-rate tax payer, and got extra relief on contributions.

“If I had spare money, and the choice was to put it into a pension, spend it, or put it into another form of like , I would say putting it into a pension would probably be last on my list. If I invest it in an Isa, then if I suddenly need it – if I have a couple of hard years, if the car blows up – I’ve got that money, whereas a pension is very inflexible.
“Especially without having the extra tax relief, I’d rather keep some of the money or invest it in my business or use it for my family,” he says.

In the past two years, a third of all workers have looked into reducing or stopping their pension contributions according to research from Royal London – and this rises to 49 per cent of workers aged 18-34.
But although stopping paying into a pension can bump up your annual salary, it can also cost you significantly in the long-term.

A worker on £35,000 paying 5 per cent of their wage into a pension would boost their take-home pay by £1,404 per year, but would lose out on £4,092 per year in pension savings, as a result of losing money from their employer – if they matched their contributions – and tax relief, according to Royal London.
Becky O’Connor, director of public affairs at PensionBee, said that while cutting pension contributions was “understandable” for many, the consequences should be weighed up.

“Life moves quickly, and before you know it, you might’ve kicked the can too far down the road and end up needing to give up work without having enough to fall back on to even cover basic living costs,” she said.

“If you are also likely to have housing costs when you hit retirement age, you’ll need even more in your pension pot to cover them – something for people who expect to be paying rent or a mortgage into their sixties to consider.

“Before giving up pension contributions, make sure you’ve cut out any excess spending. If you have no choice and just need to do it, keep things under review and reintroduce pension saving when you can. Your future self will thank you for it.”

Most people pay their pensions into a ‘defined contribution’ scheme, whereby their money goes into a savings pot, and grows over time as it is invested. Therefore, the more you save earlier, the more your pot could grow.

In 20 years’ time the £4,092 a year someone would lose through opting out of their workplace pension could have boosted the pension pot by £10,575 through investment growth had the contributions not been paused.

title: Climate change ‘dithering’ sparks fuel inflation and costs UK more, Bank of England adviser warns
lead: Adviser said there is “a lot of work that we really need to do” on climate change.
author: David Connett

body.text: Bank of England warned that uncertainty around environmental policy was likely to increase the volatility of inflation in Britain.
She made her comments after the Prime Minister, last week, including banning the sale of new petrol cars.
Ms Greene said there is “a lot of work that we really need to do” on climate change.
“The macro impacts are possibly huge, but the biggest impact really is that this amounts to a pretty significant supply shock,” she said, adding that needed to hit net zero.

The full impact of climate change depends on “how long we dither before we really get to address this”.Inflation is likely to be more volatile in the future than in past years, she warned, when low and stable inflation was the norm.
“A lot of it . It’s not our job to set policy, central banks aren’t the best actors to set policy,” Ms Greene told a conference in Sweden about the economics of climate change.

“But insofar as all the actors in the economy aren’t sure what the policy is going forward, the more inflation volatility there might be. So I agree there probably will be volatility around our 2 per cent target [for inflation],” she said.
Her comments came as it was revealed that up to one in five new cars on Britain’s roads could still be petrol and diesel models in 2030.
The figure was disclosed in government  by its new extended deadline of 2035.
Under the terms of the revised zero-emissions mandate published by transport officials, 22 per cent of new cars will have to be zero-emission from January next year.
Mr Sunak announced a five-year delay to the ban on new petrol and diesel cars and vans earlier this month, calling it a “pragmatic” approach to achieving the UK’s net-zero goals.
There will not be a total ban on owning a petrol or diesel car after 2035 and experts said there are likely to be millions still on the road for a long time afterwards.
Transport Secretary Mark Harper said: “The path to zero-emission vehicles announced makes sure the route to get there is proportionate, pragmatic and realistic.”
The Department for Transport said carmakers that fail to meet thresholds will be able to make use of “flexibilities” in the scheme, particularly during the first three years.
Car maker Ford, which slammed the Prime Minister’s delay warning that it undermined confidence in British industry, welcomed the latest guidelines.
Mike Hawes, chief executive of the industry lobby group, , said: “With less than 100 days to go, manufacturers finally have clarity on what they are required to sell next year and up to 2030.”

title: Government threatened with legal action after North Sea oil field go-ahead sparks green fury
lead: Greenpeace said approval of the Rosebank North Sea oil and gas field will give ‘carte blanche to fossil fuel companies to ruin the climate’
author: David Connett

body.text: The Government has been threatened with the prospect of a legal challenge over the decision to approve development of the Rosebank North Sea oil and gas field.
The said Rosebank, one of the largest untapped fields in the North Sea, could be developed. It is expected to produce 500 million barrels of oil in its lifetime.

But the move has been attacked by environmental groups, reigniting the debate around Britain’s climate change strategy after Rishi Sunak last week watered down the country’s interim plans to hit the 2050 net-zero target.

Tessa Khan of , called it a “rip-off”, adding: “It’s another case of the Government allowing foreign companies to profit, while the costs are put on British people who worry about the world we are handing on to our children.

“Rosebank will do nothing to lower fuel bills or boost UK energy security. Most of this oil will be shipped abroad and then sold back to use at whatever price makes the oil and gas industry the most profit.
“There are strong grounds to believe that the way this Government has come to this decision is unlawful and we will see them in court if so.”
Green MP  called it “the greatest act of environmental vandalism in my lifetime.”

She tweeted: “Rosebank oilfield just given go-ahead – the greatest act of environmental vandalism in my lifetime, causing emissions equal to 28 lowest income countries, busting climate targets & doing nothing for energy security since vast majority is for export. #climatecriminals.”
Phil Richards of Greenpeace UK said the decision amounted to “carte blanche to fossil fuel companies to ruin the climate”.

Last month 50 cross-party MPs and members of the House of Lords urged ministers to block Rosebank, warning that it could produce 200m tonnes of carbon dioxide. They claimed that most of the cost would fall on UK taxpayers.
The decision allows Norwegian oil and gas firm Equinor and its UK partner Ithaca Energy to begin drilling at the field, which lies north-west of Shetland. It  from environmental groups.

Energy Security Secretary Claire Coutinho welcomed the decision, saying that the regulator, the North Sea Transition Authority (NSTA), had given approval after “extensive scrutiny, including undergoing a detailed environmental impact assessment process and a period of public consultation.

“We are investing on our world-leading renewable energy but, as the independent Climate Change Committee recognises, we will need oil and gas as part of that mix on the path to net zero and so it makes sense to use our own supplies from North Sea fields such as Rosebank.
“The jobs and billions of pounds this is worth to our economy will enable us to have greater energy independence, making us more secure against tyrants like [Vladimir] Putin.
“We will continue to back the UK’s oil and gas industry to underpin our energy security, grow our economy and help us deliver the transition to cheaper, cleaner energy.”
The  in Britain, supporting up to 1,600 jobs during construction. First production is expected in 2026-27.

It said new projects like Rosebank are expected to be significantly less emissions intensive than previous developments, as they are more efficient and are developed with measures to mitigate emissions.

It added: “Even when we’ve reached net zero in 2050, the Climate Change Committee says that a quarter of our energy needs will come from oil and gas, but the choice is between it coming from hostile states rather than from the supplies we have here at home.”

title: Paul Lewis: The mortgage shock is now over, but the Bank of England can’t take any credit
lead: Homeowners faced a tough choice between fixing at a high rate or risking staying on a variable rate in the hopes fixed deals came down
author: Paul Lewis

body.text: The UK economy – worth £2.5 trillion a year – is a complex thing. So why does the Bank of England have just one lever to try to keep it on a steady course? Economy growing too fast and inflation too high?  more expensive and business investment and shopping slow down. Economy too slow and  Pull it back to cut interest rates to encourage borrowing so businesses invest and consumers hit Amazon Street. One lever.

Trouble is, at the moment we have neither combination. The economy is growing very slowly if at all and inflation is far too high. Even after this week’s slightly better than expected inflation rate it is still more than three times the 2 per cent target given to the Bank by the Government. A combination of a stagnant economy and high inflation is known as stagflation. So what do the nine members of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) do with their one lever apart from jiggle it about and hope for the best?

In 2009, faced with a global financial crisis created by the banks mis-selling billions of pounds worth of rubbish investments that could not perform as promised, the Bank installed a new lever. It had already decided the Bank Rate of 0.5 per cent was already as low as it could go (though it was cut further later) so it needed a new one that would have the same effect as cutting interest rates.

It was called by the unpronounceable and unspellable name of quantitative easing, or QE for short. It magicked up money out of thin electrons and guess what? The computer said we had loads more cash than it thought, so the Bank used it to buy back government bonds which businesses and others had invested in. That gave them loads of money – which it had just created from nothing – hoping it would encourage investment and growth.

Quantitative Easing created £895,000,000,000 new money out of nothing. And guess what? This digital version of printing money did what the paper variety has done in every banana republic in the last two hundred years – inflation shot up. So after voting to sit on its hands and do nothing for 128 out of 133 meetings from April 2009 to November 2021 the MPC swung into action and over the next fourteen meetings pushed forward that interest rate lever by 21 notches and watched as inflation slowly fell from its 11.1 per cent peak to 6.7 per cent in August.
Which is still more than three times the somewhat arbitrary target set by government and still too high to fulfil the Prime Minister’s pledge to ‘halve inflation’ by the end of the year.
This month the MPC decided slightly better than expected inflation in August merited a pause in its lever pushing.

The Bank’s Chief Economist Huw Pill – a key member of the MPC – made clear recently he preferred a plateau rather than a series of peaks and valleys. So get used to rates at this level. My spreadsheet of the bank rate every day shows it is now close to the average of 5.56 per cent for the century from 1900 to 2008 and lower than the average of just over 6 per cent from now back to 1950 and 1975.

Taking a longer view, since the Bank of England was founded in 1694 charging 6 per cent, e (under various names) for those 120,133 days is 4.65 per cent. So even when rates fall – which won’t be soon – don’t expect them to plummet. I have said before this is not the new normal it is the old normal after the brief anomalous period of 13 years which followed the banking crisis of 2008.

The last fourteen meetings of the MPC have been painful. by month tens of thousands came to the end of their over-sold 1 per cent loans with no adequate warning those rates couldn’t last. They faced Hobson’s choice of another fix at well over 5 per cent or a standard variable rate above 8 per cent as they realised rather too late they had been encouraged to borrow too much.

As a result their other spending was certainly cut back – just what the Bank wanted from all this pain. Others, many without mortgages, faced with the grim reality of food bills shooting up every time they shopped, started rationing themselves so their kids could eat and borrowing on their credit card for day-to-day expenses. The banks cashed in by raising credit card interest rates to what MoneyFacts says is now an average 31.8 per cent – in other words £6 a week for a revolving debt of £1,000 and not a penny repaid.

But the good news is that because of today’s decision mortgage lenders now see a plateau rather than a mountain ahead and are easing down lending rates as competition brings back a degree of choice in the market and some certainty of where rates will stay. In other words the mortgage shock is over. But the mortgage reality of over 5 per cent for a fix and 8 per cent for a variable mortgage is still very different to the reality for a whole generation brought up on silly rates that could never be sustained.

title: Want to avoid paying inheritance tax? Nigel Farage’s company has published a guide
lead: After stepping away from politics, the former MEP started giving financial tips
author: Laurie Havelock
