title: Government’s first Investment Zone in Sheffield will create thousands of jobs, experts say
lead: South Yorkshire will be the first area to benefit from a scaled-back version of the Liz Truss policy
author: Steve Robson

body.text: The Government’s first Investment Zone will support a new research facility in Sheffield that is hoped will reduce the aviation industry’s carbon footprint and generate a £2bn industry.
Investment Zones were first announced by Liz Truss’ short-lived Government as a way of boosting economic growth in deprived areas and 38 local authorities were invited to bid for funding.
Earlier this year, Chancellor Jeremy Hunt , primarily around elite universities, which will benefit from £80m in funding and tax incentives to become research and development hubs.
Today the University of Sheffield confirmed it will be the first area in the country to receive support to further develop ground-breaking aerospace technology.
The aviation industry is estimated to need 40,000 new passenger jets over the next 20 years but is only on track to deliver around 12,000.
Engineers at the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC) have made a technological breakthrough which can reduce the manufacturing time of major components by up to 90 per cent.
It also means the components – such as parts of the wing and fuselage – are lighter and more aerodynamic making planes more fuel efficient.
The process has been achieved thanks to state-of-the-art robot automation which is now able to build to an accuracy of 0.1 milimetres.
The technology is already being used by elite car manufacturer McLaren on its chassis but could prove crucial for the future of the aviation industry as it transitions to greener fuels.
US giant Boeing will be the first partner for the research programme amid hopes it will help meet global demand.
Steve Foxley, chief executive of AMRC, told i: “Because we’ve got robotic experience elsewhere in the sector, we’ve been able to push robots beyond the boundaries of their current performance.
“It’s a game-changing improvement.”
The new project Composites at Speed and Scale (Compass) will be built as an extension one of AMRC’s Factory 2050 and one of the North of England’s largest ever research and innovation projects.
It will initially create around 50 jobs in South Yorkshire, but university bosses and the government believe it has the potential to create 3,000 jobs by the mid 2030s.
Mr Foxley hailed the support for the new facility as “fantastic” for Sheffield’s manufacturing sector.
“Manufacturing has been decimated in the past 30 or 40 years but we saw in Covid how critical it still is in the UK,” he added.
“There’s been a big push for reshoring and green shoring, this is really important for Sheffield.”
Boeing opened its first manufacturing plant in Europe in Sheffield in 2018 and the US company says the new facility will boost the potential for further growth.
Maria Laine, President of Boeing UK, Ireland and Nordic region, said: “This project is a testament to Boeing’s commitment to drive innovation and growth within the UK aerospace sector.
“Together with our world-leading industry partners, this investment is poised to revolutionise aerospace manufacturing to meet global demand, while supporting vital jobs and growth in the UK.”
Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt: “Our first Investment Zone is a shining example of how we will drive growth across the country.
“It’s already secured more than £80m of private investment, including backing from Boeing, and will help support more than 8,000 jobs by 2030.”

Secretary of State for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities Michael Gove said: “Today’s announcement is a significant moment for South Yorkshire as it becomes the home of England’s first advanced manufacturing Investment Zone. This will help level up the region, creating jobs and boosting economic growth.

“We want to build on South Yorkshire’s proud heritage so that it can make an even greater contribution to the UK economy. This is what levelling up is all about, promoting growth and providing opportunities so people can thrive in the communities they are from.”

title: ‘I’m putting the brakes on’: How rising interest rates have hammered small businesses
lead: Rates going up has ‘massively slowed down growth’, a business owner told i
author: Callum Mason

body.text: “I’ve had to be more cautious. If we weren’t in this situation, I’d have more confidence on bringing in an extra person but at the moment I’m putting the brakes on that.”

These are the thoughts of Hannah Viney, the founder of Sycamore Communications, who has said she has had to be more measured with her company’s growth in recent times following successive interest rate increases.

Ms Viney, who founded her firm five years ago just before the Covid pandemic, said there is “much less risking taking” now than there would have been in previous years. “I wouldn’t take out a loan to take a punt on investment now because it’d be so expensive,” she added.
She is just one of  grappling with the .

The interest rate determines the amount that banks are charged for borrowing from the Bank of England, and although most consumers see the effects of this in the form of higher mortgage costs, loans – including those offered to businesses and households – there is another knock-on effect.

“Small business confidence stalled significantly between the first and second quarters of the year, and interest rate rises are undoubtedly an important factor behind the fall,” explained Martin McTague, National Chair of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB).
Viney’s business is now a six-figure company and has around 20 clients but admits she doesn’t want to make risky moves.

“The mortgage has gone up, so instead of pushing on, I’ve had to be more cautious. Cashflow is a concern because other clients are struggling financially, so there’s definitely a shift in mindset,” she added.
“I’m tentative in pushing on in terms of extra investment – that means putting off extra training for example as well.”

Interest rates are upped to bring down inflation, which  – far above the target rate of 2 per cent. The logic being that by increasing the cost of borrowing, spending is generally decreased, and thus price rises slow down as demand for goods fall.

But the downside of that, as well as decreasing people’s ability to buy, businesses themselves find it more expensive to get finance, meaning they often have to curtail creating new jobs, or new ventures.

“Low-cost finance for small firms has almost entirely disappeared,” explained Mr McTague. “It’s therefore sadly not surprising that some small firms have had to scale down or even shelved growth plans.”
Kamran Saleem, who runs a motoring business in the West Midlands, is having to change his plans.
The 41-year-old employs more than 30 staff at Motorserv-uk, a car service centre that also deals in used vehicles.
“We’re thinking about U-turning on the sales part of our business. It’s just not feasible anymore,” he said.

“Around 80 per cent of our cars are sold on finance, but headline rates [on finance loans] have gone up by 4 percentage points in the last year or so, so we’ve had an absolutely massive drop-off in purchases. It’s massively slowing down growth”, he told i.
Nick Staab, an entrepreneur and founder of the Elite Sales Academy, which works with businesses’ staff to improve their sales, has said the rising rates will have a big impact on new ventures.
“A lot of people are waiting for rates to come down and things to improve, meaning they have great ideas that they can’t get out there because they can’t get the finance,” he explained.
This cautiousness among firms is likely to curtail economic growth.

Stats released on Friday morning shows that the economy grew by just 0.2 per cent in the second quarter of the year, and although experts have said a recession – two quarters of successive negative growth – are likely to be avoided, a leading think-tank has highlighted that this means the period has been the .
Periods of low growth typically mean  and possibly lower wages as less jobs are created and retained.
So what should happen to rates? Mr Staab has said he recognises that inflation needs to come down, as this a “challenge,” to businesses too in terms of the increased costs it poses.
Mr Saleem has said that he now thinks interest rates need to come down though.
“I’d really want to see lower interest rates – inflation is coming down already and a lot of people are at breaking point in terms of mortgages,” he explained.

He has said he wants to see tax breaks for small businesses as well. The FSB has specific demands: increasing the VAT threshold to £100,000, tackling late payment to get cash moving through supply chains, and taking more small firms out of paying business rates would “all provide immediate relief to hard-pressed small businesses who feel hemmed in on all sides by costs,” it has said.

A spokesperson for HM Treasury said: “We’re committed to boosting the growth of small businesses, which is why we have supported them throughout the pandemic and Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, which since last year includes a £13.6billion business rates package slashing bills, a £27billion effective cut to corporation tax through full expensing, energy bills protection, £10billion in fuel duty cuts and simplifications to the tax system to save firms time and money.
“The UK has a higher VAT registration threshold than any EU member state and the second highest in the OECD, which keeps most businesses out of VAT altogether.”

title: How I Make My Money: Graphic designer on £2.5k per month with a £1.5k vegan shampoo side hustle
lead: Nicola Wordsworth would love to go full-time with her side-hustle of making vegan shampoo for dogs – and dreams of investment from Dragon’s Den star Deborah Meaden
author: Jane Denton

body.text: In our  we aim to find out how people in the UK are earning their cash and making a living.

This week we speak to Nicola Wordsworth, 56, who lives in Minnis Bay, Kent, with her two dogs, Bertie and Mabel. Nicola has one daughter, Emily, 29. By day, Nicola is a graphic designer, but she’s also running a blossoming side-hustle shampoo bar business for dogs, Pup Suds. She used to make 100 shampoo bars a night in a tiny household kitchen and has ambitions to get on Dragon’s Den and secure an investment from multi-millionaire businesswoman Deborah Meaden.
Income: I make £2,500 a month from my job as a senior graphic designer and studio manager at Whybrow Studio. I make about £1,500 a month from my side-hustle business, Pup Suds.
My main monthly outgoings: Mortgage, £550; groceries, £300; utility bills, £300; council tax, £145; car fuel, £100; car lease, £150.

By day I work as a senior graphic designer and studio manager at Whybrow Studio in Margate. I work four days a week, earning £2,500 a month. I work on large-scale jobs, often pulling together tenders for projects worth more than £400,000, and work with clients like the British Library and Castle Howard.

I’m also a massive dog lover. My eldest dog, a Tibetan Terrier, Bertie, is divine. He’s totally zen and makes me late for everything as people are always stopping to tell me how gorgeous he is; and, boy, does he know it! Recently, I’ve got Bertie’s niece, Mabel, who is eight weeks old. She is causing me many sleepless nights as she settles in.

Up to three days a week, including weekends, and three evenings a week, I work, along with my daughter, on my burgeoning , . I set it up during lockdown as most of my work dried up and I wanted to keep busy. I make solid vegan shampoo bars for dogs. Naturally, Bertie was my inspiration for the business, as he is always up to his belly in seaweed, sand and water and sometimes rolls around in stinky stuff. Most of the products I tried on him weren’t very good or eco-friendly. He’s become the poster boy for Pup Suds.
I managed to save myself about £20,000 in set-up costs as I was able to do things like get a website going and sort out the branding for the business myself.

At the moment I make about £1,500 a month from my side-hustle and can sell anything from 10 solid shampoo bars a week to more than 200 a week. The best seller by far is the “Massaging Anti-Stink Anti-Fox Poo’ bar, which is £10. My costs have been rising so I might have to increase my prices, but I don’t want to. I like the fact I don’t have to deal with pitches or proposals all the time. People either buy the products or they don’t. I get a real buzz getting up in the morning and finding orders in the online basket. We also go to fairs and dog shows.

Wholesalers have become involved, and we sell products in some overseas locations too now. We have even secured a potential listing with a UK-based retailer in Dubai to sell our products in fifteen stores out there. However, this deal is, for one reason or another, in limbo.

When I first started my side-hustle, my family and friends were a little sceptical and thought it was just a little hobby. But since making lots of sales and even winning awards, they are now fully behind it and proud of my achievements.

Getting the production line in order at the beginning was a challenge. I used to make 100 shampoo bars a night in a small standard kitchen in my former house. I had the best smelling house for miles, but it was tough juggling a production line and cramming worktops, a desk and dining table with the moulds needed.

Bringing in extra income from Pup Suds has been really helpful. I moved house, to what I call my “Old Lady Bungalow”, in December last year. With additional income coming in I was able to sort out a garage conversion for my new home, at a cost of £15,000. I’ve created a bespoke production line and manufacturing space in the garage. I’ve gone for the industrial look and have a commercial microwave and mixer, which I use for some of the products. I can now grow the business, before eventually taking the plunge and renting a unit somewhere.

I’m so tempted to get on the BBC television show Dragon’s Den and try to secure an investment for Pup Suds. I think my products are right up their street, particularly for Deborah Meaden. The prospect of investment is somewhat daunting as it’s not something I have experience of, but it’s an exciting proposition.

It would be great to be able to make about £100,000 a year from my business. I don’t necessarily want the stress that goes with having a multi-million pound business, as I have run a large business before, and it is very stressful and can stop being fun. But I still want to make Pup Suds into a decent business and even better than it is now.

I would love to be able to give up my day job as a graphic designer and focus on my side-hustle business full-time. I’d be able to work with dogs every day, and having the opportunity to run a family business with my daughter full-time would be a dream. If we secure more retailers this could happen sooner rather than later!

title: ‘The cost of insuring our two Teslas has gone up to £5.6k a year’: Why electric car insurance is so expensive
lead: Electric vehicles are often more costly to insure although insurance costs are going up for all vehicles
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Alex Gosney and his wife, Rachel, expected an increase when they asked for a car insurance renewal quote for their two Teslas, as Alex had received three points for speeding.
But even so the quote they received shocked them: their bill . Put another way, the bill just for their car insurance alone is now £450 a month.
“This is an increase of £3,800 – an amount we just did not expect,” said Alex, 34, who owns one Tesla outright and with his wife pays off the other one each
“If one of the cars wasn’t leased, we would have given it up, but we do have two young children we need to take to school and we both work full time, so having two cars is convenient,” he added.
The Gosneys say that they will consider other makes of car in future

The initial quote came from their existing insurer, Admiral. They turned to comparison sites to see if there were any better offers, and then a broker – but all to no avail. And so they stuck with the first offer.

“In fact, Admiral seemed to have the best deal. One of the quotes that came back was for £8,000,” Alex said. “We are fortunate that we have two incomes and so can just about afford it but other families will not be so lucky.

“For our next car, we will have to do more research to see which vehicles are cheaper to insure. If a hybrid is cheaper we will opt for that but for sustainability purposes, we’re going backwards to go forwards.”
Why have insurance costs for electric vehicles gone up so much?
One of the main reasons why policies can be so extortionate is because Teslas are electric vehicles, which are more expensive to insure because their repair costs are higher.

Figures from the price comparison site Compare the Market show that the cost of car insurance is rising faster for electric vehicles than petrol-fuelled cars. The typical EV premium has risen by £274 year-on-year, while insurance for a petrol-fuelled car has increased by £250.

Julie Daniels, a motor insurance expert at Compare the Market, said: “This increase may in part be due to insurers facing higher repair costs. The rapid rise in inflation will have probably affected many areas of the motor repair industry including the cost of spare parts, energy and hiring specialist mechanics.

“Insurance for EVs usually costs more as these cars are typically more expensive to purchase than petrol-fuelled equivalents. This means these vehicles are often also more costly to repair or replace. Replacing some parts of electric vehicles such as new batteries can be particularly costly.”
Batteries drive up the cost of electric car insurance so much as all use lithium ion batteries which are complex and expensive to repair or replace.
Data from the insurer Axa also recently revealed that when electric cars crash, they are more expensive to fix and can do more damage than other vehicles.

Louise Thomas, a motoring expert at , said: “EVs typically use smarter technology or have more expensive parts than others so if an EV driver ever needed to make a claim, this would more likely cost their insurer a lot more to repair or replace compared to other vehicles. This includes smaller claims, too.”
While shopping around for a quote can help to curb some of the costs, car insurance prices are going up across the board.
The average bill is now £511, and the industry blames and increased repair costs for the steep increases, which are expected to continue.

title: I had to sell my car because my insurance went up by nearly 50%
lead: The cost of owning a car has soared for many drivers, leaving them with a difficult decision as to whether they can afford it anymore
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Amy Downes had been driving a car for 17 years but said the increasing costs of tax, petrol and
“I feel like I’ve lost my independence, but the costs were too high,” says Amy, a 39-year-old freelance writer who lives in Leeds with her husband and two children.
“I’ve been driving for nearly 20 years and live far from my family so it made seeing them easier and it was good to be able to take my children everywhere.”
What made the decision was the , which went up £121 this year – a rise of 48 per.  Then there was the bigger tax bill, which has risen from £165 to £216 since 2016.
“My husband and I were shocked when we received the insurance bill. This alongside paying £60 for fuel each month.”

On average, car insurance has soared , according to the Office for National Statistics. The average bill is now £511, and the industry blames and increased repair costs for the steep increases, which are expected to continue. August also fuel price rises, the RAC said, as the price of petrol rose by 6.68p a litre while diesel shot up by 8p.
This has left some with difficult choices about whether owning a car is now financially feasible.

Amy said it started to become much easier to spend £5 for her and her sons, ages seven and four, to get return bus tickets when heading out for the day as opposed to spending larger sums on filling up her car with petrol. Her husband has still kept his car, which he uses to commute to work.

“My eldest has now started school which is in walking distance. As I am self employed, there are also times I am struggling for income which means unexpected costs, like repairs, can be difficult to manage.”
However, she admits it was a difficult decision to make.

“It was a massive decision but it was just not viable anymore. We were told replacing our tyres in the MOT would cost £300 while to repair the clutch it would cost £325. It felt like it was only going to get worse financially.”

Other costs that factored into the decision to sell included the fact it was a struggle to clean the vehicle as they have no access to a hose at home and the expense of parking. The environmental impact of owning a petrol car also swayed her decision.
Unfortunately, when the couple did sell the car, they got far less than expected. They had bought the Peugeot 206 in 2015, second hand, for £4,000.
However, they only got £260 for it on WeBuyAnyCar.com last month.
“This was very disappointing as we were hoping to use the money from the sale to go towards our other .”
Even though she hopes that by selling her car, she will now be more comfortable financially, Amy said it has left her with much less freedom.

“The fact I can’t just pack up and go is difficult. I am missing out on networking opportunities as I can’t easily get there. There has been a fair bit of sacrifice. But the car felt like a luxury at a time I’m not convinced we should have so many.”

title: Who is eligible for the water bill repayment? Which firms will have to pay compensation and the areas affected
lead: Water firms have been ordered to pay back £114m to customers by lowering bills, after industry regular Ofwat criticised them for poor standards
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: to customers by lowering bills, after industry regular Ofwat criticised them for poor standards.
It comes after failing to meet key targets on reducing , leakage and supply interruptions while customer satisfaction continues to fall, Ofwat said.
Ofwat judges the performance of water companies in England and Wales each year. If they fail to meet certain targets, the regulator restricts the amount of money they can take from customers.

Not one company achieved Ofwat’s top category of “leading”, while Dŵr Cymru, Southern, Thames, Anglian, Bristol, South East and Yorkshire Water fell into the lowest category of “lagging”. The remaining 10 were rated “average”.
The following water companies have been ordered to cut bills:
The five companies expected to pay out the most are Thames, Southern, Dŵr Cymru, Anglian and Yorkshire Water.
Apart from Dŵr Cymru, which has no shareholders, these companies are owned by various pension and investment funds based all over the world. Some have debt piles that run into the billions.
is the company that must return the most – more than £101m – followed by Southern Water which must pay out £43m.
Thames Water serves 15 million people with water and wastewater while Southern Water serves about 4.6 million.
The net total industry amount of £114m is offset by some companies being rewarded, such as Severn Trent Water taking £88m and United Utilities taking £25m.
As the figures are provisional, Ofwat has not yet revealed how much customers may see their bills reduced by.
David Black, Ofwat CEO, said: “The targets we set for companies were designed to be stretching – to drive improvements for customers and the environment.
“However, our latest report shows they are falling short, leading to £114m being returned to customers through bill reductions.
“While that may be welcome to bill payers, it is very disappointing news for all who want to see the sector do better.

“It is not going to be easy for companies to regain public trust, but they have to start with better service for customers and the environment. We will continue to use all our powers to ensure the sector delivers better value.”
Mike Keil, senior director at the Consumer Council for Water, said: “Customers are tired of not getting the service they deserve for the things they care about.

“It’s right and fair that people get their money back when they don’t receive the services they were promised by some water companies. People want assurance that their water bill is good value for money.”
A Water UK spokesperson said: “Today’s figures show that, in many areas, there have been significant improvements since the start of the decade.

“There were fewer incidents of serious pollution and less leakage from our ageing water infrastructure. However, companies recognise there is still much more to do to meet the regulator’s ever-tightening targets.
“Ensuring the security of our water supply in the future while protecting the will take significant investment.
“That’s why water companies in England and Wales are proposing record levels of investment over the rest of this decade, with detailed plans set to be published next week.”

title: Money Clinic: ‘My partner and I have separated but he won’t continue paying our mortgage. What can I do?’
lead: Nicholas Mendes helps a reader who has been caught out by their partner refusing to continue paying their mortgage
author: Nicholas Mendes

body.text: Is the mortgage market turbulence getting you down? Have you got a mortgage-related question you need answering? Email in and we’ll get one of our experts to reply. Nick Mendes, mortgage technical manager at John Charcol, has given his advice to a reader below. If you have a question for our experts, email us at

Question: My ex-partner and I have recently separated after eight years together. We lived together in a home we jointly bought, and we had a joint mortgage. He’s now moved out, and is renting, as it wasn’t feasible for us to continue to live together after the split. The only problem is he has now said he won’t continue. Is there anything I can do in this situation? What are my rights?

Answer: Going through divorce or separation is . That said, it’s actually not uncommon for one partner to move out and refuse to maintain the mortgage payments or uphold their end of an agreement when it comes to financial outgoing.
Be reassured that . There will be some extremely severe consequences if they try to.

The first thing I would recommend you do in this situation is to inform your lender. You should then consider seeking legal advice. Lenders will show leniency when mortgages are kept up to date, which means they could look to reduce your monthly payments by converting to interest only or extending the term.
Lenders could also look to change the mortgage from a joint to a sole depending on affordability.

With a joint mortgage you and your ex-partner are both equally liable for the mortgage and moving out of the property doesn’t relinquish your agreement with the lender. A lender can choose to chase either party jointly or individually for payment including any costs, legals fees or loss made upon any possible repossession.

If one party chooses to not pay it is important that the other party doesn’t follow the same course, as refusing to pay the mortgage can impact your credit file meaning it will be harder to secure a mortgage or credit in the future.
In the event your existing lender doesn’t deem it would be affordable to transfer the mortgage into your sole name you could consider any of the following –
I would recommend you speak with your lender to understand your options, it would also be advisable to speak with a solicitor to understand other options.
Lastly, speak with a broker. If you existing lender doesn’t feel that the mortgage is affordable one lender view doesn’t reflect the market.
A mortgage broker will be able to review your circumstances and potentially find another lender that can raise the funds you need to clear the mortgage and refinance into your sole name.

title: How being LGBTQ+  can affect your money, from higher property costs to lower salaries and smaller pensions
lead: Having a gender identity outside of the “norm” means you are likely to encounter several inequalities
author: Annabelle Williams

body.text: and shining a light on areas that are often overlooked – such as how sexual orientation or gender identity interacts with a person’s ability to thrive financially.
While everyone grapples with money and no one finds it easy to increase their pay, build a decent retirement fund or reach their financial goals, LGBTQ+ people can face additional barriers.

That is not to say that all LGBTQ+ people are worse off or face the same issues.  It does mean it is important to recognise that, despite all the progress that’s been made for LGBTQ+ equity and inclusion, even today life paths that differ from “the norm” and the impact of discrimination in the past or present all come with a cost.
In other ways, being LGBTQ+ just means having additional things to consider when it comes to financial planning.
Here are some of the factors that may affect an LGBTQ+ person’s finances.

It is difficult to build a full picture of how being LGBTQ+ affects a person financially because population data has typically been gathered using traditional definitions of “male”, “female”, “husband” and “wife”. What we know about people’s earnings, tax, pensions, credit scores, mortgages – virtually every aspect of money – is based on this assumption of a gender binary.

There is increasing recognition these data models don’t tell the full story and things are changing – for example, the Census asked about gender identity and sexual orientation for the first time in 2021 – but it will take time before the data gap is bridged.
Academic studies from around the world are filling part of the data gap. Some findings include:

Living in a neighbourhood where they’ll feel safe and supported by others like them . But renting or buying a home in one of the big LGBTQ+ communities in Manchester, Brighton or London can cost significantly more than elsewhere. Even within those cities, a person who identifies as LGBTQ+ will still probably have to spend more to be able to buy or rent in an area that feels progressive and accepting.

It takes a national average of 5.7 years for a first-time buyer to save a deposit with the help of the Lifetime ISA,. But for a first home in Brighton it would take 8.8 years and in London it would be 10.8 years.

Higher property prices in these areas can be a factor when it comes to retirement planning, as homeowners often downsize to a smaller property in a cheaper area when they are older, to release equity from their home which they live off in retirement. Someone who is LGBTQ+ may be less willing to move away from the community or feel they have fewer choices about where to live. This underscores why it is so important to have pension savings, rather than relying on property wealth for retirement.
Despite all the progress made for LGBTQ+ equality, discrimination persists. Studies have found gay men and lesbian women are less likely to be invited for a job interview,  and .

It’s still not easy to be “out” in the workplace. Sometimes people “go back in the closet” when they change job, if they sense the environment is not safe. Stress from the ongoing effort of modifying behaviour to fit in at work, changing a partner’s pronouns or dodging the topic during office chats about family or holiday plans can take its toll and people in this situation are less likely to stay in their job.
The flipside is that many employers value the benefits of a diverse workforce. LGBTQ+ people’s careers can thrive even more when they find an inclusive organisation with the right cultural fit.

Campaigners have successfully challenged historical discriminatory policies in all areas of life, including financial services. For example, until rules were changed in 1994, insurers would ask customers if they had ever taken a HIV test in the assumption that testing was an indicator of someone having a “riskier” lifestyle.

In the past, pension providers did not recognise same-sex partners when it came to “survivor benefits’” This meant that when a straight person died their remaining pension went to their opposite-sex partner, but when someone in a same-sex relationship died their pension went with them. Since 2017 same-sex couples have had the same rights – not very long ago.
While laws and social norms have changed, it is understandable that some LGBTQ+ individuals might have bitter memories or continue to feel alienated by industries that did not support them.
There is still work that needs to be done and things are far from perfect, but banks, investment managers, financial advisers and pension providers are trying harder to ‘speak’ to LGBTQ+ customers.

Tweaks to policies such as using customers’ preferred pronouns or offering gender-neutral titles may be small ways of showing respect towards different identities, but over time their impact could be much bigger.

By knowing who their customers really are, companies can help with financial inclusion, close the data gap and create services tailored to the individual, regardless of someone’s sexual orientation or gender identity.
Annabelle Williams is a personal finance specialist at Nutmeg

title: How much it will cost to run your washing machine, fridge and other appliances as energy price cap goes down
lead: Energy prices are still much higher than they were before the pandemic
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Households are set to see their  decrease later  however, they will still be paying hundreds of pounds more a year when compared to before the pandemic.
, which limits the unit cost of gas and electricity and standing charges and not the total bill, is falling to an average of £1,923 a year from October 1, down from the current level of £2,074.
As a result, the average weekly cost for a family to use a  will go down 12p (assuming six washes a week), and using a tumble dryer will be 42p cheaper per week.
Overall, homeowners will be paying £1.11 less a week –  and £53.36 a year for using the most popular appliances – the oven, washing machine, fridge, TV, tumble dryer and dishwasher.
Bigger families and those using more energy could save more money than this.
However, how much they pay is still significantly up from what was paid before the pandemic, with the average household spending £125.88 more now compared with 2019.
Despite the fall in the price cap, the energy regulator has decided to increase , which are a fixed daily amount that you pay on your bill
Average daily standing charges, now at 52.97p for electricity and 29.11p for gas, will nudge up to 53.37p and 29.62p.
This is up 8 per cent for gas and 119 per cent for electricity since 2011, according to the End Fuel Poverty Coalition.

Natalie Mathie, energy expert at Uswitch, said: “Standing charges vary across the country due to the differing costs of transporting power to each region, so more rural locations may pay a higher amount due to the increased price of the necessary infrastructure.”
The average standing charge works out at around £299 a year, representing nearly 14 per cent of the average total energy bill.
It is expected that will stay above the pandemic level until at least the end of the decade, according to Cornwall Insight, which said higher prices could well be “the new normal”.

This compares to 2019 when households could fix an annual deal of £800 or lower from multiple companies. Prices started to rise after several suppliers collapsed and Russia invaded Ukraine, damaging supply chains and stocks.
i, with help from Uswitch, compared how much people will be paying to use their home appliances this week compared to next.
It also compared how much people will be paying compared to three years ago when energy prices were over £1,000 a year lower.

It found that the annual cost of using an oven, at six hours a week, is £157.44 as of next week, down from £172.80 currently but up from £103.86 in 2019. This is an increase of 34 per cent over just four years.
Similarly, the cost of using a washing machine, when calculating six cycles a week, will go to £54.72, up from £37.44 in 2019.
Another big jump is for the cost of a fridge, which is on all the time. Although reducing by 9 per cent as of Sunday, it is still 40 per cent more expensive than 2019, up from £29.88 to £45.40.
Using a tumble dryer six times a week will increase costs from £129.60 in 2019 to £195.84 as of October. This is slightly down from £216 currently.
Meanwhile, a dishwasher’s cost, when also used six times a week, will rise from £40.32 a year as of four years ago to £63.36 as of Sunday. This is down marginally from £69.12 at present.
For those who have a larger family or use more energy, the prices are expected to be much higher.
Campaigners have said families will find it harder this winter to cope as there is less support from the Government this year.

Simon Francis, co-ordinator of the End Fuel Poverty Coalition, said: “Average energy bills are still almost double what they were three years ago and , has been axed. This means this winter will feel worse for many households.”

title: UK households to pay £3,500 a year more in tax since Boris Johnson became Prime Minister
lead: Taxes are set to hit 37 per cent of national income next year, a new report says
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Households are on track to pay £3,500 more tax each year than they did when Boris Johnson came to power in 2019, analysis has shown.

Taxes are set to hit a record-breaking 37 per cent of national income next year, up from 33 per cent when Theresa May left Number 10 according to a report by the independent economic think tank, the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS).
This means the Government more a year in tax revenue from across the UK, resulting in the average household paying £3,500  more a year in tax on average on top of having to pay for

Johnson and Sunak have, between them, increased the tax take over the four years they have been in charge of the country more than any other other prime minister with Tony Blair the second highest. Only in the aftermath of the two world wars have government revenues grown by as much as they have now.

Sunak and Hunt have done this primarily through awhere a chancellor doesn’t increase the rate of, say, income tax, instead they freeze tax thresholds by not increasing them in line with inflation. As wages are pushed up by inflation it means more people are dragged into higher tax thresholds, or have to pay tax for the first time.

Sir Iain Duncan Smith, the former Tory leader, said: “The scale of taxation stifles hard work, innovation and revenues – as it is well known that higher levels of taxation lead to falling tax receipts. We need economic growth as a priority. Or the UK will fall into a form of economic purgatory and those least able to pay will suffer the most – £3,500 per household is an enormous burden.”

But a Treasury source insisted that the size of the tax take was not the fault of ministers, saying the country has suffered two economic shocks – Covid and the war in Ukraine – that “required the state to borrow £400bn”. The source added: “It was the right thing to to do, but it has to be paid for.”

The IFS report said that since comparable records began in the 1950s, “no parliament has presided over a bigger increase in taxes”. Notable examples include the big increase in the main rate of corporation tax from 19 to 25 per cent,  and the freezes to various income tax and National Insurance thresholds.
Once considered a relatively low tax country, Britain is now ‘climbing up the ranks’ as it moves it joins the higher taxed countries, Ben Zaranko, senior research economist at IFS, told i.
“The key thing people need to know going into next year and the general election is that neither party is being open with the public about the unfortunate reality that higher taxes are here to stay.

“We are going to see even more tax rises after the next election so the party can avoid making cuts to public services. The British people just aren’t being presented with an honest assessment of what we are going to face.”
He added that the pandemic was “far from the only – or even the most significant – explanation for the tax rises.”
Instead manifesto promises that pre-date the pandemic, such as expanding the NHS workforce and relaxing austerity, are the main reasons, along with paying for an ageing population.
“It is likely this parliament will mark a decisive and permanent shift to a higher-tax economy. It looks nailed on to be the biggest tax-raising parliament since at least the Second World War.”
During , from 1996 to 2001, taxes increased by 2.9 per cent of national income, making up 33.1 per cent of GDP by the end of his first term.

Under Margaret Thatcher, between 1979 to 1990, taxes rose by 2.6 per cent of national income over her first term, from 30.4 to 33 per cent, but overall during her premiership they decreased from 30.4 to 30.3 per cent.
Now the only way taxes could decrease is if the public could accept cuts to services such as the NHS, defence or the state pension, Zaranko said.

He said a means testing model could be introduced where only people who have lower income or fewer assets could get the state pension. Alternatively, the NHS could start charging for some NHS services or the Government could spend less on defence.
However, the Government haven’t showed much of an appetite for this, and have said any tax cuts would have to sit alongside spending cuts.

Mark Franks, director of welfare at the Nuffield Foundation, said: “There will be strong pressure in coming parliaments to raise taxes further to meet growing demand for public services such as healthcare.

“Future governments must not only have a credible and robust strategy for the economy and the public finances, but should also be forthright and transparent about the difficult trade-offs they will face.”

title: How to sign up for the National Grid energy scheme, and how much the demand flexibility service could save you
lead: The plan is designed to combat power blackouts during winter, and was first introduced in 2022 due to Europe’s gas squeeze caused by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: is  its  (DFS), which rewards customers for switching off appliances at peak times.
The plan is  during the winter. It was first introduced in 2022 due to Europe’s gas squeeze caused by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
ESO said it successfully saved more than 3,300MWh across 22 critical supply events last winter – enough to power nearly 10 million homes.
It is now pushing to broaden the scheme and encouraging more consumers and businesses to sign up.
People who sign up to the scheme are asked to avoid using power-hungry appliances during a stated time period to ease strain on the power network, saving it money.
In return, suppliers are rewarded, and they in turn are expected to pass on a saving to their customers involved in the scheme.

The scheme is not about getting people to sit in the dark and not use vital power. Power-guzzling appliances such as washing machines, clothes dryers, dishwashers, electric showers and immersion heaters are the ones to avoid using during the energy-saving periods.
Efficient lightbulbs and small appliances such as modern televisions consume very little electricity and so it is unlikely to be worth adapting usage of these during an event.
Customers with a smart meter whose energy supplier offers the service are eligible to sign up.
ESO says it expects participating electricity providers to contact eligible customers from late October with details about how to enrol.

“If you have signed up to take part in the DFS scheme your electricity provider will contact you before a demonstration test or live event and ask if you want to participate in the following day’s event,” ESO said.

“Demonstration tests will run for one hour, however live events could run for a longer period. There are no penalties for not participating once you have signed up to the DFS or notified your electricity provider that you will take part in a demonstration test or live event. In order to be eligible to receive an incentive from your provider, you do however have to participate.”
Your supplier should give you about £3 for every kWh of electricity you save – last year, suppliers said this could add up to £100 of savings over a five-month period.
However, the decision on how much to pass on is down to each individual supplier.
Craig Dyke, the Grid’s head of national control, said, but that it still made sense to bring back the DFS.
“Energy markets across Europe have responded,  ahead of this winter,” he said.

“While this is reflected in slightly higher operational margins for this winter, we and the rest of the energy industry will as always continue to prepare for a range of potential eventualities, so that we are fully prepared for any changes in circumstances this winter.

“To support our preparations, we have chosen to reintroduce the demand flexibility service for this winter, following the impressive response from consumers and businesses to act as virtual power plants.”
ESO said it only expects there to be around six minutes between the end of October and the end of March where it might have to resort to special measures to keep the grid running smoothly.

A Government spokesperson said: “These outlooks show we are in an even stronger position going into this winter than last, thanks to the efforts we have made to boost our energy security, with our system operators expecting there to be sufficient gas supply and electricity capacity to meet demand.
“We are confident in our plans to protect families and businesses in a wide range of scenarios, but we are not complacent and will continue to work closely with energy partners at home and abroad.”

title: Hidden mortgage fees mean homeowners could be paying more than ever despite rates falling
lead: Some homeowners could find they are paying more on their mortgage now than when rates were at their peak
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Mortgage holders could find themselves paying more now than whenhave been found to be upping their fees by as much as 60 per cent.
Some leading two-year fixed deals in July, proved to be cheaper than those currently on the market despite rates coming down, research by Which?, exclusive to i, reveals.
This is because providers are increasing their arrangement fee – also know as product fee – which most come with. They usually cost between £999 and £1,999 and are charged by lenders.
Now many providers are increasing these fees, offsetting mortgage rates coming down, with some charging nearly £3,000 – money which could
Skipton Building Society is the worst offender, charging £2,995 on its five-year deals for those with 10 per cent, 15 per cent and 25 per cent deposits.

Ele Clark, senior money editor at Which?, said: “While several lenders are reducing products’ headline rates, some have also hiked their arrangement fees, meaning that a number of borrowers could actually have secured a cheaper deal back in July, when mortgage rates were higher.
“The market is complicated for borrowers and choosing a new deal is not as straightforward as picking the cheapest rate – it’s vital to look at the overall cost.”

Which? compared the top 10 leading products available on 25 September with the top 10 deals available two months ago on 24 July across four different deposit brackets including 40, 25, 10 and 5 per cent deposits using Moneyfacts data.
Of the 40 leading products, 15 were fee-free in July. In contrast, on 25 September there were no fee-free products in the top 40.
The average fee for a product with a 40 per cent deposit was £718 in July, but this has now risen to £1,157 – an increase of 61 per cent.
Separate data from Moneyfacts found the average mortgage fee has risen for two consecutive months, increasing to £662 in September. This is the highest on its records since April 2021 (£663).
At the same time, average fixed rates dropped this month. Last month, the average two-year fixed rate was 6.85 per cent the highest since August 2008 when it reached 6.94 per cent.
Now the average five-year deal is under 6 per cent and the average two-year deal is 6.5 per cent.
Rachel Springall, finance expert at Moneyfacts, said: “Low-rate fixed mortgages can carry some of the highest fees, so they may not be the best choice for every borrower.”
So what does this mean for the cost of a mortgage? Which? compared the market-leading deal in September with the best fee-free deal from July, to find out the overall cost.
It crunched the numbers based on how much a homeowner would pay over a two-year fix on a £200,000 mortgage taken out over a 25-year term.

The analysis found that while borrowers who took out the best fee-free deal at a 40 or 25 per cent deposit in July would have been better off with September’s market-leading rates that are lower but come with a fee, the reverse is true for those with smaller deposits. It found that borrowers at 5 or 10 per cent deposit would have paid less in July, even though were higher.
So while interest rates on mortgage deals may have dropped, you need to check how the fee impacts what you pay back.
When searching for a mortgage deal, always look at the extra costs involved, these come under different guises, such as a product, arrangement or completion fee.

Banks commonly set fees between £999 and £1,999, but some use percentages instead – for example 0.5 per cent of the overall loan amount. If you’re borrowing a larger sum, this kind of fee can be significantly more expensive.
If you’re unsure about which type of deal to go for, a mortgage broker will be able to research deals based on their true cost, taking into account rates, fees and incentives such as cashback.
